questions.text: Which one of the following membranes has the highest content of protein per gram of tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inner mitochondrial membrane

 

  • The inner mitochondrial membrane has the highest content of proteins per gram of tissue. 
  • This membrane is packed with proteins because it contains the electron transport chain and ATP synthase complexes, which are essential for cellular respiration and energy production. 
  • These proteins are critical for oxidative phosphorylation, the process that generates ATP, the cell's energy currency. The high demand for energy in cells explains the abundance of protein in this membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outer mitochondrial membrane: The outer mitochondrial membrane has a balanced lipid-to-protein ratio of 1:1, meaning it does not have as high a concentration of proteins as the inner mitochondrial membrane.

 

Option B. Myelin sheath: The myelin sheath is rich in lipids rather than proteins. It primarily serves as insulation for nerve fibers, facilitating rapid transmission of electrical impulses. Therefore, the lipid content is much higher than the protein content.

 

Option D. Plasma membrane: The plasma membrane, like the outer mitochondrial membrane, has a lipid-to-protein ratio of about 1:1. It functions as a selective barrier around the cell, with proteins embedded within it, but it does not have as high a protein concentration as the inner mitochondrial membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inner mitochondrial membrane has the highest protein content among the listed membranes, reflecting its crucial role in energy production and cellular respiration.

choices.text: Increased hydrogen secretion via α-intercalated cells
Increased bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule
Impaired renal ammoniagenesis leading to inadequate acid excretion
Excessive loss of H⁺ via β-intercalated cells

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with confusion, lethargy, and asterixis. Arterial blood gas shows:

 

  • pH: 7.32
  • pCO₂: 60 mmHg
  • HCO₃⁻: 31 mEq/L

 

Lab values show:

 

  • Na⁺: 138 mEq/L
  • K⁺: 5.6 mEq/L
  • Cl⁻: 96 mEq/L

 

Urine pH is 6.8, and ammonium excretion is low. Which of the following best explains the renal action responsible in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Impaired renal ammoniagenesis leading to inadequate acid excretion

 

  • This is a case of chronic respiratory acidosis with partial metabolic compensation. 
  • The renal compensation involves increased ammoniagenesis, H⁺ secretion, and bicarbonate reabsorption. 
  • However, in advanced COPD, chronic hypoxia and renal dysfunction impair ammonia production, which is essential for excreting H⁺ as NH₄⁺.
  • This leads to incomplete compensation, persistent acidemia, and features like hyperkalemia and high urine pH (suggesting poor acid excretion).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased hydrogen secretion via α-intercalated cells: Should occur in compensation, but urine pH is high, indicating it’s not effective.

 

Option B. Increased bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule: Already elevated (HCO₃⁻ = 31), but not sufficient alone without ammoniagenesis.

 

Option D. Excessive loss of H⁺ via β-intercalated cells: β-intercalated cells secrete bicarbonate, not H⁺—this would worsen acidosis, not help.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In chronic respiratory acidosis, renal ammoniagenesis is key to acid excretion. 
  • Failure of this mechanism (e.g., in hypoxic states or CKD) leads to inadequate compensation despite elevated bicarbonate.

questions.text: Identify the treatment in the neonate having bilious vomiting, showing the below abdominal x-ray.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodeno-duodenostomy

 

  • Duodeno-duodenostomy is the surgical treatment of choice for duodenal atresia, a congenital condition in which the duodenum fails to recanalize during development. 
  • The procedure involves creating an anastomosis between the two segments of the duodenum to bypass the atresia. 
  • This approach restores intestinal continuity while preserving normal gastric emptying and physiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroduodenostomy: Gastroduodenostomy is not suitable for duodenal atresia as it does not address the atresia site in the duodenum. This procedure is typically used in other conditions like gastric outlet obstruction.

 

Option C. Gastrojejunostomy: Gastrojejunostomy bypasses the duodenum entirely and is used for distal gastric or duodenal obstructions that cannot be repaired directly. It is not indicated for congenital duodenal atresia.

 

Option D. Duodenojejunostomy: While duodenojejunostomy can also bypass the obstruction, it is not the preferred approach for duodenal atresia. Duodeno-duodenostomy is simpler, more physiological, and maintains continuity of the proximal small intestine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The "double bubble" sign on abdominal X-ray is pathognomonic for duodenal atresia, a congenital condition requiring surgical correction. 
  • Duodeno-duodenostomy is the treatment of choice, creating a direct anastomosis to bypass the atretic segment and restore intestinal continuity.
  • Early surgical intervention is critical for preventing complications such as malnutrition and aspiration.

choices.text: Square root of crown-rump length in cms
Square root of crown-heel length in cms
Crown-rump length in cms divided by 5
Crown-heel length in cms divided by 5

questions.text: According to Hasse’s rule, which of the following formulas is used to estimate the age of the fetus in months during the first 5 months of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Square root of crown-heel length in cms 

 

  • Square root of crown-heel length in cms is used to calculate age during the first 5 months of pregnancy as per Hasse`s rule.
  • Rule of Hasse- a rough method of calculating approximate age of the fetus by measuring the crown to heel length of the fetus.
    • During the first 5 months of pregnancy, 

Age (months)= square root of crown-heel length in centimeters

  •  During the last 5 months, 

Age (months)= crown-heel length in centimeters divided by 5

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hasse’s rule estimates fetal age during the first 5 months of pregnancy by calculating the square root of the crown-heel length in centimeters.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with episodic migraine (4 attacks/month) is started on a β-blocker for prophylaxis. Which agent should not be used because of its intrinsic sympathomimetic activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pindolol

 

  • Pindolol is a nonselective β-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA).
  • Its partial agonism at β-receptors blunts the full β-blocking effect needed for migraine prophylaxis. 
  • Because ISA maintains basal sympathetic tone, pindolol is less effective at reducing the vascular and neuronal hyperexcitability thought to trigger migraines, and is therefore not recommended for migraine prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Non-selective β-blocker with no intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA); commonly used for migraine prophylaxis.

 

Option B. Metoprolol: β1-selective blocker with no ISA; also used for migraine prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Atenolol: β1-selective blocker without ISA; used in migraine prophylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For migraine prevention, choose a β-blocker without ISA—such as propranolol, metoprolol, or atenolol—and avoid agents like pindolol that exhibit intrinsic sympathomimetic activity.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with OCD undergoes neuroimaging as part of a study. Structural abnormalities are likely to be found in which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caudate nucleus

 

  • Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is associated with dysfunction in cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical (CSTC) circuits, particularly involving the orbitofrontal cortex, anterior cingulate cortex, and basal ganglia.
  • Within the basal ganglia, the caudate nucleus plays a central role in filtering intrusive thoughts and regulating repetitive behaviors. 
  • Abnormalities in this region — including hyperactivity and structural changes — are commonly reported in OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Occipital cortex: This region is mainly involved in visual processing and is not typically implicated in OCD pathophysiology.

 

Option C. Hippocampus: While important for memory and emotional regulation, the hippocampus is more commonly affected in mood disorders (like depression and PTSD) rather than OCD.

 

Option D. Parietal lobe: Responsible for sensory integration and spatial orientation, the parietal lobe has no primary role in OCD’s core symptoms of obsessions and compulsions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Structural and functional imaging studies in OCD frequently implicate the caudate nucleus, a component of the CSTC loop involved in the pathogenesis of obsessions and compulsions.

choices.text: Catheter‐associated urinary tract infection on day 4 of hospitalization
Pneumonia developing on day 3 after admission
MRSA colonization in a patient new to the hospital with no prior hospitalization
Central line–associated bloodstream infection on day 5

questions.text: Which of the following does not meet the standard criteria for a healthcare‐associated infection (HAI)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MRSA colonization in a patient new to the hospital with no prior hospitalization

 

  • An HAI is an infection that
    • Infection contracted at the time of admission 
    • Was not present or incubating on admission,
    • Manifests ≥48 hours after admission,
    • Includes infections appearing after discharge but attributable to hospitalization, and
    • Covers occupational infections among healthcare staff (but only for surveillance, not patient HAIs).
    • Symptoms appearing within 3 days after discharge or <30 days for general surgeries or <90 days after prosthetic surgeries (heart valve implants, breast implants, orthopedic implants)
  • MRSA colonization without signs or symptoms is not an infection; it lacks tissue invasion or host response and therefore falls outside HAI definitions.
  • Colonization in a newly admitted patient does not meet the “acquired during care” or “clinically infected” criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catheter‐associated urinary tract infection on day 4 of hospitalization: Occurrence ≥48 hours after admission in a patient without UTI on arrival meets HAI criteria.

 

Option B. Pneumonia developing on day 3 after admission: Onset ≥48 hours post-admission qualifies as a hospital-acquired pneumonia.

 

Option D. Central line–associated bloodstream infection on day 5: Infection occurring ≥48 hours after central line placement is classified as an HAI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asymptomatic MRSA carriage in a new admission is colonization, not a healthcare-associated infection—HAIs require clinical infection acquired during care.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy presents with vaginal dryness, dry eyes requiring cessation of contact lenses, and increased dental caries despite no prior history. Examination shows reduced saliva pooling and bilateral parotid fullness, with regular menses and no arthralgias or rash. What is she at highest risk of long-term?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignancy
 

  • The patient’s dry eyes, dry mouth, parotid fullness, and dental caries suggest Sjögren’s syndrome, an autoimmune disorder.
  • Sjögren’s increases the risk of non-Hodgkin lymphoma due to chronic inflammation and immune dysregulation.
  • Regular monitoring for lymphoproliferative disorders is essential in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Joint destruction: Is more common in rheumatoid arthritis, not Sjögren’s.

 

Option C. Life-threatening infection: Infections are a risk but not the primary long-term concern compared to lymphoma.

 

Option D. Pulmonary hypertension: Is associated with systemic sclerosis, not Sjögren’s.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sjögren’s syndrome increases the risk of non-Hodgkin lymphoma due to chronic inflammation.
  • Regular screening is critical for early detection of malignancy.

questions.text: In a fetus presenting in vertex presentation with the head in complete flexion attitude, which of the following is the engaging diameter of the fetal skull?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

 

  • In vertex presentation with complete flexion of the fetal head, the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter is the presenting and engaging diameter.
  • This is the smallest anteroposterior diameter of the fetal skull, measuring approximately 9.5 cm, extending from the suboccipital region to the center of the anterior fontanelle (bregma).
  • Complete flexion ensures that this smallest diameter passes through the birth canal, facilitating normal vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suboccipito-frontal diameter: Incorrect. This diameter (10 cm) engages when the fetal head is in incomplete flexion (partial flexion), not in complete flexion.

 

Option C. Occipito-frontal diameter: Incorrect. The occipito-frontal diameter (11.5 cm) engages when the head is in deflexion, seen in vertex presentations with no flexion or deflexion, which is less favorable for vaginal delivery.

 

Option D. Occipito-posterior position: Incorrect. This is a fetal position, not a diameter. It describes the orientation of the occiput relative to the maternal pelvis, typically associated with labor difficulties, but it does not refer to the presenting diameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a vertex presentation with complete flexion of the fetal head, the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is the presenting and engaging diameter, allowing optimal passage through the birth canal.

choices.text: Start levothyroxine 25 μg IV daily and T3 10 μg IV daily

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis, admitted for Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia and bacteremia, develops thyroid function abnormalities 1 week into hospitalization. A chest CT is done and shows multifocal infiltrates. Labs show TSH 1.2 mU/L (normal 0.5-5) and fT4 1.2 (normal 0.8 to 1.9 ng/mL), fT3 0.5 (normal 0.8-2 ng/mL). What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat thyroid tests after recovery
 

  • The chest CT shows multifocal infiltrates consistent with S. aureus pneumonia.
  • Low TSH (0.3 mU/L) and fT4 (0.7 ng/dL) suggest non-thyroidal illness syndrome (NTIS), common in critical illness like sepsis, reflecting an adaptive response.
  • Thyroid hormone replacement is not indicated; repeat testing after recovery is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start levothyroxine 25 μg IV daily: Levothyroxine IV is for primary hypothyroidism, not NTIS.

 

Option C. Start levothyroxine 25 μg IV daily and T3 10 μg IV daily: Combined T4/T3 is unnecessary in NTIS, which is transient.

 

Option D. Start levothyroxine 50 μg oral daily: Oral levothyroxine is inappropriate in critical illness and NTIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NTIS in critical illness presents with low thyroid hormone levels and does not require treatment.
  • Thyroid function should be reassessed after recovery.

choices.text: Olive-shaped palpable mass is best felt when the baby is crying
Peristalsis from the left to right side of abdomen may be seen on feeding

questions.text: A male child presented with non-bilious vomiting at 4 weeks of age. An X-ray was taken that shows the following. What is false regarding the above condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Olive-shaped palpable mass is best felt when the baby is crying

 

  • The scenario and the X ray (showing single bubble sign) suggests infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), a common cause of non-bilious projectile vomiting in infants around 3–6 weeks of age.
  • The mass is best felt during a calm moment or during feeding, not while the baby is crying. 
  • Crying tenses the abdominal muscles, making palpation difficult.
  • A test feed is often used to relax the baby and enhance palpation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It leads to hypokalemic alkalosis: True. Persistent vomiting causes loss of gastric hydrochloric acid, leading to:

 

  • Hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.
  • Secondary hypokalemia due to renal compensation and aldosterone-mediated potassium loss.

 

Option C. Peristalsis from the left to right side of abdomen may be seen on feeding: True. Visible gastric peristalsis is a hallmark sign.

 

  • Seen as waves moving left to right across the upper abdomen.
  • Reflects the stomach's effort to push contents past the obstructed pylorus.

 

Option D. Treatment involves Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy: True. This is the definitive surgical treatment.

 

  • Involves splitting the hypertrophied pyloric muscle to relieve obstruction.
  • Can be done via open or laparoscopic approach.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with fatigue, nausea, and confusion after a high-protein meal. Labs show elevated serum glutamate and mild hyperammonemia, but liver function is normal. Further testing indicates a mitochondrial enzyme involved in oxidative deamination is overactive. Notably, this enzyme can use both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as cofactors. Which of the following enzymes fits this description?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glutamate dehydrogenase

 

  • Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) catalyzes the conversion of glutamate to α-ketoglutarate and ammonia, crucial for amino acid and nitrogen metabolism.
  • It is unique in using both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as cofactors depending on cellular conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Has separate NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ isoforms, not dual use.

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase: Uses only NAD⁺.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Uses NAD⁺, not NADP⁺.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glutamate dehydrogenase is a mitochondrial enzyme critical in amino acid catabolism and nitrogen metabolism.
  • It uniquely uses both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as cofactors and catalyzes the oxidative deamination of glutamate, contributing to ammonia production.

questions.text: What is the maximum defibrillator shock energy that can be given to a pediatric patient during CPR?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10 J/kg

 

  • In pediatric cardiac arrest, the energy levels for defibrillation are carefully prescribed to be both effective and safe. 
  • The guidelines typically recommend:
    • Initial shock: The first defibrillation attempt should be at 2 J/kg. This initial energy level is chosen to provide sufficient electrical current to depolarize the cardiac cells and attempt to terminate the abnormal rhythm without causing unnecessary cardiac injury.
    • Second shock: If the first shock does not result in the return of a normal rhythm, a second shock may be delivered at 4 J/kg. The increase in energy aims to enhance the likelihood of achieving defibrillation if the lower energy was not successful.
    • Maximum shock energy: The maximum recommended energy level for subsequent shocks is usually up to 10 J/kg. This cap is set to prevent potential damage to the pediatric heart, which may be more susceptible to injury from high-energy shocks. In some cases, the adult maximum defibrillation dose may be used if it does not exceed the pediatric maximum of 10 J/kg.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The maximum defibrillation shock energy for pediatric CPR is 10 J/kg, intended to effectively terminate arrhythmic activity while minimizing the risk of cardiac injury in children.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with dull, persistent throat pain radiating to the ear for the past 3 months. The pain worsens when she turns her head to the left or swallows. She also complains of a foreign body sensation in the throat and mild difficulty swallowing. On examination, a bony projection is palpable in the tonsillar fossa. She has a history of tonsillectomy done 5 years ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Eagle syndrome

 

  • Eagle syndrome is caused by an elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament, and is often seen post-tonsillectomy or after pharyngeal trauma.
  • It presents in two forms:
    1. Classic Eagle syndrome:
      • Dull pharyngeal pain referred to the ear
      • Pain worsens with head rotation
      • Palpable mass/bulge in tonsillar fossa
      • Dysphagia, foreign body sensation, tinnitus
      • Commonly bilateral
    2. Stylocarotid syndrome: Vascular compression symptoms (carotid artery)
  • In this case, the classic form is described. 
  • The key features—post-tonsillectomy, pharyngeal pain referred to the ear, pain with head movement, and tonsillar bulge—are hallmark clues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal neuralgia: Sudden, sharp, shock-like pain—not dull and persistent—and no tonsillar mass or post-tonsillectomy association.

 

Option B. Peritonsillar abscess: Presents acutely with fever, trismus, and unilateral swelling; not chronic and bilateral.

 

Option D. Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dysfunction: Presents with jaw pain aggravated by chewing, clicking sounds—not throat pain or tonsillar mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eagle syndrome is a post-tonsillectomy complication characterized by elongated styloid process causing pharyngeal and ear pain, tonsillar bulge, and dysphagia. 
  • It is diagnosed clinically and treated with styloidectomy if analgesics fail.

choices.text: Provide supportive care and blood product replacement

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with acute pulmonary embolism is receiving fondaparinux. She develops a life-threatening gastrointestinal bleed. Which is the most appropriate next step in managing her anticoagulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Provide supportive care and blood product replacement

 

  • Fondaparinux is a synthetic pentasaccharide that selectively inhibits factor Xa via antithrombin III and lacks a specific antidote. 
  • Protamine only neutralizes heparin and partially LMWH, not fondaparinux. Vitamin K reverses vitamin K–dependent factors (II, VII, IX, X) but does not affect direct or indirect factor Xa inhibitors.
  • Recombinant factor VIIa may enhance thrombin generation but carries high thrombotic risk and is not routinely recommended. 
  • Therefore, management focuses on supportive measures—stop the drug, hemodynamic stabilization, transfusion of packed red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma or prothrombin complex concentrates as needed, and local hemostatic control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer protamine sulfate: Ineffective against fondaparinux; no binding affinity. It is antidote for heparin 

 

Option B. Give intravenous vitamin K: Does not restore antithrombin–Xa inhibition; irrelevant to fondaparinux’s mechanism. It is antidote for warfarin

 

Option C. Infuse recombinant factor VIIa: Off-label and high-risk for thrombosis; not first-line for fondaparinux bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fondaparinux has no reversal agent—treat severe bleeding with supportive measures, including drug discontinuation, volume resuscitation, and judicious use of blood products or procoagulant concentrates.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with symptoms of depression. He is started on a medication ‘A’ that improves depressive symptoms but causes sedation and weight gain. The drug is known to antagonize central α2-adrenergic receptors and 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be medicine ‘A’?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mirtazapine

 

  • Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that improves depressive symptoms through antagonism of central α2-adrenergic receptors (which increases norepinephrine and serotonin release) and blockade of 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors.
  •  This mechanism enhances serotonergic neurotransmission while minimizing certain serotonergic side effects. 
  • Mirtazapine is also a potent H1 histamine receptor blocker, leading to sedation and weight gain, which are well-known side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trazodone: Primarily a serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor (SARI). It also blocks 5-HT2A receptors and has antihistaminic properties, causing sedation, but does not antagonize α2 receptors.

 

Option B. Amitriptyline: A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that inhibits norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake and has anticholinergic, antihistaminic, and α1-blocking effects, but not significant α2-adrenergic or 5-HT2/5-HT3 antagonism.

 

Option D. Escitalopram: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that increases serotonin levels by inhibiting reuptake. It does not block α2 or 5-HT2/5-HT3 receptors, and is not typically associated with sedation and weight gain to the extent seen with mirtazapine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mirtazapine is a noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA) that enhances mood by α2-adrenergic antagonism and 5-HT2/5-HT3 blockade, while its H1 antagonism leads to common side effects like sedation and weight gain. 
  • It is particularly useful in patients with depression and insomnia or weight loss.

questions.text: A young female presented with left sided severe throbbing headache associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia and phonophobia. Which of the following is a new drug that can provide immediate relief to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lasmiditan

 

  • The symptoms described, including severe throbbing headache, nausea, vomiting, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), are characteristic of a migraine headache. 
  • Lasmiditan is a new drug that belongs to a class called 5HT1F agonist. 
  • It is specifically approved for the acute treatment of migraine attacks in adults.
  • It provides immediate relief by inhibiting the release of CGRP from the neurons. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: A nonselective β-blocker used for migraine prophylaxis (DOC), not for aborting an active attack.

 

Option C. Topiramate: An antiepileptic agent effective in preventing migraine episodes by modulating ion channels and neurotransmission; it is not used for acute relief.

 

Option D. Erenumab: A monoclonal antibody targeting the CGRP receptor for preventive therapy; it does not treat acute migraine attacks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For acute migraine relief, use agents like lasmiditan; reserve propranolol, topiramate, and erenumab for prophylaxis, not abortive therapy.
  • Propranolol is DOC for prophylaxis of migraine.

choices.text: Increased conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use is brought to the emergency room by his family due to agitation, confusion, and aggressive behavior. His family members report that he has not eaten much in the past few days. On examination, he is disoriented, and his blood glucose level is measured at 41 mg/dL. Which of the following biochemical processes is most likely responsible for his hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased lactate/pyruvate ratio

 

  • Chronic alcohol consumption results in an increase in the NADH/NAD+ ratio due to alcohol metabolism. 
  • This shift favors the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, leading to an increased lactate/pyruvate ratio. 
  • As a result, gluconeogenesis is impaired because pyruvate, a key gluconeogenic substrate, is diverted to lactate instead of entering the gluconeogenic pathway. 
  • This disruption in gluconeogenesis leads to hypoglycemia, particularly in patients who have poor nutritional intake (such as alcoholics) and are dependent on gluconeogenesis for maintaining blood glucose levels during fasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate: In alcohol metabolism, the increased NADH/NAD+ ratio inhibits the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate. Instead, pyruvate is converted to lactate, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Increased gluconeogenesis: Alcohol impairs gluconeogenesis, not increases it. The increased NADH/NAD+ ratio shifts metabolism away from producing glucose from pyruvate, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio: Alcohol metabolism leads to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio, not decreased. The elevated NADH levels are what interfere with gluconeogenesis and promote the formation of lactate from pyruvate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio, leading to an increased lactate/pyruvate ratio, which impairs gluconeogenesis and can result in hypoglycemia, especially in patients with poor nutritional intake or fasting.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with diabetes and coronary artery disease presents with a 4-week history of progressive dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, and occasional dizziness. Recent cardiology evaluation ruled out cardiac ischemia, but labs show new anemia (hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL, MCV 75 fL, RDW 19%) and positive occult blood in stool. Colonoscopy and EGD are unrevealing, and she denies melena or hematochezia. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Video capsule endoscopy

 

  • Iron deficiency anemia (low hemoglobin, low MCV, high RDW) with positive occult blood suggests gastrointestinal bleeding, likely from the small bowel since colonoscopy and EGD are negative.
  • Video capsule endoscopy is the best test to identify small bowel sources like angiodysplasia or tumors.
  • This non-invasive approach is critical for pinpointing the bleeding site in occult GI bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance: Is inappropriate with anemia and occult bleeding.

 

Option B. CT arteriography: Is for large vascular bleeds, not occult small bowel sources.

 

Option C. Tagged white blood cell (WBC) scan: Is for inflammatory conditions, not bleeding sources.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Iron deficiency anemia with occult GI bleeding requires small bowel evaluation via video capsule endoscopy when standard endoscopies are negative.
  • Identifying the bleeding source prevents ongoing anemia and complications.

choices.text: Human plague risk is highest, given abundant fleas and burrows
The low cheopsis index suggests Xenopsylla cheopis is a minor vector here
A burrow index of 4 indicates fewer than four fleas per rodent burrow
Total flea index >10 always correlates with pneumonic rather than bubonic plague

questions.text:
In evaluating plague transmission risk in a village, field entomologists report:

  • Total flea index = 15
  • Burrow index = 4
  • Cheopsis index = 0.2

Which statement is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The low cheopsis index suggests Xenopsylla cheopis is a minor vector here

 

  • Cheopsis index (average number of X. cheopis fleas per rat) of 0.2 means there are only 0.2 of the primary rat flea vector per rat on average—far below the threshold (usually ≥1) that indicates X. 
  • Cheopis is driving transmission.
  • Total flea index of 15 shows many fleas overall, but if they are non–X. cheopis species, plague risk may remain lower than expected.
  • Burrow index of 4 means an average of 4 fleas (all species) per rodent burrow, not fewer than four.
  • A high total flea index does not dictate the form of plague (bubonic vs. pneumonic), which depends on disease progression and human‐to‐human spread, not vector density alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human plague risk is highest, given abundant fleas and burrows: Abundant fleas and burrows can increase risk, but if most fleas are non–X. cheopis, the principal vector’s low density limits efficient transmission.

 

Option C. A burrow index of 4 indicates fewer than four fleas per rodent burrow: The burrow index counts all flea species per burrow; 4 means four fleas per burrow on average, not “fewer than four.”

 

Option D. Total flea index >10 always correlates with pneumonic rather than bubonic plague: The type of plague (bubonic vs. pneumonic) depends on disease manifestation. High flea density fosters bubonic cases; pneumonic plague requires human respiratory spread, unrelated to vector indices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flea Indices in Plague:
    • Total flea index: Is average no. of fleas of all species per rat
    • Cheopsis index: Is average no. of X. cheopsis per rat; Is an ‘indicator of potential explosiveness, if outbreak occurs
    • Specific percentage of fleas: Percentage of different fleas
    • Burrow index: Average no. of fleas per species per rodent burrow

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a history of glaucoma presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of blurred vision and eye irritation. The patient reports that she has been using an anti-glaucoma medication for the past six months, and her symptoms began to appear gradually over the past few weeks. Upon further evaluation, it is discovered that the patient has experienced darkening of the iris and eyelid skin as well as increased length, thickness, and pigmentation of the eyelashes. Which of the following anti-glaucoma drugs is likely to produce these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Latanoprost. 

 

  • The patient's symptoms are consistent with the known side effects of latanoprost, which is a prostaglandin analog used in the treatment of glaucoma. 
  • Latanoprost can cause: 
    • Pigmentation of Iris: It is also known as heterochromia iridis
    • Growth of Eyelashes: It is also called hypertrichosis
    • Macular Edema
    • Worsening of inflammation: So contraindicated in patients with uveitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: A nonselective β-blocker that reduces aqueous humor production. Side effects include ocular irritation and systemic β-blockade (bradycardia, bronchospasm), but no changes in iris or eyelash pigmentation.

 

Option C. Brimonidine: An α₂-adrenergic agonist that decreases aqueous humor production and increases uveoscleral outflow. Adverse effects include allergic conjunctivitis and dry mouth; it does not affect iris color or lash growth.

 

Option D. Dorzolamide: A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces aqueous secretion by the ciliary epithelium. Commonly causes local stinging or bitter taste, but no pigmentary or eyelash changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a glaucoma patient develops iris hyperpigmentation and eyelash hypertrichosis, suspect a prostaglandin analogue—most commonly latanoprost—and consider alternative therapies if these cosmetic changes are problematic.

questions.text: Researchers enroll participants in a nutrition cohort and collect baseline dietary data via standardized questionnaires. Years later, when a subset develops a chronic disease, investigators re-interview only the cases about their current diet at diagnosis, while using only the original baseline data for controls. This approach is most likely to introduce which of the following biases?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Differential misclassification

 

  • In this nested design, cases have their exposure (diet) assessed twice—at baseline and again at diagnosis—whereas controls are assessed only once at baseline. 
  • This creates differential misclassification, because the accuracy or consistency of exposure measurement differs between cases and controls. 
  • Cases’ second interviews may reflect recall influenced by disease status or changes over time, whereas controls’ exposure data remain “frozen” at baseline, distorting the comparison.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recall bias: Occurs when cases and controls differ in recollection of past exposures at the same time point, typically in retrospective studies. Here, the error arises from different measurement schedules, not purely memory recall.

 

Option B. Lead‐time bias: Pertains to earlier detection of disease (e.g., via screening) that artificially inflates apparent survival time without affecting the disease course. It does not apply to exposure measurement error.

 

Option D. Berkson’s bias: A selection bias from hospital‐based sampling when two conditions influence admission probability. It is unrelated to differing exposure measurement methods in a nested design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ensure that exposure measurements are comparable between cases and controls—using identical methods and timing—to avoid differential misclassification and preserve study validity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia and COPD presents with a 1-week history of painless jaundice. On examination he has axillary lymphadenopathy, but has no fever or weight loss. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis reveals a 3-cm pancreatic head mass with mediastinal/hilar lymphadenopathy. ERCP shows bile duct dilation without gallstones. S.IgG4 is elevated. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endoscopic ultrasound with biopsy
 

  • The CT scan shows a pancreatic head mass and lymphadenopathy, with elevated IgG4 suggesting IgG4-related sclerosing pancreatitis, mimicking pancreatic cancer.
  • Endoscopic ultrasound with biopsy is critical to confirm the diagnosis via histopathology, distinguishing it from malignancy.
  • The absence of weight loss and presence of IgG4 elevation support a benign etiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation: Is inappropriate with a pancreatic mass requiring diagnosis.

 

Option B. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography: MRCP provides imaging but not tissue diagnosis.

 

Option D. Referral for Whipple procedure: Whipple procedure is premature without confirming a malignant etiology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IgG4-related pancreatitis mimics pancreatic cancer and requires endoscopic ultrasound with biopsy for diagnosis.
  • Elevated IgG4 and lymphadenopathy are key diagnostic clues.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a gradually enlarging, painless thyroid swelling for the past 3 months. There are no compressive symptoms like dysphagia or dyspnea. Physical examination reveals a firm, non-tender 4 × 4 cm nodule in the right thyroid lobe. Histological examination of the thyroid mass shows the features depicted in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary carcinoma

 

  • The findings of nuclear grooves, intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions, and papillary fronds with fibrovascular cores on FNA are pathognomonic for papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). 
  • PTC is the most common thyroid cancer, particularly in young to middle-aged women, and is the only thyroid malignancy reliably diagnosed by FNA cytology due to its distinctive nuclear morphology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hurthle cell adenoma: A variant of follicular neoplasm showing oncocytic cells with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm. It lacks the papillary architecture, nuclear grooves, or INCI seen in PTC.

 

Option B. Poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma: Typically presents with high-grade features, such as mitotic figures, necrosis, and cellular pleomorphism. It lacks the classic nuclear features seen in PTC and is usually diagnosed by histopathology, not cytology alone.

 

Option D. Follicular carcinoma: Characterized by follicular architecture, but requires capsular and vascular invasion for diagnosis, which cannot be determined on FNA. The presence of papillary structures and nuclear features rules out follicular carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the only thyroid malignancy with diagnostic nuclear features identifiable on FNAC, including nuclear grooves and intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions.

questions.text: A template strand of DNA has the sequence 5′GATCTAC3′. What is the sequence of the RNA transcript produced from this template?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5′GUAGAUC3′

 

  • RNA polymerase reads the DNA template strand in the 3′→5′ direction and synthesizes the RNA transcript in the 5′→3′ direction, pairing A (in DNA) with U (in RNA) and T (in DNA) with A (in RNA), while C pairs with G.
    1. Write the template strand in the 3′→5′ orientation:
      Template given as 5′–G A T C T A C–3′ becomes 3′–C A T C T A G–5′.
    2. Determine the complementary RNA bases (A→U, T→A, C→G, G→C) in the 5′→3′ direction:
      • Template 3′–C → RNA 5′–G
      • Template 3′–A → RNA 5′–U
      • Template 3′–T → RNA 5′–A
      • Template 3′–C → RNA 5′–G
      • Template 3′–T → RNA 5′–A
      • Template 3′–A → RNA 5′–U
      • Template 3′–G → RNA 5′–C
  • This yields 5′–G U A G A U C–3′.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When transcribing DNA to RNA, read the template strand 3′→5′, synthesize RNA 5′→3′, replace T with U, and use complementary base pairing (A→U, T→A, C→G, G→C).

choices.text: She died before entering the water
The lung findings are due to putrefactive gas

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is found unconscious in a lake. At autopsy 3 days later, her trachea and bronchi contain mud and algae, and her stomach has similar debris. Her lungs are bulky, and the Griess (diatom) test is positive. Which conclusion is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) She inhaled water and drowned

 

  • When a person dies by drowning, active breathing efforts pull water—and any suspended particulate matter—into the airways and stomach. 
  • This produces:
    • Mud and algae in the trachea, bronchi, and gastrointestinal tract
    • Bulky, edematous lungs from water and air trapping
    • Positive diatom test, since diatoms are inhaled into the circulation and deposited in organs like bone marrow
  • These findings confirm antemortem aspiration of water, establishing that she was alive and breathing when she entered the lake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. She died before entering the water: If death occurred prior to immersion, there would be no mud/algae in the airways or stomach, lungs would be collapsed, and diatoms would be absent.

 

Option C. She was submerged after death: Postmortem submersion allows only passive water entry. Airways remain largely free of debris, lungs collapse or decompose, and diatom tests are negative.

 

Option D. The lung findings are due to putrefactive gas: Putrefaction can cause lung “bulking,” but it does not deposit mud/algae or yield a positive diatom test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Active inhalation of water during life produces airway debris, bulky lungs, and positive diatoms—the hallmarks that distinguish true drowning from postmortem immersion.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presented to the hospital with a history of recurrent pain in the right Hypochondrium for 1 week. She is a known case of hereditary spherocytosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gall stone disease 

 

In patients with hemolytic disorders, black pigment stones are seen in the gall bladder, which are likely to block cystic duct and cause biliary colic or cholecystitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic infarct: May occur in sickle cell disease and will present with LUQ pain.

 

Option B. Acute Pancreatitis: Patient with Acute Pancreatitis presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. Lab investigations reveal increase serum amylase and lipase levels. Its management is mainly supportive care with adequate analgesia, IV Fluid therapy and oxygen administration.

 

Option D. Amoebic liver abscess: Patients with amoebic liver abscess are mostly asymptomatic. There is usually a history of dysentery with mucus in stools. It is caused by E. histolytica and on aspiration, pus with Anchovy-sauce appearance is obtained.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haemolytic disorders with RUQ pain is likely to be due to gall stones and will be confirmed by USG abdomen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with newly diagnosed hypertension presents with persistent elevated BP (165/95 mmHg) despite maximum-dose triple therapy with amlodipine, Enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide. Labs show creatinine 0.8 mg/dL, potassium 3.6 mEq/L, and sodium 141 mEq/L. What is the next step to evaluate the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Morning plasma renin and aldosterone

 

  • Resistant hypertension in a young patient without Cushing’s or pheochromocytoma symptoms suggests primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • An elevated aldosterone/renin ratio indicates hyperaldosteronism, common in resistant hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone suppression test: DST is for Cushing’s syndrome, not suggested by the patient’s symptoms.

 

Option C. Renal ultrasound: Is for renovascular disease, less likely without suggestive findings.

 

Option D. 24h urinary fractionated metanephrines: Urinary metanephrines are for pheochromocytoma, not indicated here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary hyperaldosteronism is a common cause of resistant hypertension, screened with plasma renin and aldosterone.
  • Early diagnosis prevents cardiovascular complications.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding muscles with dual nerve supply is/are correct? 

 

  1. Subscapularis is innervated by the upper and lower subscapular nerves.
  2. Pectoralis major is innervated by both the medial and lateral pectoral nerves.
  3. Pronator teres is a hybrid muscle and is innervated by the median and ulnar nerves.
  4. Flexor digitorum profundus is partially innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve (median nerve branch) and partially by the ulnar nerve.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Subscapularis is innervated by the upper and lower subscapular nerves: Correct. Subscapularis is innervated by the upper and lower subscapular nerves, making it a muscle with dual nerve supply.

 

Statement 2. Pectoralis major is innervated by both the medial and lateral pectoral nerves: Correct. Pectoralis major receives its nerve supply from both the medial and lateral pectoral nerves, qualifying as a hybrid muscle.

 

Statement 4. Flexor digitorum profundus is partially innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve (median nerve branch) and partially by the ulnar nerve: Correct. Flexor digitorum profundus has a dual nerve supply:

 

  • Lateral half: Anterior interosseous nerve (branch of the median nerve).
  • Medial half: Ulnar nerve.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. Pronator teres is a hybrid muscle and is innervated by the median and ulnar nerves: Incorrect. Pronator teres is not a hybrid muscle; it is solely innervated by the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective:


Hybrid muscles of the upper limb receive dual nerve supply, but pronator teres is solely innervated by the median nerve and is not classified as a hybrid muscle.

questions.text:
A 10-month-old infant presents with an abdominal mass and features such as macroglossia and umbilical hernia. Genetic testing confirms Wilms' tumor. Which of the following statements are true regarding the underlying syndrome? 

 

  1. The syndrome is associated with hemihypertrophy.
  2. It involves an overgrowth disorder caused by IGF-2 dysregulation.
  3. The risk of Wilms’ tumor decreases after 8 years of age.
  4. The most likely diagnosis is Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Statement 1. The syndrome is associated with hemihypertrophy: True. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with hemihypertrophy.

 

Statement 2. It involves an overgrowth disorder caused by IGF-2 dysregulation. True. It is caused by IGF-2 dysregulation, leading to overgrowth.

 

Statement 3. The risk of Wilms’ tumor decreases after 8 years of age: True. The risk of Wilms’ tumor significantly decreases after 8 years.

 

Statement 4. The most likely diagnosis is Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome: True. The clinical presentation strongly suggests Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth disorder associated with hemihypertrophy and Wilms’ tumor.

questions.text: Which of these factors cause a decrease in MAC requirement of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • Considering the individual effects of hypothermia, old age, and preoperative medication, all these factors can contribute to a decreased MAC requirement.
  • Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) is the concentration of an inhaled anesthetic required to prevent movement in 50% of subjects in response to a painful stimulus. 
    • Hypothermia: Lower body temperature can reduce metabolic rate and anesthetic requirements, thereby lowering MAC.
    • Old Age: As patients age, the MAC requirement typically decreases. The anesthetic requirement is greatest in infants and young children and decreases with advancing age.
    • Preoperative Medication: Certain preoperative medications, especially those with sedative or analgesic properties like opioids and benzodiazepines, can lower the MAC of inhaled anesthetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factors causing decrease in MAC: 

 

  • Age (MAC is greatest at 6-12 months of age) 
  • Decreased temperature.
  • Hyponatremia 
  • Opioids 
  • Barbiturates 
  • Alpha 2-blockers (clonidine, dexmedetomidine) 
  • Calcium channel blockers 
  • Acute alcohol intoxication 
  • Pregnancy 
  • MAC is NOT affected by gender.

questions.text: Which of the following trophozoite characteristics is absent in Entamoeba histolytica but commonly observed in Entamoeba coli?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sluggish, non-purposeful motility

 

  • Sluggish, non-purposeful motility is a hallmark of E. coli trophozoites. They move slowly with blunt, wide pseudopods in an erratic fashion.
  • In contrast, E. histolytica exhibits very active, unidirectional motility with finger-like pseudopodia, moving rapidly toward food or host tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Finger-like pseudopods: Entamoeba histolytica extends slender, pointed pseudopods for rapid, directional movement. E. coli has blunt, broad pseudopods.

 

Option B. Ingested leukocytes and RBCs: E. histolytica trophozoites are invasive and often contain ingested RBCs and leukocytes in their cytoplasm. E. coli may ingest bacteria but never red cells.

 

Option D. Differentiated ectoplasm and endoplasm: E. histolytica shows a distinct clear outer ectoplasm and granular inner endoplasm. E. coli trophozoites have more homogeneous cytoplasm without sharp differentiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Differentiate E. histolytica from E. coli trophozoites by their motility patterns, ingestion of host cells, and cytoplasmic features:
    • E. histolytica: rapid, purposeful motility with finger-like pseudopods, ingestion of RBCs, clear ectoplasm vs. endoplasm.
    • E. coli: sluggish, aimless movement, lack of erythrophagy, and uniform cytoplasm.

choices.text: Capable of directly lysing macrophages harboring intracellular pathogens
Recognizes peptide antigens presented via classical MHC molecules
Plays a role in antimicrobial defense against Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Releases cytotoxic mediators such as perforin and granulysin to eliminate pathogens

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is incorrect regarding the immune functions of gamma-delta (γδ) T lymphocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recognizes peptide antigens presented via classical MHC molecules

 

  • γδ T-cells are a distinct subset of T lymphocytes that differ from conventional αβ T-cells in several key ways.
  • Unlike αβ T-cells, γδ T-cells:
    • Do not require antigen processing and classical MHC presentation.
    • Recognize non-peptide antigens, such as phosphoantigens and lipid antigens, in an MHC-independent manner.
    • Act more like innate immune cells, bridging innate and adaptive immunity.
    • Possess cytotoxic activity, utilizing molecules such as perforin and granulysin.
    • Can directly kill infected macrophages.
    • Contribute to host defense, particularly against mycobacterial infections, such as M. tuberculosis.
  • Thus, the statement that γδ T-cells "recognize peptide antigens presented via classical MHC molecules" is not accurate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Capable of directly lysing macrophages harboring intracellular pathogens: Correct. γδ T-cells contribute to immune surveillance by directly lysing infected macrophages through cytolytic mechanisms.

 

Option C. Plays a role in antimicrobial defense against Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Correct. γδ T-cells are known to play a role in protective immunity against mycobacteria, especially via recognition of lipid antigens and cytokine release.

 

Option D. Releases cytotoxic mediators such as perforin and granulysin to eliminate pathogens: Correct. γδ T-cells kill infected or stressed cells via release of granulysin and perforin, mechanisms shared with cytotoxic T lymphocytes and NK cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

γδ T-cells are unique lymphocytes that participate in early host defense and do not require classical MHC-dependent antigen presentation, instead responding to non-peptide antigens and contributing to innate immune responses, particularly against intracellular pathogens like mycobacteria.

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent presents with painful menstruation (dysmenorrhea). On physical examination, she has normal secondary sexual characteristics, and the vagina is patent, but a bulge is noted on the right side near the cervix. On per rectal examination, a bulge is felt about 4 cm from the anal verge, more towards the left side. Pelvic ultrasound reveals hematocolpos, and the left kidney is absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) OHVIRA syndrome

 

  • OHVIRA syndrome (Obstructed Hemivagina and Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis), also known as Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome, is a rare congenital Müllerian anomaly. 
  • It typically presents in adolescent girls after menarche with:
    • Cyclic pelvic pain/dysmenorrhea due to obstruction
    • Patent external genitalia with normal secondary sexual characteristics
    • A bulging obstructed hemivagina
    • Hematocolpos/hematometra due to trapped menstrual blood
    • Renal agenesis on the same side as the obstructed hemivagina
  • In this case:
    • Vaginal bulge near cervix suggests obstructed hemivagina
    • Hematocolpos on ultrasound confirms trapped menstrual blood
    • Left-sided renal agenesis supports diagnosis
      Thus, the findings are diagnostic of OHVIRA syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRKH syndrome: Incorrect. MRKH (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) presents with primary amenorrhea, absent vagina and uterus, and normal secondary sexual characteristics. This patient has a patent vagina and hematocolpos, ruling out MRKH.

 

Option C. Robert’s uterus: Incorrect. Robert’s uterus is a rare asymmetric septate uterus where one side is obstructed. It can cause similar symptoms but is not typically associated with ipsilateral renal agenesis. The presence of renal agenesis supports OHVIRA over Robert’s uterus.

 

Option D. Noncommunicating functional uterine horn: Incorrect. This can cause hematometra and cyclic pain, but it usually doesn't involve a bulge at the vaginal level or renal agenesis, and the anomaly lies within the uterus rather than hemivaginal obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • OHVIRA syndrome (Obstructed Hemivagina and Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis) should be suspected in adolescents presenting with dysmenorrhea, hematocolpos, and renal agenesis.
  •  Key features include a vaginal bulge, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and unilateral renal absence.

choices.text: A positive test increases the odds of disease 10-fold.
A negative test reduces the odds of disease to one-tenth.
LR⁻ = (1 − Sensitivity) / Specificity = 0.1 implies very poor rule-out capability.
Both LR⁺ ≥ 10 and LR⁻ ≤ 0.1 indicate the test is excellent for both ruling in and ruling out disease.

questions.text: In evaluating Test Y for Condition Z, you find a positive likelihood ratio (LR⁺) of 10 and a negative likelihood ratio (LR⁻) of 0.1. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LR⁻ = (1 − Sensitivity) / Specificity = 0.1 implies very poor rule-out capability.

 

  • An LR⁻ of 0.1 actually represents excellent rule-out capability—post-test odds fall to 10% of pre-test odds. 
  • A “poor” rule-out test would have an LR⁻ closer to 1 (e.g., 0.5–1.0).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A positive test increases the odds of disease 10-fold: True. By definition, LR⁺ tells you how much to multiply pre-test odds when the test is positive. An LR⁺ of 10 means a positive result raises the odds by tenfold.

 

Option B. A negative test reduces the odds of disease to one-tenth: True. LR⁻ indicates how much to multiply pre-test odds when the test is negative. An LR⁻ of 0.1 reduces the odds to one-tenth, dramatically lowering the likelihood of disease.

 

Option D. Both LR⁺ ≥ 10 and LR⁻ ≤ 0.1 indicate the test is excellent for both ruling in and ruling out disease: True. General benchmarks hold that LR⁺ ≥ 10 strongly “rules in” disease, and LR⁻ ≤ 0.1 strongly “rules out” disease, making this test robust for both confirming and excluding Condition Z.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A test with LR⁺ ≥ 10 and LR⁻ ≤ 0.1 is considered excellent for both confirming and excluding disease—an LR⁻ of 0.1 does not imply poor rule-out ability but rather a tenfold reduction in post-test odds.

choices.text: It is longest acting anti arrhythmic drug.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about amiodarone?
questions.solution:
Ans B) It has positive ionotropic action.

 

  • Side effects of amiodarone
    • Thyroid 
    • Peripheral neuropathy 
    • Myocardial depression 
    • Lung fibrosis
    • Liver damage 
    • Corneal deposits 
    • Photosensitivity – Blue man syndrome 
  • Amiodarone is a potent antiarrhythmic medication with multiple actions on cardiac ion channels.
  • However, it does not have a positive ionotropic action. 
  • In fact, amiodarone has predominantly negative inotropic effects, meaning it reduces the force of cardiac contractions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the longest-acting antiarrhythmic drug: Amiodarone has a half-life of around 3 weeks, meaning it remains in the body for an extended period. This allows for a once-daily dosing regimen in many cases.

 

Option C. It contains iodine: Amiodarone contains around 40 percent iodine, which contribute to its structure. This iodine content is responsible for some of the medication's potential adverse effects, such as thyroid abnormalities.

 

Option D. It can cause pulmonary fibrosis: Amiodarone has been associated with pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as lung inflammation and fibrosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is a long-acting, iodine-containing antiarrhythmic with negative inotropic properties and a risk of pulmonary fibrosis, distinguishing it from agents that enhance contractility.

choices.text: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a total thyroidectomy for papillary carcinoma. Postoperatively, she develops hoarseness and a weak, breathy voice. Laryngoscopy reveals immobility of the left vocal cord in a paramedian position. Which of the following nerves was most likely injured during surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent laryngeal nerve

 

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies motor innervation to all intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except cricothyroid). 
  • Injury leads to vocal cord paralysis in a paramedian position, resulting in hoarseness and weak phonation. 
  • This nerve is highly susceptible during thyroid surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve: Supplies only cricothyroid, injury causes pitch alteration, not hoarseness or cord immobility.

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Affects pharyngeal sensation and taste, not vocal cord movement.

 

Option D. Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve: Purely sensory to larynx above vocal cords; injury leads to aspiration, not hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The recurrent laryngeal nerve is the most commonly injured nerve during thyroid surgery and causes vocal cord paralysis with hoarseness.

choices.text: Order a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test (DST)
Order fasting insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) level
Order morning cortisol with adrenocorticotopic hormone (ACTH)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the endocrinology clinic with a 15kg weight gain over 6 months, easy bruising, mild leg swelling, and increased fatigue. Examination reveals BP 145/90 mmHg, facial plethora, and 1+ pitting edema. HbA1c is 7.4% (up from 5.3% last year). What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Order a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test (DST)
 

  • The patient’s symptoms (central obesity, moon facies, easy bruising, hyperglycemia) are highly suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome due to glucocorticoid excess.
  • The low-dose DST is the initial screening test to confirm cortisol excess by assessing suppression of cortisol secretion.
  • Failure to suppress cortisol indicates Cushing’s syndrome, prompting further tests to identify the cause (pituitary, adrenal, or ectopic).
  • The test is non-invasive and highly sensitive for detecting cortisol overproduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Order fasting insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) level: IGF-1 screens for acromegaly, which presents with enlarged extremities and facial changes, not matching this patient’s symptoms.

 

Option C. Order morning cortisol with adrenocorticotopic hormone (ACTH): These tests help determine the etiology of Cushing’s syndrome but are not the initial screening step; DST is preferred first.

 

Option D. Refer for pituitary MRI: Imaging is premature without confirming cortisol excess via DST, as it may not be the cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cushing’s syndrome should be suspected in patients with central obesity, moon facies, easy bruising, and hyperglycemia.
  • The low-dose dexamethasone suppression test is the first-line screening tool for cortisol excess.
  • Subsequent tests like ACTH levels and imaging are used to pinpoint the cause after confirmation.

choices.text: Continue antibiotics for 7 more days and observe
Myringotomy with or without grommet insertion

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever and severe right ear pain for 2 days. On examination, the child is irritable, and otoscopy reveals a bulging, opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex. There is no response to a 48-hour course of oral amoxicillin-clavulanate, and hearing loss is noted in the affected ear. The pediatrician suspects impending tympanic membrane rupture. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myringotomy with or without grommet insertion

 

  • This child has acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) with severe earache, bulging tympanic membrane, and incomplete resolution despite antibiotics, along with persistent conductive hearing loss—all of which are indications for myringotomy.
  • Myringotomy relieves pressure, prevents rupture, and facilitates pus drainage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue antibiotics for 7 more days and observe: Already tried without resolution; continued observation risks complications like perforation or facial nerve palsy.

 

Option B. Add intranasal decongestants and antihistamines: These may relieve Eustachian tube congestion but are not definitive management in this case with clear signs of bulging and non-resolution.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty: This is a reconstructive surgery for chronic perforation or ossicular discontinuity, not indicated in acute ASOM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myringotomy is indicated in ASOM when there is severe earache with a bulging tympanic membrane, failure to respond to antibiotics, or complications like facial palsy or meningitis. 
  • Early intervention prevents spontaneous rupture and long-term hearing loss.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with oliguria, hypertension, and microangiopathic hemolysis two days after an episode of bloody diarrhea. Laboratory studies reveal fragmented red cells and rising creatinine, and Shiga toxin is detected in her circulation. Which endothelial surface glycolipid is the primary receptor for this toxin, explaining the renal‐predominant damage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gb₃ 

 

  • Shiga toxin consists of a B-subunit pentamer and an A-subunit enzymatic moiety.
  • The B-subunit specifically binds to globotriaosylceramide (Gb₃) on the cell surface. Gb₃ is highly expressed on renal glomerular endothelial cells, which facilitates receptor-mediated endocytosis of the toxin. The toxin goes and attach on the 60s ribosomes leads to kidney damage.
  • Once inside the cell, the A-subunit de-purinates the 28S rRNA of the 60S ribosomal subunit, halting protein synthesis and causing cell death. 
  • The abundance of Gb₃ in kidney endothelium explains why Shiga toxin–mediated hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) predominantly injures the renal microvasculature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM₁ (monosialotetrahexosylganglioside): This glycolipid is the receptor for cholera toxin, not Shiga toxin. Binding to GM₁ does not facilitate Shiga toxin entry.

 

Option C. LacCer (lactosylceramide): While a glycosphingolipid, LacCer lacks the specific trisaccharide structure required for high-affinity Shiga toxin binding.

 

Option D. Cer (ceramide): Ceramide is the simple lipid backbone of complex glycosphingolipids; it does not itself serve as a toxin receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Shiga toxin–mediated HUS, the toxin’s renal tropism is due to high expression of globotriaosylceramide (Gb₃) on glomerular endothelium, making Gb₃ the critical docking receptor.

choices.text: Drug toxicity from pre-HSCT conditioning chemotherapy

questions.text: A 20-year-old man, 12 days post-hematopoietic stem cell transplantation for acute myelogenous leukemia, presents with a 3-day history of right upper quadrant pain, hepatomegaly, ascites, and a 8-kg weight gain. He reports lower extremity edema and fatigue, with no recent infections or trauma. USG of the abdomen demonstrates reversal of flow in the portal vein, with bilirubin at 6.5 mg/dL and normal transaminases. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sinusoidal obstruction syndrome

 

  • The ultrasonography showing reversal of portal vein flow, with hepatomegaly, ascites, and rapid weight gain, indicates sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (SOS), a common complication within 3 weeks post-HSCT due to endothelial damage from chemotherapy.
  • Elevated bilirubin and edema further support SOS, which can lead to liver failure if untreated.
  • The absence of infectious or chronic symptoms narrows the diagnosis to SOS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute cytomegalovirus infection: CMV infection causes fever, rash, and diarrhea, not portal vein reversal.

 

Option B. Acute graft-versus-host disease: GVHD affects skin, GI, and liver but lacks rapid ascites or portal vein changes.

 

Option C. Drug toxicity from pre-HSCT conditioning chemotherapy: Chemotherapy toxicity causes hepatocellular injury, not portal vein flow reversal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SOS post-HSCT presents with hepatomegaly, ascites, and reversed portal vein flow.
  • Early recognition is critical to manage this life-threatening condition.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with knee pain and limping. He has limited internal rotation of the hip, and X-rays reveal a "frog-leg" view of the hip. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perthes disease

 

  • Perthes disease, or Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, is a condition characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children, typically affecting those aged 4 to 10 years.
  • The exact cause of Perthes disease is unknown, but it is thought to result from a temporary loss of blood supply to the femoral head, leading to bone necrosis.
  • Children with Perthes disease often present with hip or knee pain, limping, and limited range of motion, particularly internal rotation and abduction. 
  • Symptoms can be insidious and may not always correlate with the severity of radiographic findings.
  • On X-ray, the "frog-leg" view can show various stages of the disease, including initial lateralization of the femoral head and eventual fragmentation and deformity. 
  • MRI can also be used to assess the extent of necrosis.
  • Diagnosis is made through clinical evaluation, imaging studies, and sometimes MRI. 
  • Given the child’s age, symptoms, and imaging findings, Perthes disease is a strong consideration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE): SCFE is a condition in which the femoral head slips posteriorly and inferiorly due to displacement at the growth plate (physis), typically occurring in adolescents. SCFE is associated with growth plate instability and can be related to obesity or hormonal factors. It is most commonly seen during periods of rapid growth. Symptoms include hip or knee pain, limping, and reduced range of motion, particularly internal rotation. The pain may be referred to the knee, leading to initial misdiagnosis. X-rays in SCFE often show a displaced femoral head relative to the neck, particularly on the frog-leg view. 

 

 

This condition is more common in older children and adolescents, which makes it less likely in a 10-year-old. Diagnosis is confirmed with clinical and imaging findings. While SCFE could present similarly, the patient's age and symptoms are more consistent with Perthes disease.

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone, typically caused by bacteria, which can occur in children following trauma or hematogenous spread. It can occur after an injury or surgery but can also arise without any clear precipitating event, particularly in immunocompromised children. Symptoms include localized bone pain, swelling, fever, and sometimes a limp. Pain may be severe and localized rather than diffuse. X-rays may show bone changes, but early osteomyelitis may not be visible until there is significant bone loss. MRI is often more sensitive for detecting early changes. Diagnosis typically involves clinical evaluation, blood tests, and imaging. Given the chronic presentation and specific findings, osteomyelitis is less likely in this scenario.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour that typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones, most commonly around the knee in adolescents. The exact cause is unknown, but factors may include genetic predispositions or pre-existing conditions. Patients usually present with localized pain, swelling, and sometimes a palpable mass. The pain may worsen over time and is often associated with activity. X-rays may show a destructive lesion with a sunburst pattern, and an MRI or CT scan would be needed for further evaluation. 

 

 

However, the acute nature of the symptoms in this case points more towards a developmental condition. Diagnosis involves imaging and often a biopsy for histological confirmation. Given the patient’s age and symptoms, osteosarcoma is less likely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Perthes Disease fits the age of the patient, the symptom profile, and the characteristic findings on imaging, making it the most appropriate diagnosis in this scenario.

questions.text: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maydl’s hernia

 

The diagram shows Maydl's hernia/Hernia-en-W/Retrograde hernia, where 2 loops of the bowel remain in the sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Richter's hernia: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the presence of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

 

Option B. Pantaloon hernia: In pantaloon hernia, both direct and indirect hernia occur on the same side.

 

Option C. Littre's hernia: In Littre's hernia, Meckel's diverticulum is the content.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Maydl’s hernia, a condition where two bowel loops are within a hernial sac with the intervening segment lying within the peritoneal cavity and at risk for strangulation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with newly diagnosed glioblastoma multiforme begins chemoradiation. His oncologist prescribes an oral alkylating agent that crosses the blood–brain barrier. Which drug is this?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Temozolomide

 

  • Temozolomide is an oral prodrug that spontaneously converts at physiologic pH to the active methylating species MTIC. 
  • Its small, lipophilic nature allows excellent penetration of the blood–brain barrier, achieving therapeutic concentrations in the CNS. 
  • This property, along with its favorable oral dosing and toxicity profile, makes temozolomide the standard alkylating agent used concurrently with radiotherapy for glioblastoma multiforme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carmustine: Although it also penetrates the CNS and alkylates DNA, carmustine is given intravenously (or via wafer implants) and carries a higher risk of pulmonary fibrosis and delayed myelosuppression.

 

Option B. Lomustine: This oral nitrosourea does cross the blood–brain barrier but causes prolonged, delayed bone marrow suppression and is typically reserved for recurrent disease rather than frontline chemoradiation.

 

Option D. Procarbazine: An oral methylhydrazine derivative used in Hodgkin lymphoma and brain tumor regimens (e.g., PCV), but its CNS penetration is inferior to temozolomide and it has more complex drug interactions and dietary restrictions (MAO inhibition).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temozolomide is the preferred oral alkylating agent for glioblastoma because it is a lipophilic prodrug that readily crosses the blood–brain barrier and converts to a DNA‐methylating agent within the CNS.

choices.text: Laser photocoagulation of the neovascularization on Optic Disc
Laser photocoagulation of the entire Retina
Laser photocoagulation of the Retina outside the Central Posterior Pole

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with proliferative diabetic retinopathy and poor clinic follow-up is found to have early neovascularization on his optic disc (NVD). He admits missing his last two appointments. What is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laser photocoagulation of the Retina outside the Central Posterior Pole 

 

  • Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the standard of care for proliferative diabetic retinopathy. 
  • It:
    • Targets the ischemic peripheral retina, which reduces VEGF production.
    • Leads to regression of neovascularization, including NVD.
    • Is preferred especially in patients with poor follow-up, because it provides a durable response.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Laser photocoagulation of the neovascularization on Optic Disc: Incorrect. This is not done because, Laser directly to the optic disc can cause damage to nerve fibers. It’s ineffective at treating the underlying ischemic drive for neovascularization. Neovascularization is a response to ischemia, and treating the ischemic peripheral retina is the key.

 

Option B. Laser photocoagulation of the entire Retina: Incorrect. This is not precise or safe. The entire retina should not be treated, this would include healthy macula and posterior pole, leading to permanent central vision loss. Treatment needs to spare the central macula.

 

Option D. Intravitreal Anti-VEGF Injection only: Incorrect, but not best as monotherapy. Anti-VEGF is useful especially in NVE/NVD and macular edema. However, in patients with poor follow-up, PRP is more reliable because:

 

  • Anti-VEGF effects are temporary.
  • Patients may not return for re-injections.
  • Monotherapy with anti-VEGF is not first-line in this setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP)  treats the underlying ischemia that drives neovascularization.
  • It is particularly important in non-compliant patients due to its longer-lasting effect compared to anti-VEGF injections.

choices.text: It is a maculopapular lesion caused by eosinophils.
It is due to neutrophil accumulation and resolves in 2-3 days.
It is a capillary hemangioma and typically fades within the first year.
It is a melanocyte-derived lesion that persists into adulthood.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about this lesion is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a capillary hemangioma and typically fades within the first year.

 

Salmon patches, also known as stork bites or nevus simplex, are capillary hemangiomas that fade spontaneously within the first year of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a maculopapular lesion caused by eosinophils: Describes erythema toxicum.

 

Option B. It is due to neutrophil accumulation and resolves in 2-3 days: Seen in neonatal pustular melanosis.

 

Option D. It is a melanocyte-derived lesion that persists into adulthood: Describes Mongolian spots, not salmon patches.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Salmon patches are benign capillary hemangiomas that are self-limiting and usually resolve within the first year.

choices.text: 85% of participants in the trials had a positive treatment response.
85% of the observed variability in effect sizes is due to heterogeneity rather than chance.
There is an 85% probability that the meta-analytic estimate is invalid.
85% of the included studies are of low methodological quality.

questions.text: In a meta-analysis of statin trials, the I² statistic is reported as 85%. Which interpretation is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 85% of the observed variability in effect sizes is due to heterogeneity rather than chance.

 

  • The I² statistic quantifies the proportion of total variation across studies in a meta-analysis that is due to real differences (heterogeneity) rather than sampling error (chance). 
  • An I² of 85% indicates substantial heterogeneity, meaning that most of the variability among study results reflects genuine differences in effect sizes (e.g., populations, interventions, study designs) instead of random variation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 85% of participants in the trials had a positive treatment response: I² is about between-study variability, not the proportion of individual participants responding to treatment.

 

Option C. There is an 85% probability that the meta-analytic estimate is invalid: I² does not measure validity or the likelihood of being wrong. It assesses consistency among included studies.

 

Option D. 85% of the included studies are of low methodological quality: I² does not reflect study quality. Poor methodology can contribute to heterogeneity, but I² itself only quantifies variance, not quality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high I² (e.g., ≥75%) signals substantial heterogeneity among studies’ results in a meta-analysis, prompting further investigation of sources of variability (e.g., subgroup analyses, sensitivity analyses) before drawing definitive conclusions.
