questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a history of chronic hepatitis B presents with progressive abdominal distension, weight loss, and right upper quadrant discomfort. Laboratory studies reveal elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels. A liver biopsy is performed, and IHC staining is positive for Hep Par 1. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

  • Hep Par 1 (Hepatocyte Paraffin 1) is a sensitive and specific immunohistochemical marker used to identify cells of hepatocellular origin.
  •  It stains cytoplasmic enzymes in hepatocytes, and is especially useful in confirming hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), particularly when histologic features overlap with metastatic carcinomas or cholangiocarcinomas.
  • This patient with a history of hepatitis B (a known risk factor for HCC), elevated AFP, and positive Hep Par 1 staining is most consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangiocarcinoma: Arises from bile ducts and typically does not express Hep Par 1; may stain for CK7/CK19 instead.

 

Option B. Metastatic colorectal carcinoma: Usually expresses CK20 and CDX2, not Hep Par 1.

 

Option D. Pancreatic adenocarcinoma: Typically expresses CK7 and CA19-9, not Hep Par 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hep Par 1 is a specific immunohistochemical marker for hepatocellular differentiation and is most commonly used to confirm hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with high fever, cough, and confusion after returning from a hotel stay. Sputum Gram stain shows abundant neutrophils but no organisms. Silver stain reveals faint, slender bacilli. Which culture medium is required to isolate the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar

 

  • Legionella pneumophila is a fastidious, aerobic, Gram-negative bacillus that often eludes routine Gram and MacConkey cultures.
  • It requires a specialized medium—BCYE agar—which provides L-cysteine and iron for growth.
  • Culture on BCYE at 35 °C yields gray–white, glistening colonies within 3–5 days, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chocolate agar: Supports growth of many respiratory pathogens (e.g., Haemophilus, Neisseria), but lacks the cysteine/iron enrichment needed by Legionella.

 

Option C. Thayer–Martin agar: A selective medium for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis, containing antibiotics that inhibit Legionella growth.

 

Option D. MacConkey agar: Selective for lactose-fermenting Enterobacteriaceae; does not support Legionella due to its nutritional requirements and inhibitory bile salts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Legionella pneumophila is a fastidious, aerobic Gram-negative bacillus requiring L-cysteine and iron supplementation for growth; the only routine medium that provides these factors is Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar.

choices.text: Color change from a pH indicator
Hemolysis of embedded red blood cells

questions.text: A clinical laboratory inoculates egg yolk agar to identify Clostridium perfringens by its lecithinase activity. Which characteristic of this medium allows direct visualization of lecithinase action?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Precipitation zone forming around colonies

 

  • Egg yolk agar contains lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) from the yolk. C. perfringens produces lecithinase, an enzyme that hydrolyzes lecithin into phosphorylcholine and insoluble diglycerides. 
  • These diglycerides precipitate in the agar immediately surrounding colonies, creating an opaque, white zone—a direct visual marker of lecithinase activity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Color change from a pH indicator: Egg yolk agar does not include a pH-sensitive dye; opacity, not hue shift, indicates enzyme activity.

 

Option C. Hemolysis of embedded red blood cells: Hemolysis occurs on blood agar. Egg yolk agar lacks intact erythrocytes, so no hemolytic clearing is observed.

 

Option D. Fluorescence under ultraviolet light: No fluorogenic substrates are present; lecithinase activity is detected by precipitation, not fluorescence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lecithinase-positive organisms like C. perfringens produce an opaque precipitation halo on egg yolk agar due to hydrolysis of lecithin into insoluble diglycerides.

choices.text: Resting in dark bottom corners of water containers
Inclined adult resting posture at the water’s edge
Eggs laid singly with lateral floats

questions.text: A fogging team targets a mosquito species that breeds exclusively in clean, sunlit water collections and whose adults fly up to 3–5 km seeking human blood. Which behavior mismatches this vector’s biology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Resting in dark bottom corners of water containers

 

  • The described species is Anopheles, the primary malaria vector in India.
  • Key Anopheles features include:
    • Breeding habitat: Clean, sunlit, fresh water (e.g., ponds, rice fields)
    • Flight range: Relatively long (3–5 km), enabling wide dispersal
    • Eggs: Laid singly on the water surface; boat-shaped with lateral floats
    • Larvae: Lack a siphon tube and rest parallel to the water surface
    • Adults: Rest with bodies inclined at an angle (head down) against surfaces near water. It sits at 45 degrees on the surface of skin while taking a bite. 
    • Wings: Black spots 
  • Larvae or adults of container-breeding, short-flight mosquitoes (Aedes). 
  • Aedes adults rest in dark container corners, not Anopheles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inclined adult resting posture at the water’s edge: Anopheles adults rest at a characteristic 45° angle to the surface, often on vegetation or walls near breeding sites.

 

Option C. Eggs laid singly with lateral floats: Anopheles females deposit single boat-shaped eggs, each stabilized by paired floats—distinct from raft-laying Culex or strip-laying Aedes.

 

Option D. Larvae lacking a siphon tube: Anopheles larvae breathe through spiracles on their eighth abdominal segment (no siphon) and lie parallel to the surface, unlike other genera with siphoned larvae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anopheles mosquitoes breed in clean, sunlit waters, lay single boat-shaped eggs, have siphon-less larvae resting parallel to the surface, and adults rest inclined near water—they do not congregate in dark container corners (an Aedes trait).

questions.text:
Regarding pleomorphic adenoma, which of the following statement is/ are incorrect? 

 

  1. These tumors are composed exclusively of ductal epithelial cells forming gland-like structures.
  2. Myoepithelial cells contribute to the diverse stromal components such as myxoid and chondroid areas.
  3. The tumor demonstrates dual immunoreactivity for both epithelial and myoepithelial markers like cytokeratin and S-100.
  4. Perineural invasion is a characteristic feature seen in pleomorphic adenoma.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 4 are incorrect

 

Statement 1. These tumors are composed exclusively of ductal epithelial cells forming gland-like structures: Incorrect. Pleomorphic adenomas are not composed exclusively of ductal epithelial cells. They are defined by the presence of both ductal (epithelial) and myoepithelial cells, contributing to their pleomorphic histology.

 

Statement 4. Perineural invasion is a characteristic feature seen in pleomorphic adenoma: Incorrect. Perineural invasion is not characteristic of pleomorphic adenoma. It is more typically seen in malignant salivary gland tumors like adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2. Myoepithelial cells contribute to the diverse stromal components such as myxoid and chondroid areas: Correct. Myoepithelial cells are responsible for producing the diverse stromal features such as myxoid, hyaline, chondroid, and sometimes osseous tissue.

 

Statement 3. The tumor demonstrates dual immunoreactivity for both epithelial and myoepithelial markers like cytokeratin and S-100: Correct. Immunohistochemical profile includes dual staining: cytokeratin, EMA, and CEA for epithelial components, and S-100, actin, and vimentin for myoepithelial cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pleomorphic adenomas are benign salivary gland tumors composed of both epithelial and myoepithelial elements, showing epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation.
  • Perineural invasion is not typical and suggests a malignant transformation.

questions.text: Match the correct pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Diagrammatic presentation: 

 

 

1- b. Pressure Epiphysis:

 

  • Pressure epiphyses are regions of long bones where growth occurs due to the pressure applied to the epiphyseal plate.
  • Growth is a result of compression forces.
  • Example: The distal end of the femur is a pressure epiphysis.
  • During childhood and adolescence, the weight-bearing activities apply pressure on this epiphysis, allowing for bone elongation.

 

2-a. Traction Epiphysis:

 

  • Traction epiphyses are areas in long bones where growth happens in response to pulling or traction forces on the epiphyseal plate. 
  • These forces are typically exerted by tendons or muscles attached to the bone.
  • Example: The proximal end of the tibia is a traction epiphysis. 
  • The action of the patellar tendon, connected to the tibial tuberosity, leads to traction forces that promote bone growth.

 

3-d. Atavistic Epiphysis:

 

  • Atavistic epiphyses are secondary centers of ossification that are rare and may resemble ancestral bone structures. 
  • They are considered vestigial.
  • Example: The presence of an additional epiphysis in the elbow joint that is not typically seen in modern humans would be considered an atavistic epiphysis.

 

4-c. Aberrant Epiphysis:

 

  • Aberrant epiphyses are anomalous growth centers or irregularities in bone development that deviate from the usual patterns.
  • Example: An individual with an extra epiphyseal center in the metacarpal bone, not commonly observed in the general population, would have an aberrant epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to your clinic with the following deformity of the right arm. Which is the most likely fracture leading to such a defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar fracture

 

  • A supracondylar fracture is a common type of elbow fracture in children, typically occurring in children aged 5 to 10 years old. 
  • It usually results from a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) or a direct trauma to the elbow. 
  • The fracture occurs just above the condyles of the humerus, involving the distal part of the bone.
  •  It can lead to significant deformity and complications, such as nerve injury (like median nerve damage) or vascular compromise (like brachial artery injury).
  • Supracondylar fractures often present with a typical “gunstock deformity” in the elbow, which results in cubitus varus (a varus angulation of the elbow).
  • This deformity involves the angulation of the elbow, which can resemble the deformity shown in the question, especially if it is a displaced or malaligned fracture. This makes it the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colle’s Fracture:

 

  • A Colle’s fracture is a type of distal radius fracture that occurs when a person falls onto an outstretched hand, causing the distal radius to break and displace dorsally (toward the back of the hand). 
  • This fracture is common in older adults, especially those with osteoporosis, but can also occur in children. It is characterized by dorsal displacement of the distal fragment.
  • A Colle's fracture involves the radius and affects the wrist, not the elbow. Therefore, this fracture would not lead to a deformity at the elbow as shown in the question. This fracture does not match the typical presentation of supracondylar fractures.

 

Option B. Lateral Epicondyle Fracture:

 

  • A lateral epicondyle fracture involves the lateral epicondyle of the humerus, which is located on the outer part of the elbow. 
  • This injury is less common in children compared to other elbow fractures and typically occurs due to direct trauma or a fall. 
  • Lateral epicondyle fractures can lead to elbow instability or disruption of the extensor tendon attachments, but they do not typically cause the same deformity seen in supracondylar fractures.
  • While a lateral epicondyle fracture may cause some elbow pain and dysfunction, it is less likely to cause a noticeable deformity such as a gunstock deformity or angulation. 
  • This type of fracture would be less likely to present as the deformity described in the question.

 

Option C. Medial Epicondyle Fracture:

 

  • A medial epicondyle fracture involves the medial epicondyle of the humerus, which is located on the inner part of the elbow. 
  • This type of fracture can occur due to direct trauma or excessive stress, such as in throwing injuries (e.g., in young athletes who participate in baseball or other throwing sports). 
  • Medial epicondyle fractures are also associated with the avulsion of the flexor tendons.
  • Although a medial epicondyle fracture can cause elbow pain and dysfunction, it does not typically lead to the characteristic deformities seen with supracondylar fractures. 
  • The deformity shown in the question is more consistent with a supracondylar fracture rather than a medial epicondyle fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Supracondylar fractures are the most common elbow fractures in children and can result in the characteristic cubitus varus deformity (also called the gunstock deformity). 
  • This deformity is caused by improper alignment during healing and is the most likely outcome based on the deformity shown in the question.

questions.text: A 26-year-old multiparous woman complains of mild dull aching abdominal pain. Her periods are regular and her LMP was 3 weeks back. On pelvic examination, a mass is felt through the posterior fornix. Ultrasound reveals a simple ovarian cyst measuring 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follow-up ultrasound after 6 weeks

 

  • In premenopausal women, simple ovarian cysts up to 5 cm in size are commonly functional cysts and often resolve spontaneously without intervention.
  • A clear ovarian cyst seen on ultrasound, especially if unilocular, thin-walled, and less than or equal to 5 cm, is generally benign.
  • The standard recommendation is to perform repeat ultrasound in 6 weeks to assess for spontaneous resolution.
  • Surgical intervention or further diagnostic tests are unnecessary unless the cyst persists, grows in size, becomes symptomatic, or exhibits complex features.
  • This conservative approach minimizes unnecessary surgical risk while ensuring appropriate surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pelvic computed tomography (CT scan): Incorrect. CT pelvis is not the first-line modality for ovarian cyst evaluation. Ultrasound is more sensitive for pelvic pathology. CT is generally reserved for staging known malignancies or complex masses with atypical features.

 

Option C. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Incorrect. Laparoscopy is indicated if the cyst persists, grows, or exhibits suspicious features such as septations, solid components, or papillary projections. It is not indicated for an initial finding of a simple cyst measuring 5 cm in a premenopausal woman.

 

Option D. Serum CA-125 level estimation: Incorrect. CA-125 is not routinely indicated for simple ovarian cysts in premenopausal women, as it lacks specificity and can be elevated in benign conditions like endometriosis or pelvic inflammatory disease. CA-125 is more useful in postmenopausal women or if the mass appears suspicious on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In premenopausal women, a simple ovarian cyst measuring up to 5 cm on ultrasound is managed conservatively with repeat imaging after 6 weeks to monitor for spontaneous resolution, avoiding unnecessary interventions.

questions.text: On slit-lamp examination of a patient with early keratoconus, you note a pigmented iron ring encircling the base of the cone. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fleischer’s ring

 

  • Fleischer’s ring is an epithelial iron deposition that appears as a yellow-brown or greenish pigmented ring at the base of the cone in keratoconus.
  • It forms because tears pool in the trough created by the conical protrusion, allowing iron to accumulate in the epithelial cells. 
  • This ring often correlates with the area of maximal corneal thinning and steepening, and can be highlighted with cobalt blue illumination to improve visibility.

 

 

 

  • Other Signs in Keratoconus include:
    • Vogt’s striae: These are fine vertical stress lines in the stromal collagen of the cone that temporarily disappear when gentle pressure is applied to the cornea; they are not pigmented.
    • Rizzuti’s sign: Observed when a penlight shone from the temporal side produces a bright, triangular reflection on the nasal cornea; this reflects the cone shape but does not involve iron deposition.
    • Munson’s sign: A V-shaped indentation of the lower eyelid seen on downgaze, caused by the protruding conical cornea; this is a lid configuration sign rather than an epithelial finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weiss ring: A vitreous opacity seen in posterior vitreous detachment at the optic disc  (not corneal).

 

 

Option C. Vossius ring: Represents pigment on the anterior lens capsule after blunt trauma to the eye (not related to keratoconus). It is iron deposition on anterior lens capsule

 

 

Option D. Soemmering’s ring:  A ring of retained lens epithelial cells seen after cataract extraction (not corneal). It is posterior capsular ossification.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In keratoconus, Fleischer’s ring is the pigmented iron ring at the base of the cone, distinguishing it from stress lines (Vogt’s striae), light reflex signs (Rizzuti), and lid changes (Munson).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman had a non-medicated (inert) copper IUD placed 6 weeks ago. She now reports significantly heavier menses lasting 7 days but is hemodynamically stable and mildly anemic. Which statements are true regarding management? 

 

  1. Increased bleeding is the most common side effect and often resolves by 1–2 months.
  2. You should remove the IUD immediately to stop the bleeding.
  3. First‐line management is reassurance and a course of IFA for 1–2 months.
  4. If bleeding remains heavy or persists beyond 2 months, removal is indicated.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Increased bleeding is the MC side effect and often resolves by 1–2 months: True. Copper IUDs frequently cause heavier menstrual bleeding in the first 1–2 months. This side effect is well recognized and typically improves as the endometrium adapts.

 

Statement 3. First‐line management is reassurance and a course of IFA for 1–2 months: True. Initial management consists of reassuring the patient that this is common, prescribing IFA for 1–2 months to address mild anemia, and monitoring her response.

 

She should take Tab. FeSO4 200 mg TDS for 8 weeks 

 

Statement 4. If bleeding remains heavy or persists beyond 2 months, removal is indicated: True. If bleeding is heavy (e.g., soaking through pads every 1–2 hours) or persists beyond 2 months, then removal of the IUD is appropriate to alleviate symptoms.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. You should remove the IUD immediately to stop the bleeding: False. Immediate removal is not recommended for mild to moderate increased bleeding. The protocol is to observe and manage medically unless bleeding becomes severe or the patient is unstable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Don’t remove a copper IUD for mild-to-moderate early bleeding. Reassure, supplement with iron, and reserve removal for persistent or severe bleeding lasting longer than two months.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with a high-pitched cry, severe developmental delay, and microcephaly. Genetic testing confirms a chromosomal deletion on 5p. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cri du Chat Syndrome

 

Cri du Chat Syndrome is caused by a 5p deletion and is characterized by a high-pitched cry, severe developmental delay, and microcephaly.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smith-Lemli-Opitz Syndrome: Not associated with 5p deletion or a high-pitched cry.

 

Option C. Rubinstein-Taybi Syndrome: Features broad thumbs and a beaked nose, not a high-pitched cry.

 

Option D. Edward Syndrome: Characterized by overlapping fingers and micrognathia, not a high-pitched cry.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A high-pitched cry in an infant with developmental delay should prompt consideration of Cri du Chat Syndrome and chromosomal deletion testing.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with HCV-related cirrhosis and a MELD score of 20 presents to the ED with a 2-day history of abdominal pain, fever to 38.5°C, and nausea. He has a history of ascites managed with diuretics and denies recent alcohol use. Paracentesis reveals 510 nucleated cells (75% neutrophils), with no evidence of bleeding. His BP is 110/70 mmHg, and he appears uncomfortable. Which is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV ceftriaxone

 

  • Paracentesis findings (510 cells, 75% neutrophils) indicate spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) in this cirrhotic patient, confirmed by >250 neutrophils.
  • IV ceftriaxone is the first-line empiric therapy for SBP, covering common gram-negative pathogens like E. coli and Klebsiella.
  • The patient’s fever and discomfort necessitate prompt antibiotic initiation to prevent sepsis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Ciprofloxacin: Is used for SBP prophylaxis, not empiric treatment.

 

Option C. IV Vancomycin and meropenem: Are overly broad for uncomplicated SBP.

 

Option D. PO trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Oral TMP-SMX lacks adequate coverage for SBP pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SBP in cirrhosis is diagnosed by paracentesis showing >250 neutrophils and treated with IV ceftriaxone.
  • Prompt antibiotics are critical to prevent complications like sepsis.

choices.text: Continuous monitoring of respiratory rate and effort

questions.text: A neonate with TTN (transient tachypnoea of newborn) is being monitored in the NICU. Which of the following management strategies is not indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous antibiotics

 

Antibiotics are not routinely required for TTN unless there is suspicion of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supplemental oxygen to maintain SpO₂ >92%: Indicated for hypoxia.

 

Option C. Continuous monitoring of respiratory rate and effort: Crucial in TTN management.

 

Option D. Maintenance of normothermia: Important to minimize metabolic demands.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

TTN is managed with supportive care, and antibiotics are reserved for cases with clinical or laboratory evidence of infection.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with a history of IV drug use presents to the ER with a 4-day history of fever, chills, back pain, and inability to lift her right arm above shoulder level. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV Vancomycin
 

  • This patient presents with features concerning for infective endocarditis with possible spinal epidural abscess or vertebral osteomyelitis, both of which are common in IV drug users.
  • Fever + back pain + limb weakness/restriction → suggests spinal infection with possible neurologic compromise.
  • Given her IV drug use and high suspicion for MRSA, empiric antibiotic therapy should be started immediately.
  • IV Vancomycin provides coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), the most likely pathogen in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI brain: Not indicated initially; her presentation suggests spinal, not intracranial, pathology.

 

Option C. Urgent Trans-esophageal echo: Urgent Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is important in diagnosing endocarditis, but antibiotics must be started immediately in febrile IV drug users with systemic signs.

 

Option D. IV Dexamethasone: Steroids are used for spinal cord compression due to malignancy, not first-line for spinal infections. Antibiotics come first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IV drug users with fever and back pain should raise concern for epidural abscess or vertebral osteomyelitis.
  • Empiric IV Vancomycin is the most appropriate first step to cover MRSA.
  • Imaging and TEE are important but should not delay empiric therapy in suspected serious bacterial infection.

choices.text: Histopathological examination showing hydropic villi and trophoblastic proliferation
History of passing grape-like vesicles per vagina

questions.text: Which of the following is the definitive method for diagnosing molar pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histopathological examination showing hydropic villi and trophoblastic proliferation

 

  • While clinical presentation, elevated beta-hCG levels, and characteristic ultrasound findings (snowstorm appearance) are highly suggestive of molar pregnancy, the definitive diagnosis requires histopathological confirmation.
  • Microscopic examination of evacuated tissue revealing:
    • Hydropic swelling of chorionic villi
    • Circumferential trophoblastic proliferation is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • Histological analysis not only confirms the diagnosis but also helps differentiate between complete and partial molar pregnancy, which have different management and malignant potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated serum beta-hCG concentration: Incorrect. Although markedly increased beta-hCG levels are a hallmark of molar pregnancy, this finding is not specific enough for a definitive diagnosis because beta-hCG can also be elevated in normal pregnancy, multiple gestations, or choriocarcinoma.

 

Option B. Characteristic snowstorm appearance on ultrasound: Incorrect. The snowstorm pattern on ultrasound is a classic imaging finding suggestive of molar pregnancy but is not diagnostic. Ultrasound cannot distinguish molar pregnancy from other gestational trophoblastic diseases with certainty.

 

Option D. History of passing grape-like vesicles per vagina: Incorrect. Although passing clear or grape-like vesicles is a notable clinical feature of molar pregnancy, it is neither consistent nor definitive. This clinical sign alone does not confirm the diagnosis without histological evidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The definitive diagnosis of molar pregnancy is established by histopathological examination showing hydropic chorionic villi and trophoblastic proliferation. 
  • obsClinical presentation, elevated beta-hCG, and ultrasound findings are supportive but not diagnostic.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is diagnosed with Fabry disease presents with progressive renal involvement. A urinalysis is ordered. Which of the following urinary casts or findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maltese cross cast

 

  • Fabry disease is an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme α-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) in various tissues, including renal epithelial cells.
  • In urine microscopy, lipid-containing oval fat bodies are seen due to nephrotic-range proteinuria and lipiduria. 
  • These fat bodies exhibit a "Maltese cross" pattern under polarized light, which is a hallmark finding in Fabry disease and other causes of lipiduria.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waxy casts: Seen in chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal failure, not specific to Fabry disease.

 

Option B. RBC casts: Typically found in glomerulonephritis (e.g., post-streptococcal GN, lupus nephritis), not Fabry.

 

Option C. WBC casts: Seen in interstitial nephritis or pyelonephritis, not in Fabry disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Fabry disease, the accumulation of lipid-rich material in renal tubules leads to the presence of Maltese cross-shaped oval fat bodies on urine microscopy under polarized light.
  • This is a distinguishing feature and helps in clinical recognition of lipiduria associated with nephrotic-range proteinuria.

choices.text: Babesia microti – Maltese cross forms on blood smear

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy returns from a family trip to rural Brazil and presents with unilateral periorbital swelling, conjunctivitis, and a subcutaneous “chagoma” at the site of a recent insect bite. Which pathogen and finding pair is most consistent with his presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trypanosoma cruzi – Romana’s sign

 

  • Romana’s sign is the characteristic painless, unilateral periorbital edema and conjunctival inflammation seen in acute Chagas disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. 
  • The parasite enters through the conjunctiva or a bite wound of the reduviid (“kissing”) bug, forming a local inflammatory “chagoma” and leading to this distinctive ocular finding within days of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toxoplasma gondii – Ring-enhancing brain lesions: Typical of reactivated toxoplasmosis in immunocompromised hosts, not associated with periorbital swelling.

 

Option C. Babesia microti – Maltese cross forms on blood smear: Causes hemolytic anemia; no periorbital sign or chagoma.

 

Option D. Leishmania donovani – Amastigotes in macrophages: Visceral leishmaniasis presents with hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia, not ocular swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient develops painless, one-sided periorbital swelling after exposure to reduviid bugs, think Romana’s sign or chagoma’s of acute Chagas disease.

choices.text: Decreased afferent firing from baroreceptors → Increased vagal output
Increased carotid sinus firing → Increased parasympathetic tone
Activation of aortic arch baroreceptors → Sympathetic inhibition

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes carotid massage for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Seconds after massage, she experiences bradycardia, mild hypotension, and lightheadedness. Which of the following physiological changes best explains the observed bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased carotid sinus firing → Increased parasympathetic tone

 

  • Carotid massage mechanically stimulates baroreceptors in the carotid sinus, which perceive it as increased BP. This leads to:
    • ↑ baroreceptor firing
    • ↑ afferent signals via glossopharyngeal nerve
    • ↑ vagal stimulation to SA and AV nodes
    •  Result: Bradycardia and transient hypotension
  • This is used therapeutically in PSVT to slow AV nodal conduction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased afferent firing from baroreceptors → Increased vagal output: Occurs in hypotension—not during carotid massage. It would increase sympathetic tone.

 

Option C. Activation of aortic arch baroreceptors → Sympathetic inhibition: Less sensitive; mainly respond to higher BP ranges. Carotid sinus dominates reflex.

 

Option D. Chemoreceptor stimulation → Enhanced parasympathetic discharge: Respond to hypoxia/CO₂—not involved here. They cause tachycardia, not bradycardia.

 

Educational Objective:


Carotid sinus baroreceptor activation triggers a parasympathetic reflex that slows heart rate, which can be used therapeutically in supraventricular tachycardias.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with SLE, lupus nephritis, and antiphospholipid syndrome on warfarin presents with a 3-week history of increasing fatigue, low-grade fevers, rash, and bilateral wrist pain/swelling. She is adherent to hydroxychloroquine. Labs reveal low C3/C4, and elevated ESR/CRP. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start steroids

 

  • The clinical picture is consistent with active SLE flare (fever, rash, arthritis, low C3/C4 and elevated ESR/CRP).
  • Systemic steroids are indicated to control acute SLE flare symptoms, including joint inflammation and systemic inflammation.
  • Hydroxychloroquine should be continued for long-term SLE management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Provide Reassurance: Is inappropriate with active SLE symptoms.

 

Option B. Renal biopsy: Is not indicated without proteinuria or hematuria.

 

Option D. Stop hydroxychloroquine: Is unnecessary; it’s essential for SLE control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active SLE flares require systemic steroids to manage symptoms like arthritis and rash.
  • Continuation of hydroxychloroquine is critical for long-term disease control.

choices.text: Defective B-cell maturation due to RAG1/2 mutation
Defective interaction between B-cells and T-cells due to CD40L mutation
Impaired antigen presentation due to MHC class I deficiency
Mutation in BTK gene leading to absence of mature B-cells

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent ear and respiratory infections. His past history includes episodes of pneumonia and otitis media. He also developed oral thrush and chronic diarrhea. Physical examination reveals no lymphadenopathy or tonsillar tissue. Laboratory testing shows: Hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL, Platelets 105,000/μL, TLC 3,200/Μl and serum Ig levels as IgM (markedly elevated), IgG (decreased) and IgA (decreased). Flow cytometry reveals normal numbers of CD19+ B-cells and CD3+ T-cells. Genetic testing is likely to conform which of the following as the underlying mechanism of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective interaction between B-cells and T-cells due to CD40L mutation

 

  • This child has Hyper-IgM Syndrome, most often caused by an X-linked mutation in CD40 ligand (CD40L) on T cells, which impairs the ability of T cells to stimulate B cells to undergo class-switch recombination. 
  • As a result:
    • IgM is markedly elevated
    • IgG, IgA, and IgE are decreased
    • Despite normal numbers of B- and T-cells, there is impaired communication between them
    • Patients present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, opportunistic infections, and sometimes cytopenias (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Defective B-cell maturation due to RAG1/2 mutation: This is seen in Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) due to failure of V(D)J recombination, leading to absence of both B- and T-cells.

 

Option C. Impaired antigen presentation due to MHC class I deficiency: Leads to low CD8+ T-cells and recurrent viral infections, but does not cause hyper-IgM or affect B-T interaction via CD40/CD40L.

 

Option D. Mutation in BTK gene leading to absence of mature B-cells: Seen in X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Bruton’s), characterized by absence of mature B-cells and all immunoglobulin classes, not elevated IgM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyper-IgM Syndrome is caused by a defect in CD40–CD40L interaction, leading to failure of class-switch recombination despite normal numbers of B and T cells.
  •  It presents with elevated IgM, low IgG/IgA, recurrent infections, and X-linked inheritance (CD40L mutation).

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with a painless, hard, and immobile mass located near his left knee. The mass has been gradually increasing in size over the past year. On physical examination, there is a bony protuberance on the distal femur. The overlying skin appears normal, and there is no erythema or warmth. Radiographs of the knee are shown below. Based on the X-ray findings and clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteochondroma

 

  • The most common benign bone tumour. It is an outgrowth of bone covered by a cartilaginous cap.
  • Typically presents in adolescents and young adults (fitting the 15-year-old).
  • Often found near growth plates, especially around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia) – fitting "near his left knee" and "distal femur."
  • Usually painless (unless causing mechanical irritation, nerve compression, or fracture), hard, immobile, gradually growing, and presents as a bony protuberance. Overlying skin is typically normal.
  • Characteristically appears as a sessile or pedunculated bony outgrowth from the external surface of the bone, with the cortex and medullary cavity of the lesion being continuous with the underlying bone. This continuity is the hallmark radiographic sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing Sarcoma:

 

  • A highly malignant primary bone tumour.
  • Common in children and young adults (fits the age).
  • Often presents with pain, swelling, and sometimes systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss). The pain is usually progressive and can be severe. It is rarely painless for a year.
  • Typically presents as an aggressive, lytic lesion in the diaphysis or meta diaphysis of long bones, often with a characteristic "onion-skin" periosteal reaction. Not usually a discrete "bony protuberance."

 

Option C. Chondrosarcoma:

 

  • A malignant tumour of cartilage.
  • Less common in adolescents; usually affects older adults (over 40-50 years old), although secondary chondrosarcomas can arise from osteochondromas in younger individuals, this is usually not the initial presentation and implies malignant transformation.
  • Often slow growing but can be painful.
  • May show calcification within the cartilaginous matrix (rings and arcs pattern), endosteal scalloping, and cortical destruction. Not typically a continuous bony outgrowth.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma:

 

  • A highly malignant primary bone tumour that produces osteoid (immature bone).
  • Most common in adolescents and young adults (fits the age).
  • Often found in the metaphysis of long bones, especially around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • Typically presents with significant pain, swelling, and sometimes a palpable mass. The pain is usually severe and progressive. A painless mass for a year makes this less likely for an initial presentation.
  • Aggressive lesion with osteoid matrix formation (sclerotic areas), cortical destruction, soft tissue mass, and classic periosteal reactions like a "sunburst" appearance or Codman's triangle. Not a continuous bony outgrowth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of the patient's age, the nature of the mass, and the presumed radiographic findings strongly points to Osteochondroma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female has recently undergone total thyroidectomy for a thyroid mass. The histopathological examination shows papillary thyroid cancer. What would be the further management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radioiodine scan

 

  • After a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, the usual next step is a radio-iodine scan to look for metastasis.
  • It is performed 3-6 weeks postoperatively 
  • After total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, a radioiodine scan (also known as I-123 or RAI scan) is often used to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastatic disease.
  • It can also aid in planning for subsequent radioactive iodine therapy, if necessary, to ablate residual tissue or treat metastatic disease. 
  • The patient is usually given a dose of radioactive iodine, which is taken up by any remaining thyroid cells, and then imaging is done to determine the distribution of the radioactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Post-operative calcitonin and CEA: Incorrect They are performed in medullary thyroid cancer. In PTC, serum Thyroglobulin is done.

 

Option C. Conservative management: Incorrect. Simply monitoring without further treatment is not the standard of care for papillary thyroid cancer after surgery, especially when the cancer is of significant size, shows aggressive features, or has spread to lymph nodes or distant sites. Typically, the patient will undergo some form of adjuvant therapy or monitoring, often starting with a radioiodine scan.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy: Incorrect for early and most intermediate stages. Chemotherapy isn't a standard treatment for most thyroid cancers. However, it might be recommended for people who don't respond to standard treatments and for certain types of aggressive thyroid cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radioiodine scan to detect any remaining thyroid tissue and potential metastasis usually after 3-6 weeks. 
  • Based on the findings, further therapeutic radioactive iodine might be administered. Regular follow-up, including blood tests and imaging studies, will be necessary to monitor for any recurrence or metastasis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with signs of developmental delay and recurrent infections. Genetic testing reveals a rare inherited disorder affecting vesicular trafficking. Further studies indicate a defect in a coated protein involved in internalization of molecules such as LDL cholesterol and transferrin. The clinician suspects a dysfunction in a protein that forms triskelion-shaped scaffolds around budding vesicles. Which cellular process is primarily impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Receptor-mediated endocytosis

 

  • The clinical scenario describes a clathrin-related transport disorder. Clathrin is a protein that forms a coated pit on the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane, essential for receptor-mediated endocytosis—a selective process used to internalize nutrients (like iron via transferrin or cholesterol via LDL receptors) and hormones.
  • Defects in clathrin or its adaptor proteins impair vesicle formation, leading to inadequate uptake of critical macromolecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple diffusion: Passive movement of small nonpolar molecules (e.g., O₂, CO₂), does not involve proteins or vesicles.

 

Option B. Exocytosis: Involves secretion, not uptake, and uses different machinery (e.g., SNARE proteins).

 

Option D. Facilitated diffusion: Uses carrier or channel proteins, not vesicle formation or clathrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clathrin-mediated receptor endocytosis is a critical cellular process for internalizing specific molecules. 
  • Defects in clathrin impair this pathway, leading to clinical consequences such as nutrient deficiency or signal transduction errors.

choices.text: Rapid overgrowth of contaminants within 3–5 days
Faster growth of Leptospira with enhanced motility
Conversion of Leptospira into nonmotile coccoid forms

questions.text: While establishing cultures for suspected leptospirosis, you accidentally incubate Fletcher’s semisolid medium at 37°C instead of the recommended 30°C. What is the most likely outcome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complete inhibition of Leptospira growth

 

  • Leptospira are obligate aerobes with a narrow optimal growth temperature around 28–30°C.
  • Their enzymes and membrane structures are adapted to this lower temperature. 
  • Incubation at 37°C disrupts their metabolic processes and prevents replication altogether.
  •  Unlike some bacteria that tolerate a broad temperature range or form survival variants, Leptospira simply fail to grow at body temperature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rapid overgrowth of contaminants within 3–5 days: Contaminants may grow at 37°C, but the defining effect is absence of Leptospira growth rather than just contaminants flourishing.

 

Option B. Faster growth of Leptospira with enhanced motility: Higher temperatures inhibit Leptospira; they do not speed up growth or motility above their optimum.

 

 Option D. Conversion of Leptospira into nonmotile coccoid forms: Leptospira do not form coccoid or spore‐like survival forms; they simply do not replicate when conditions are unfavorable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospira culture requires incubation at ~30°C; temperatures at or above 37°C inhibit growth completely.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with facial cellulitis near the nose develops headache, ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, and loss of corneal reflex on the right side. Neurologic exam reveals impaired abduction and sensory loss in V1 territory. Which of the following structures is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cavernous sinus


Cavernous sinus thrombosis from facial infection can affect CN III, IV, V1, V2, VI, and cause corneal reflex loss, ophthalmoplegia, and ptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior orbital fissure: Carries similar nerves but not likely infected from facial cellulitis.

 

Option C. Optic canal: Only CN II and ophthalmic artery.

 

Option D. Infratemporal fossa: Involved in mandibular nerve lesions, not ophthalmoplegia.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Facial infections in the danger triangle can spread to the cavernous sinus, leading to multiple cranial nerve palsies and ophthalmic signs.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with headache, facial plethora, pruritus after hot showers. Physical examination shows splenomegaly. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit. Leukocyte and platelet counts are also increased. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypercellularity with prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation. Serum erythropoietin level is decreased. Which of the following mutations is most strongly associated with the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) JAK2 V617F mutation

 

  • The patient presents with features suggestive of Polycythemia Vera (PV), a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by:
    • Erythrocytosis (↑ RBC mass)
    • Leukocytosis and thrombocytosis
    • Low serum erythropoietin levels
    • Hypercellular bone marrow with panmyelosis
    • Splenomegaly
    • Aquagenic pruritus (pruritus triggered by hot water)
  • The JAK2 V617F mutation is present in >95% of PV cases and leads to constitutive activation of the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, promoting uncontrolled proliferation of hematopoietic cells independent of erythropoietin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BCR-ABL fusion gene: Seen in Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), not in PV. It results from the t(9;22) translocation (Philadelphia chromosome).

 

Option B. CALR mutation: Found in some cases of essential thrombocythemia and primary myelofibrosis, but not typically associated with PV.

 

Option D. MPL mutation: Associated with myeloproliferative disorders like essential thrombocythemia and primary myelofibrosis, but not PV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polycythemia Vera is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by JAK2 V617F mutation, which drives panmyelosis and elevated red cell mass.
  •  This mutation leads to erythropoietin-independent proliferation via JAK-STAT pathway activation.

questions.text:
A biochemistry student measures NADPH production in various metabolic enzymes. Which of the following enzymes generate NADPH under physiological conditions?

 

  1. Cytosolic Isocitrate dehydrogenase
  2. Malic enzyme
  3. Succinate dehydrogenase
  4. α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  5. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2

 

  • NADPH is a crucial reducing agent used in biosynthetic reactions, antioxidant defense (e.g., glutathione regeneration), and cytochrome P450 metabolism.
  • It is primarily generated by cytosolic reactions.

 

Statement 1. Cytosolic Isocitrate Dehydrogenase:

 

  • This is a NADP⁺-dependent enzyme (not to be confused with mitochondrial IDH3 which uses NAD⁺).
  • Catalyses the conversion of isocitrate → α-ketoglutarate + NADPH (in cytosol).
  • Yes, it generates NADPH.

 

 Statement 2. Malic Enzyme:

 

  • Also known as NADP⁺-dependent malate dehydrogenase (not to be confused with mitochondrial NAD⁺-dependent malate dehydrogenase).
  • Converts malate → pyruvate + CO₂ + NADPH.
  • Yes, it generates NADPH.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. Succinate Dehydrogenase: Incorrect.

 

  • Part of the TCA cycle and electron transport chain (Complex II).
  • Uses FAD, not NAD⁺ or NADP⁺.
  • Does NOT generate NADPH.

 

Statement 4. α-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase: Incorrect.

 

  • Mitochondrial TCA enzyme.
  • Uses NAD⁺ → NADH, not NADP⁺.
  • Generates NADH, not NADPH.

 

Statement 5. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase: Incorrect

 

  • Converts pyruvate → acetyl-CoA + CO₂ + NADH.
  • Does NOT generate NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Reposition the uterus and start intravenous oxytocin infusion
Arrange for blood transfusion and administer 20 units of oxytocin intravenously

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 3, delivers at 37 weeks of gestation following rapid progression of labor. Immediately after the baby is born, the placenta is expelled spontaneously. Soon after, the patient complains of sudden abdominal pain and collapses. On physical examination, the uterus is not palpable abdominally, and a mass is detected on vaginal examination. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reposition the uterus and start intravenous oxytocin infusion

 

  • This patient presents with a classic clinical scenario of uterine inversion, a rare but life-threatening obstetric emergency that typically occurs immediately after the delivery of the placenta.
  • Key clinical features include:
    • Sudden onset abdominal pain following placental delivery
    • Hemodynamic collapse (shock)
    • Absence of uterine fundus on abdominal palpation
    • A mass felt protruding into or through the vagina
  • The immediate management of uterine inversion is:
    1. Manual repositioning of the uterus (Johnson maneuver) — The uterus must be promptly pushed back through the vagina into its normal position to prevent irreversible uterine constriction and worsening hemorrhage.
    2. Initiation of uterotonic agents (e.g., oxytocin) — After successful repositioning, oxytocin is started to promote uterine contraction and prevent re-inversion.
  • Delay in repositioning increases morbidity due to hemorrhage and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate laparotomy: Incorrect. Laparotomy is reserved for cases where manual repositioning fails or if the uterus is irreducible by vaginal approach. The next best step in this acute scenario is immediate manual repositioning, not surgical intervention.

 

Option C. Arrange for blood transfusion and administer 20 units of oxytocin intravenously: Incorrect. Although blood transfusion and oxytocin are critical supportive measures, repositioning of the inverted uterus is the priority before administering uterotonics. Administering oxytocin before repositioning can make the uterus more difficult to reposition due to induced contractions.

 

Option D. Obtain an urgent ultrasound examination: Incorrect. The diagnosis of uterine inversion is a clinical diagnosis and does not require confirmation by ultrasound. Any delay for imaging can worsen hemorrhage and shock. Immediate repositioning is critical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine inversion is an obstetric emergency presenting with shock, abdominal pain, and a vaginal mass following delivery.
  • The immediate management is manual repositioning of the uterus followed by administration of oxytocin to maintain uterine tone.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with painless swelling of several fingers. A PA radiograph of both hands is shown in the below image. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ollier disease

 

  • Ollier disease is characterized by multiple enchondromas—benign cartilaginous tumors arising within the metaphyses of long bones and small bones of the hands and feet.
  • On radiographs, these appear as expansile, lucent lesions with internal “rings‐and‐arcs” or punctate calcifications reflecting endochondral mineralization.
  • The lesions are asymmetric and confined to the skeleton without associated vascular malformations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Maffucci syndrome: Similar to Ollier but distinguished by the presence of venous malformations or hemangiomas (soft‐tissue calcifications and phleboliths) alongside enchondromas.

 

Option C. Multiple osteochondromas: Show bony exostoses (cartilage‐capped projections) arising from the bone surface and pointing away from the joint; they are not intramedullary lucencies.

 

Option D. Metachondromatosis: Features both enchondromas and osteochondromas, but the osteochondromas typically point toward the joint and often regress over time, unlike the purely enchondromatous lesions of Ollier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ollier disease = multiple, asymmetric enchondromas with “rings-and-arcs” calcification on X-ray, no vascular malformations; Maffucci adds hemangiomas, osteochondromas are surface exostoses.

choices.text: A prolonged period of case occurrence extending beyond one incubation period
Frequent secondary cases from person-to-person spread
An explosive rise and fall in case numbers within one incubation period
Severity of illness increasing with age

questions.text: A summer‐camp counselor brings 25 campers to the infirmary complaining of sudden onset abdominal cramps, vomiting, and diarrhea. All symptoms began within 4–6 hours after eating the same contaminated potato salad at lunch. Over the next 12 hours, almost every camper recovers without further transmission. Which feature best characterizes this type of outbreak?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) An explosive rise and fall in case numbers within one incubation period

 

  • This scenario describes a single‐exposure common‐vehicle (point‐source) outbreak.
  • Explosive epidemic curve: A sharp spike in cases occurs shortly after a single exposure (the potato salad), with most cases clustering within one incubation period.
  • Limited to one incubation period: Because everyone was exposed at the same time and the source is removed (meal over), new cases decline rapidly without ongoing transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A prolonged period of case occurrence extending beyond one incubation period: Indicates a continuous common‐source outbreak where the source persists (e.g., contaminated water supply), leading to cases over multiple incubation periods.

 

Option B. Frequent secondary cases from person-to-person spread:
Suggests a propagated (person‐to‐person) outbreak, not a single‐exposure event.

 

Option D. Severity of illness increasing with age: Describes a pattern related to host factors, not the outbreak’s temporal pattern; it does not define the outbreak type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a point‐source outbreak, look for a rapid surge and decline of cases—all occurring within one incubation period—reflecting simultaneous exposure rather than ongoing or person-to-person spread.

questions.text: In menopausal women receiving hormone replacement therapy (HRT), which of the following preparations is commonly prescribed to protect the endometrium from the proliferative effects of estrogen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medroxyprogesterone acetate

 

  • In menopausal hormone replacement therapy, progesterone is added to estrogen therapy in women with an intact uterus to counteract the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation.
  • Medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA) is the most commonly used progestin for this purpose in HRT regimens.
  • It is effective in opposing estrogen’s action on the endometrium, thereby reducing the risk of hyperplasia and malignancy.
  • It can be administered orally or intramuscularly and has an established safety and efficacy profile in menopausal HRT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Micronized progesterone: Incorrect. Although micronized progesterone is also used in HRT and is better tolerated by some women, it is less commonly used compared to medroxyprogesterone acetate in standard practice. However, it may be preferred for its lower risk of breast cancer and cardiovascular side effects in certain patients.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel: Incorrect. Levonorgestrel is primarily used in contraceptive formulations and intrauterine devices (IUDs), not as a standard systemic progestin in menopausal HRT.

 

Option D. Dydrogesterone: Incorrect. Dydrogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in selected hormone therapies but is less commonly used in standard menopausal HRT compared to medroxyprogesterone acetate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medroxyprogesterone acetate is the most commonly used progestin in hormone replacement therapy for menopausal women with an intact uterus to prevent estrogen-induced endometrial hyperplasia.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Susac Syndrome are true? 

 

  1. It commonly presents in young females.
  2. Retinal involvement is due to branch retinal artery occlusion.
  3. Sensorineural hearing loss is a component of the triad.
  4. It is associated with large vessel vasculitis.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

  • Susac Syndrome is a rare autoimmune endotheliopathy characterized by occlusion of microvessels in the brain, retina, and inner ear. 
  • It most often affects young women (usually in their 20s to 40s).
  • The classic triad includes:
    • Encephalopathy (neurological symptoms) — From microinfarctions in the brain, particularly the corpus callosum
    • Branch Retinal Artery Occlusions (BRAO) — Leading to visual disturbances
    • Sensorineural Hearing Loss — Due to cochlear microvascular involvement
  • Susac syndrome is considered a small vessel vasculopathy, not large vessel vasculitis.
  • It is thought to be mediated by autoimmune attack on endothelial cells, causing microvascular occlusions.
  • Statement 1. It commonly presents in young females: True. Susac syndrome predominantly affects young females, making this a correct statement.
  • Statement 2. Retinal involvement is due to branch retinal artery occlusion: True. The retinal involvement is due to branch retinal artery occlusion (BRAO), causing transient or permanent visual symptoms.
  • Statement 3. Sensorineural hearing loss is a component of the triad: True. Sensorineural hearing loss is indeed part of the classical triad, resulting from microvascular damage to the cochlea.

 

Incorrect statement: 

 

  • Statement 4. It is associated with large vessel vasculitis: False. The condition involves small vessel vasculopathy, not large vessel vasculitis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Susac syndrome is a rare autoimmune small vessel vasculopathy presenting with the triad of encephalopathy, branch retinal artery occlusion, and sensorineural hearing loss, predominantly in young females.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought by his family due to disorganized behavior and irrelevant speech. During the interview, he says, “I like to watch TV. My feet are cold. The universe is expanding. You know, elephants have great memories.”. He appears internally preoccupied and often talks to himself. What is the most likely thought disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Derailment

 

  • The patient's speech jumps from one topic to another with no logical connection, as in: “I like to watch TV. My feet are cold. The universe is expanding. You know, elephants have great memories.” 
  • This is classic derailment, a formal thought disorder commonly seen in schizophrenia. In derailment, the individual’s ideas slip off the track onto unrelated or loosely related topics, without returning to the original theme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thought insertion: It is a disorder of possession of thoughts in which the person believes thoughts are being inserted into their mind by an external force. It is not a speech/thought flow issue.

 

Option B. Flight of ideas: Seen in mania, where thoughts rapidly shift but are connected by meaningful associations or wordplay—not evident here.

 

Option D. Tangentiality: Involves responses that begin to answer a question but never reach the point, instead going off on tangents. In derailment, the person switches topics entirely with no logical progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Derailment is a formal thought disorder characterized by a loss of connection between successive thoughts.

questions.text: In Village A, the total population is 5,000, of whom 600 are children aged 0–6 years and thus excluded from literacy calculations. If 3,200 of the remaining residents can read and write with understanding in at least one Indian language. Calculate the literacy rate according to the 2011 Census definition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 72.7%

 

  • Determine the denominator: The 2011 Census defines literacy rate as the proportion of literates among the population aged 7 years and above. Children aged 0–6 years are excluded.

 

Population ≥ 7 years = 5,000 – 600 = 4,400

 

  • Identify the numerator:
    Number of literate persons (aged ≥ 7 years) = 3,200.
  • Compute the literacy rate:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Always exclude the 0–6 years age group when calculating the standard literacy rate under the 2011 Census; use population aged ≥ 7 years as the denominator.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, and IV drug use presents to the ER with a 2-day history of a new rash on both lower extremities, malaise, and arthralgias. Examination shows a 2/6 systolic murmur at the lower sternal border, nodular liver, splenomegaly, and 4/5 strength in lower extremities. All of the following can be done except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Kidney biopsy

 

  • The clinical presentation (rash, murmur, neurological deficits) in an IV drug user suggests ongoing infection or vasculitis.
  • Blood cultures, echocardiogram, and complement/cryoglobulin testing are critical to evaluate for endocarditis and cryoglobulinemia.
  • Kidney biopsy is premature without evidence of glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood cultures: Are essential to assess for persistent bacteremia.

 

Option B. Echocardiogram: Confirms endocarditis or valvular involvement.

 

Option C. Complement levels: Help evaluate for cryoglobulinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endocarditis in IV drug users requires blood cultures and echocardiogram. 
  • Cryoglobulinemia may be seen in IVDU due to risk of HCV infection.

choices.text: Horizontal line through the angle of the mandible

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a lump under her jaw. On examination, the lump is found to be associated with the submandibular gland. Which structure separates the superficial and deep lobes of the submandibular gland?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mylohyoid muscle

 

  • The mylohyoid muscle separates the superficial and deep lobes of the submandibular gland.
  • The submandibular gland wraps around the posterior edge of the mylohyoid muscle, forming its superficial and deep parts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoid bone: The hyoid bone is located in the anterior neck and does not play a role in separating the lobes of the submandibular gland.

 

Option B. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is located near the submandibular gland, but it does not separate the superficial and deep lobes of the gland.

 

Option D. Horizontal line through the angle of mandible: A horizontal line through the angle of the mandible is an anatomical reference but does not separate the superficial and deep lobes of the gland

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mylohyoid muscle separates the superficial and deep lobes of the submandibular gland.

choices.text: It is associated with autosomal recessive inheritance due to a mismatch repair gene defect
The condition is due to APC mutation on chromosome 5q and is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern
The most commonly mutated gene encodes a zinc finger transcription factor involved in pancreatic development

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with intermittent rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and occasional episodes of spurious diarrhea. He has a strong family history of colorectal cancer. Colonoscopy and biopsy findings of the patient are shown below. Which of the following statements about this patient’s condition is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The condition is due to APC mutation on chromosome 5q and is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern

 

  • The patient’s age, symptoms, and numerous adenomatous polyps on colonoscopy, along with signet ring appearance on microscopy are classic for Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP).
  • FAP is caused by mutations in the APC gene located on chromosome 5q.
  • It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
  • Patients typically develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum during adolescence or early adulthood.
  • Without prophylactic colectomy, there is a near-100% risk of developing colorectal cancer.
  • Associated features include increased risk of IBD, Streptococcus bovis endocarditis, and extracolonic tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is associated with autosomal recessive inheritance due to a mismatch repair gene defect: Incorrect. This describes Lynch syndrome, not FAP. Lynch is due to mismatch repair gene mutations and is autosomal dominant, not recessive.

 

Option B. Cardiac complications include Libman-Sacks endocarditis: Incorrect. Libman-Sacks endocarditis is associated with SLE, not FAP. FAP may predispose to S. bovis endocarditis.

 

Option D. The most commonly mutated gene encodes a zinc finger transcription factor involved in pancreatic development: Incorrect. This describes mutations in PDX1, a transcription factor important in pancreatic development, and is not relevant to the pathogenesis of FAP or colon cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant condition due to an APC gene mutation on chromosome 5q, characterized by ≥100 adenomatous colonic polyps, with high colorectal cancer risk if not surgically treated.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man on treatment of type 2 diabetes reports progressive weight gain and worsening congestive heart failure. Which antihyperglycemic agent would be least likely to exacerbate his heart failure or cause weight gain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Canagliflozin

 

  • Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that promotes urinary glucose and sodium excretion, leading to osmotic diuresis, mild weight loss, and reduced preload/afterload on the heart. 
  • Side effects: UTI and EKA
  • Large clinical trials (e.g., CANVAS, EMPA-REG) have shown it reduces hospitalization for heart failure and is beneficial in such patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glipizide: A sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion. Increased circulating insulin promotes lipogenesis, leading to weight gain. Though it does not directly worsen CHF, the associated weight gain can indirectly aggravate fluid overload in CHF patients.

 

Option B. Glibenclamide: Another sulfonylurea, similar in mechanism to glipizide, causing weight gain and posing a risk of hypoglycemia, which may trigger sympathetic stimulation and potentially worsen CHF symptoms.

 

Option C. Pioglitazone: A thiazolidinedione (TZD) that activates PPAR-γ receptors, improving insulin sensitivity but causing fluid retention, edema, and weight gain. It is contraindicated in patients with symptomatic heart failure because it can worsen CHF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with type 2 diabetes and worsening congestive heart failure, choose an SGLT2 inhibitor like canagliflozin to avoid weight gain and fluid retention—in contrast to sulfonylureas or thiazolidinediones, which exacerbate these issues.

choices.text: Right cerebral peduncle and oculomotor nerve fascicle

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with right-sided ptosis, eye deviation down and out, and left-sided hemiparesis. He also shows an impaired pupillary light reflex on the right. Which of the following is the most likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right cerebral peduncle and oculomotor nerve fascicle

 

This is Weber syndrome, a midbrain stroke involving the oculomotor nerve fascicle (causing third nerve palsy) and cerebral peduncle (causing contralateral hemiparesis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left internal capsule: Would cause contralateral hemiparesis but no cranial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Right abducens nucleus: Would cause lateral gaze palsy, not third nerve involvement.

 

Option D. Right optic tract: Would cause left homonymous hemianopia, not motor deficits.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Weber syndrome is due to a midbrain infarct affecting the oculomotor fascicle and corticospinal fibers, causing ipsilateral CN III palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

choices.text: Initiation of a calcium channel blocker
Antifungal therapy for empiric coverage of Candida

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, COPD, and coronary artery disease presents to the ED with a 5-week history of foul-smelling breath, vomiting after meals, and epigastric pressure. Barium swallow finding is shown below. He reports occasional chest discomfort but denies dysphagia for solids specifically. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastroenterology consultation for possible EGD

 

  • The barium swallow shows a bird beak narrowing at the distal end with proximal dilatation, consistent with achalasia, a motility disorder causing dysphagia and regurgitation.
  • Foul-smelling breath, vomiting, and epigastric pressure are common symptoms of achalasia. 
  • EGD (Esophagogastroduodenoscopy) is essential to confirm achalasia and assess for complications like esophagitis or malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initiation of a calcium channel blocker: Calcium channel blockers may relieve symptoms but require diagnostic confirmation first.

 

Option C. Surgery consultation for possible esophagectomy: Esophagectomy is not first-line; EGD is needed to guide treatment.

 

Option D. Antifungal therapy for empiric coverage of Candida: Antifungal therapy is inappropriate without evidence of fungal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Achalasia is characterized by esophageal dilation, regurgitation, and risk of aspiration.
  • EGD is the initial diagnostic step to confirm the condition and guide management.

choices.text: It inhibits ATP-citrate lyase, reducing cholesterol synthesis upstream of HMG-CoA reductase.
It is a prodrug that is activated primarily in the liver, minimizing the risk of myopathy.
It significantly lowers triglycerides by activating PPAR-α receptors.
It may increase serum uric acid levels.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease and statin-associated myopathy is started on bempedoic acid for hypercholesterolemia. Which of the following statements about bempedoic acid is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It significantly lowers triglycerides by activating PPAR-α receptors 

 

  • Bempedoic acid does not activate PPAR-α and has only minimal impact on triglyceride levels. 
  • Its primary mechanism is inhibition of ATP-citrate lyase (ACL) in hepatocytes, which decreases acetyl-CoA availability for cholesterol synthesis upstream of HMG-CoA reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It inhibits ATP-citrate lyase, reducing cholesterol synthesis upstream of HMG-CoA reductase: True. Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP-citrate lyase (ACL), reducing hepatic cholesterol synthesis and upregulating LDL receptors, lowering LDL-C.

 

Option B. It is a prodrug that is activated primarily in the liver, minimizing the risk of myopathy: True. It is a prodrug converted to bempedoyl-CoA by ACSVL1 enzyme, which is expressed mainly in the liver and not in skeletal muscle, explaining its low risk of myopathy.

 

Option D. It may increase serum uric acid levels: True. Adverse effects include hyperuricemia (risk of gout) and rare tendon rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bempedoic acid lowers LDL-C by ACL inhibition in the liver and carries a low myopathy risk but does not lower triglycerides via PPAR-α and may increase uric acid.

choices.text: Neorickettsia sennetsu – Ingestion of infected fish

questions.text: A 58-year-old rancher from Minnesota presents in spring with fever, headache, and profound neutropenia. A peripheral smear shows morulae within granulocytes. Which organism is most likely responsible, and what is its primary tick vector?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplasma phagocytophilum – Ixodes scapularis

 

  • Pathogen biology: Anaplasma phagocytophilum infects neutrophils, forming characteristic intracytoplasmic morulae (microcolonies) within granulocytes.
  • Clinical features: Human granulocytic anaplasmosis typically presents in spring–summer with fever, severe myalgias, headache, and laboratory findings of neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and mild transaminitis.
  • Vector and geography: In the Upper Midwest and northeastern United States (including Minnesota), Ixodes scapularis (black-legged tick) transmits A. phagocytophilum.
  • These features contrast with other Anaplasmataceae members that infect monocytes, use different vectors, or require alternative exposure routes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehrlichia chaffeensis – Amblyomma americanum: Causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis with morulae in monocytes, not neutrophils. The Lone Star tick transmits it, and patients often show lymphopenia and elevated liver enzymes.

 

Option B. Ehrlichia ewingii – Amblyomma americanum: Also infects granulocytes, but E. ewingii infections are rarer, typically milder, and epidemiologically overlap E. chaffeensis. It does not explain the classic Ixodes–Minnesota ecology nor the degree of neutropenia seen here. It is not tick mediated

 

Option D. Neorickettsia sennetsu – Ingestion of infected fish: Causes a mononucleosis‐like illness with atypical lymphocytosis, acquired by eating fish with trematode vectors—not by tick bite—and does not produce neutrophil morulae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with early summer fever, headache, and intraneutrophilic morulae from Minnesota, think granulocytic anaplasmosis (Anaplasma phagocytophilum via Ixodes scapularis), not monocytic ehrlichiosis or fish‐borne Neorickettsia.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with chronic right ear discharge for the past year, unresponsive to multiple courses of antibiotics. He also has congenital canal atresia on the same side, making air-conduction hearing aid fitting unsuccessful. His bone conduction threshold is 30 dB, and cochlear function is normal on audiometry. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for hearing rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA)

 

  • BAHA is indicated when:
    • Air-conduction (AC) hearing aids cannot be used, e.g.:
      • Canal atresia (congenital/acquired)
      • Chronic ear discharge
      • Feedback/discomfort from AC aids
    • Conductive or mixed hearing loss where surgery is contraindicated
    • Single-sided hearing loss with a normal cochlea
  • This patient has canal atresia, chronic discharge, and a normal functioning cochlea and cochlear nerve (bone conduction threshold = 30 dB), fulfilling all criteria for BAHA.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear implant: Reserved for sensorineural hearing loss with non-functional cochlea/nerve.

 

Option B. Tympanoplasty with ossiculoplasty: Not suitable due to chronic infection and canal atresia.

 

Option D. Auditory brainstem implant: Used in bilateral acoustic neuromas or non-functional cochlea/nerve, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BAHA is indicated in conductive/mixed hearing loss where air-conduction aids cannot be used, provided the cochlea and auditory nerve are functional.
  • It is a key tool in managing canal atresia, chronic discharge, or single-sided deafness with good cochlear reserve.

choices.text: Propylthiouracil (PTU) in the 1st trimester followed by methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters
Methimazole during the 1st trimester and Propylthiouracil (PTU) in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters
Propylthiouracil (PTU) for the entire duration of pregnancy

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with Graves' disease at her first prenatal visit. She requires antithyroid medication for hyperthyroidism management. According to the recommendations of the American Thyroid Association (ATA), which of the following is the safest treatment approach for her condition during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Propylthiouracil (PTU) in the 1st trimester followed by methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters

 

  • The American Thyroid Association (ATA) recommends a trimester-specific approach for the treatment of hyperthyroidism in pregnancy due to the differing risk profiles of methimazole (MMI) and propylthiouracil (PTU).
  • Propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred in the first trimester because methimazole is associated with teratogenic effects when used during organogenesis (e.g., aplasia cutis, choanal atresia, tracheoesophageal fistula).
  • After the first trimester, the risk of methimazole-associated birth defects declines, while the risk of PTU-induced hepatotoxicity increases with longer use. Therefore, methimazole is recommended in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters to minimize the risk of maternal liver injury.
  • This switch strategy balances fetal and maternal safety throughout the pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methimazole throughout pregnancy: Incorrect. Methimazole use during the first trimester is avoided due to its association with congenital anomalies. Continuous use throughout pregnancy disregards the teratogenic risk in early gestation.

 

Option C. Methimazole during the 1st trimester and Propylthiouracil (PTU) in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters: Incorrect. This approach is not recommended. Using methimazole in the 1st trimester exposes the fetus to the risk of congenital malformations, which is specifically why PTU is preferred early in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Propylthiouracil (PTU) for the entire duration of pregnancy: Incorrect. Though PTU is safer during the 1st trimester, prolonged use increases the risk of severe hepatotoxicity in the mother, making long-term therapy throughout pregnancy inadvisable. The switch to methimazole after the first trimester is the correct strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The American Thyroid Association recommends using propylthiouracil (PTU) in the first trimester of pregnancy due to the teratogenicity risk of methimazole, followed by switching to methimazole in the second and third trimesters to minimize the risk of PTU-induced hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman in active labor develops a prolonged second stage of labor. On clinical examination, there is a constriction ring forming between the upper and lower uterine segments, causing signs of obstructed labor. What is this pathological uterine finding called?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bandl’s ring

 

  • Bandl’s ring is a pathological retraction ring seen in cases of obstructed labor, where the upper uterine segment becomes thickened and contracted while the lower uterine segment thins out excessively.
  • This creates a visible or palpable transverse groove (the Bandl’s ring) that rises progressively as obstruction worsens.
  • It is associated with risk of uterine rupture if not managed promptly.
  • Bandl’s ring is distinct from physiological constriction rings (like McDonald’s ring) and is considered a sign of obstructed labor.

 

 

Other Options:
