Option B. Cervical stenosis: Incorrect. Cervical stenosis refers to a narrowed cervical canal, typically a chronic or congenital condition causing infertility or labor dysfunction, not an acute labor obstruction phenomenon like Bandl’s ring.

 

Option C. McDonald’s constriction ring: Incorrect. McDonald’s constriction ring is a functional or physiological constriction ring, usually transient, that may occur during labor without causing obstruction. Unlike Bandl’s ring, it is not pathological and not typically associated with obstructed labor.

 

Option D. Premature cervical closure: Incorrect. This is not a recognized term in obstetric practice for labor obstruction. It refers more to incompetent cervix in pregnancy rather than an obstructed labor phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bandl’s ring is a pathological retraction ring formed between the upper and lower uterine segments during obstructed labor, characterized by uterine segmental disproportion and risk of rupture if not treated urgently.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of rash and joint pain. He has a recent history of sore throat and fever. Examination shows purpura, ankle/knee swelling, and mild abdominal tenderness. Skin biopsy shows leukocytoclastic vasculitis with immune complex deposits. Which of the following is unlikely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
 

  • The combination of palpable purpura, migratory arthralgias, and colicky abdominal pain following a streptococcal‑type illness, together with leukocytoclastic vasculitis on skin biopsy, is classic for IgA‑mediated small‑vessel vasculitis.
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is characterized by necrotizing granulomas, prominent upper and lower respiratory tract involvement, and renal disease (often with c‑ANCA positivity), none of which are present here.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis: Immune‑complex mediated; can present with purpura and arthralgias, though often in the setting of hepatitis C or cold sensitivity.

 

Option B. Cutaneous small vessel vasculitis: A broad term for isolated leukocytoclastic vasculitis of the skin, matching the biopsy and rash distribution.

 

Option C. IgA vasculitis: Presents with the exact triad of purpura, joint pain, and abdominal pain post‑infection, with IgA deposition on biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post‑infectious palpable purpura plus joint and abdominal symptoms with leukocytoclastic vasculitis strongly indicate IgA vasculitis. 
  • GPA is excluded by the absence of granulomas, respiratory tract involvement, and renal manifestations.

questions.text: A 25-year-old climber complains of shoulder weakness and inability to extend the shoulder joint effectively. On examination, you notice atrophy in the pectoral and dorsal regions. Which muscle pair is most likely involved in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pectoralis major and latissimus dorsi

 

  • Pectoralis major and latissimus dorsi are collectively referred to as the "climber's muscles" because of their role in shoulder extension, adduction, and medial rotation.
  • The pectoralis major is a primary muscle of the pectoral region, while the latissimus dorsi is located in the dorsal region. 
  • Their dysfunction can significantly impair climbing and similar activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serratus anterior and trapezius: Incorrect. These muscles are involved in scapular stabilization and movement but are not directly responsible for shoulder extension.

 

Option C. Rhomboids and levator scapulae: Incorrect. These muscles primarily assist in scapular elevation and retraction.

 

Option D. Subscapularis and teres major: Incorrect. While these muscles contribute to internal rotation and adduction of the arm, they are not the primary extensors of the shoulder joint.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The pectoralis major and latissimus dorsi are essential for shoulder extension and adduction and are commonly referred to as "climber's muscles" due to their significant role in activities involving overhead pulling.

questions.text: A mutation in a gene responsible for expressing self-antigens in the thymus leads to impaired central tolerance and early-onset autoimmune disease affecting multiple organs. Which of the following genes is most likely mutated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

  • The AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) gene encodes a transcription factor that is essential for the expression of peripheral self-antigens in the medullary thymic epithelial cells. 
  • This enables negative selection of autoreactive T cells, a process critical for the establishment of central immune tolerance. 
  • Mutations in the AIRE gene lead to the condition autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1 (APS-1), characterized by autoimmunity affecting multiple organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: This gene is important for T-cell lineage specification during thymic development but does not participate in peripheral antigen expression or central tolerance mechanisms.

 

Option B. GATA3: GATA3 is a transcription factor involved in the differentiation of T-helper 2 (Th2) cells but is not implicated in central tolerance or thymic antigen presentation.

 

Option C. Rag ½: These genes are required for V(D)J recombination in B and T lymphocytes to generate diverse antigen receptors but do not regulate expression of tissue-specific antigens in the thymus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene plays a critical role in central immune tolerance by enabling thymic expression of peripheral self-antigens, allowing deletion of autoreactive T cells. Its deficiency can lead to severe autoimmune disease.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy finds his unbroken forearm licked by a stray dog in his village. He’s never been vaccinated against rabies. Which statements are true? 

 

  1. This is Category I; only wound washing is needed—no vaccine or RIG.
  2. Because dogs are high-risk, you should still administer two ID vaccine doses on Days 0 and 3.
  3. RIG is only indicated if the dog’s saliva contacts broken skin or mucosa.
  4. If you choose IM over ID vaccine for Category I, you still give only two doses.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 3 only

 

Statement 1. This is Category I; only wound washing is needed—no vaccine or RIG: True. A lick on intact skin is classified as Category I exposure. According to WHO guidelines, Category I requires only thorough wound washing (15 minutes with soap or detergent and water); neither rabies vaccine nor rabies immune globulin (RIG) is indicated.

 

Statement 3. RIG is only indicated if the dog’s saliva contacts broken skin or mucosa: True. RIG is reserved for Category III exposures—those involving broken skin or mucosal contamination by potentially rabid saliva. Since the skin was intact, RIG is not indicated here.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. Because dogs are high-risk, you should still administer two ID vaccine doses on Days 0 and 3: False. Even though dogs can carry rabies, prophylactic vaccination is not given for Category I exposures. Administering two ID doses would constitute unnecessary overtreatment.

 

Statement 4. If you choose IM over ID vaccine for Category I, you still give only two doses: False. No vaccine regimen—ID or IM—is indicated in Category I. The choice of route (IM vs. ID) only applies when vaccine is required (Categories II/III).

 

Educational Objective:

 

PEP recommendations by category of exposure:

 

 

*Abbreviated vaccination applies only if a full PEP course was completed within the past 3 months.

choices.text: Four contractions in 20 minutes or eight contractions in 60 minutes with documented cervical changes

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior position of the cervix

 

  • The position of the cervix (anterior, mid, or posterior) is not a diagnostic parameter for preterm labor.
  • Cervical position may vary in labor, but it is not used as a criterion for diagnosing preterm labor.
  • A posterior cervix is often seen in early labor or non-laboring cervix.
  • Preterm labor is defined as regular uterine contractions causing progressive cervical changes (dilatation and/or effacement) before 37 weeks of gestation.
  • The diagnosis requires both uterine activity and cervical changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Four contractions in 20 minutes or eight contractions in 60 minutes with documented cervical changes: Correct diagnostic criterion. Frequent uterine contractions associated with cervical change defines labor, including preterm labor.

 

Option B. Cervical dilatation greater than 1 cm: Correct diagnostic criterion. Cervical dilatation greater than 1 cm is significant and diagnostic when accompanied by contractions.

 

Option C. Cervical effacement more than 80 percent: Correct diagnostic criterion. Cervical effacement of 80% or more suggests cervical ripening due to labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnosis of preterm labor requires evidence of regular uterine contractions with progressive cervical changes (dilatation and/or effacement).
  • Cervical position is not part of the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor.

choices.text: It is neutralized by specific antibodies
It is part of the somatic antigen

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit with high-grade fever, hypotension, and altered mental status. Blood cultures grow Escherichia coli. Despite fluid resuscitation, he remains hypotensive and requires vasopressors. The patient is diagnosed with septic shock due to Gram-negative bacteremia. Which of the following statements about the endotoxin responsible for his condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is neutralized by specific antibodies

 

  • Endotoxins are lipopolysaccharides (LPS) found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria.
  • The toxic component, lipid A, is responsible for triggering a strong innate immune response, often resulting in fever, hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and septic shock.
  • Importantly, endotoxins are not effectively neutralized by specific antibodies. 
  • This is due to their poor antigenicity and the fact that the lipid A portion, which mediates toxicity, is relatively hidden from the immune system and structurally conserved across species, making antibody targeting ineffective.
  • In contrast, exotoxins (typically secreted proteins of Gram-positive bacteria) are highly immunogenic and can be neutralized by specific antitoxins or antibodies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is heat stable: Correct. Endotoxins are heat stable and resist boiling temperatures, which is a key difference from protein-based exotoxins that are heat labile.

 

Option C. It is part of the somatic antigen: Correct. The "O antigen" is the outer polysaccharide chain of LPS and contributes to the somatic (O) antigen in serotyping of Gram-negative organisms.

 

Option D. It is poorly antigenic: Correct. Endotoxins stimulate immune responses via Toll-like receptors (especially TLR4), but they are not strongly immunogenic in the classical sense. They do not elicit long-lasting immunity or high-affinity antibody production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endotoxins (lipopolysaccharides of Gram-negative bacteria) are heat-stable, poorly antigenic, and are not effectively neutralized by specific antibodies.

questions.text: The ICF concentration of K⁺ is 140 mEq/L and ECF concentration is 14 mEq/L, and the cell is permeable only to K⁺. What would be the expected change if the extracellular K⁺ concentration is reduced from 14 to 1.4 millimolar?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 61 millivolts hyperpolarization

 

  • This question involves the calculation of the Equilibrium potential (EP) using the Nernst equation, which describes the equilibrium potential for an ion.
  • For potassium (K⁺), the Nernst equation can be simplified as:

 

 

Given:

 

  • Initial extracellular concentration [K⁺ outside] = 14 mEq/L
  • Intracellular concentration [K⁺ inside] = 140 mEq/L
  • After the change, [K⁺ outside] = 1.4 mEq/L

 

Step 1: Calculate initial EP

 

Before the change:

 

 

This is the initial resting membrane potential.

 

Step 2: Calculate the new EP after reducing [K⁺ outside]

 

After reducing extracellular potassium to 1.4 mEq/L:

 

 

This is the new resting membrane potential.

 

Step 3: Determine the change in EP

 

The initial RMP was −61 mV, and the new RMP is −122 mV. The change is:

 

−122 mV−(−61 mV) =−61 mV

 

Thus, the membrane potential has hyperpolarized by 61 millivolts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When extracellular K⁺ concentration is reduced, the cell undergoes 61 millivolts hyperpolarization, as the loss of K⁺ leads to the inside of the cell becoming more negative.

choices.text: Mass immunization of school children with Vi polysaccharide vaccine
Construction of community water-treatment plants and promotion of household water boiling
Weekly administration of prophylactic chloramphenicol to high-risk adults
Distribution of personal insecticide-treated bed nets to all households

questions.text: In a region with high endemic typhoid fever, public health officials are designing a prevention program. Which of the following interventions will have the greatest impact on reducing typhoid incidence?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Construction of community water-treatment plants and promotion of household water boiling

 

  • Typhoid fever is transmitted primarily via the fecal–oral route through contaminated water and food. 
  • Improving sanitation—such as safe disposal of feces, filtering or treating community water supplies, and encouraging families to boil or chlorinate drinking water—interrupts the main transmission pathway.
  • These environmental and behavioral measures yield the largest and most sustained reduction in typhoid incidence, far surpassing the impact of any single biomedical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass immunization of school children with Vi polysaccharide vaccine: While vaccination provides individual protection, its coverage and duration are limited (the Vi vaccine requires boosters and does not induce strong community herd immunity). Alone, it cannot match the broad reach of improved water and sanitation.

 

Option C. Weekly administration of prophylactic chloramphenicol to high-risk adults: Antibiotic prophylaxis risks resistance, adverse effects, and is not a sustainable public-health strategy. It treats individuals rather than addressing environmental sources.

 

Option D. Distribution of personal insecticide-treated bed nets to all households: Bed nets control vector-borne diseases like malaria, not typhoid, which is not spread by mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For typhoid control, prioritize safe water and proper fecal disposal over mass vaccination or chemoprophylaxis—addressing the root source of infection delivers the greatest epidemiologic benefit.

choices.text: Phase zero clinical trials are typically conducted in animal models to assess the safety and efficacy of a new drug.
Phase zero clinical trials are comprehensive studies designed to provide conclusive data on the safety and efficacy of a new drug.
Phase zero clinical trials primarily focus on pharmacokinetics, particularly on the movement of the drug in the human body.
Phase zero clinical trials are also known as therapeutic trials and aim to cure or mitigate symptoms of the disease in question.

questions.text: A 29-year-old researcher is studying a novel antiviral drug that has shown promise in in-vitro studies. The researcher is in the process of planning the clinical development of the drug. She explains to her team that the next step involves a phase zero clinical trial, which will be crucial in determining whether to move on to phase I trials. The team is confused, as they are not familiar with phase zero clinical trials. Which of the following statements is true regarding phase zero clinical trials, that would help the team understand its significance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phase zero clinical trials primarily focus on pharmacokinetics, particularly on the movement and metabolism of the drug in the human body.

 

  • Phase zero clinical trials primarily focus on pharmacokinetics, particularly on the movement of the drug in the human body. 
  • The main aim of phase zero trials is to gather preliminary data on pharmacokinetics and assess whether the drug behaves in humans as it does in preclinical models.
  • Therefore, the statement that would best help the team understand the significance of phase zero trials is that they primarily focus on pharmacokinetics and provide initial human data on the movement and metabolism of the drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phase zero clinical trials are typically conducted in animal models to assess the safety and efficacy of a new drug: This statement is incorrect. Phase zero clinical trials are human trials that precede phase I trials. They are not animal studies.

 

Option B. Phase zero clinical trials are comprehensive studies designed to provide conclusive data on the safety and efficacy of a new drug: This is incorrect. Phase zero trials are not designed to provide comprehensive data on safety and efficacy but are focused on pharmacokinetics and perhaps some initial pharmacodynamic data.

 

Option D. Phase zero clinical trials are also known as therapeutic trials and aim to cure or mitigate symptoms of the disease in question: This is incorrect. Phase zero trials are exploratory trials that precede phase I trials; they are not focused on therapeutic outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase 0 trials are exploratory human PK studies—they use microdoses to rapidly assess whether a drug’s absorption and metabolism in humans justify advancing to full safety and efficacy testing.

choices.text: 5 grams of 50% magnesium sulfate intramuscularly in alternate buttocks every 4 hours until 24 hours after delivery or the last seizure
5 grams of 50% magnesium sulfate intramuscularly in the same buttock every 6 hours until 24 hours after delivery
4 grams of 50% magnesium sulfate intramuscularly every 4 hours until onset of labor
Continuous intravenous infusion of magnesium sulfate at 1 gram per hour until 24 hours postpartum

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the maintenance dosing protocol according to the Pritchard regimen for magnesium sulfate administration?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 grams of 50% magnesium sulfate intramuscularly in alternate buttocks every 4 hours until 24 hours after delivery or the last seizure

 

  • The Pritchard regimen is a well-established protocol for the prevention and treatment of seizures in women with eclampsia. 
  • It involves:
  • Loading dose:
    • 4 grams of 20% magnesium sulfate intravenously over 5–10 minutes
    • Followed by 5 grams of 50% magnesium sulfate intramuscularly into each buttock
  • Maintenance dose:
    • 5 grams of 50% magnesium sulfate intramuscularly every 4 hours
    • Administered in alternate buttocks to avoid local irritation
    • Continued for 24 hours after delivery or the last seizure, whichever is later
  • This regimen ensures therapeutic levels of magnesium sulfate are maintained to prevent recurrence of seizures in eclamptic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pritchard regimen for eclampsia involves a maintenance dose of 5 grams of 50% magnesium sulfate given intramuscularly into alternate buttocks every 4 hours until 24 hours after delivery or the last seizure, whichever is later.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect option with regards to Resting membrane potential in different cells:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Smooth muscle: −8 to −12 mV

 

  • Smooth muscle cells have a resting membrane potential closer to −50 to −60 mV, not −8 to −12 mV. 
  • The −8 to −12 mV range is typically seen in red blood cells (RBCs), not smooth muscle cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurons: −60 to −70 mV: This is correct. Neurons typically have a resting membrane potential of −60 to −70 mV. This value is maintained by the selective permeability of the membrane to potassium and the action of the sodium-potassium pump.

 

Option B. Skeletal muscle: −85 to −95 mV: This is correct. Skeletal muscle cells generally have a more negative resting membrane potential, around −85 to −95 mV. This is due to the differences in ion channels and permeability compared to neurons.

 

Option C. Hair cells (cochlea): −15 to −40 mV: This is correct. The inner hair cells of the cochlea have a resting membrane potential of −15 to −40 mV, which is much less negative than other cells due to their specialized function in hearing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smooth muscle cells typically have a resting membrane potential of −50 to −60 mV, while −8 to −12 mV is characteristic of red blood cells.

choices.text: Culture of sputum on Sabouraud dextrose agar

questions.text: A 35-year-old male coffee farmer in Brazil develops a productive cough, weight loss, and mucocutaneous ulcers on the oropharynx. Sputum cytology shows multiple narrow-based budding yeasts arranged radially around a central mother cell (“pilot wheel”). Which laboratory test provides the fastest, least-invasive confirmation of active infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serologic immunodiffusion for gp43 antibodies

 

  • Serologic immunodiffusion for gp43 antibodies detects precipitins against the 43-kDa glycoprotein antigen of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. 
  • Results are available within 1–2 days, correlate with disease activity, and require only a blood sample—making it the fastest, least invasive way to confirm active infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Culture of sputum on Sabouraud dextrose agar: Highly specific but requires 4-6 weeks for mold growth at 25°C and subsequent yeast conversion at 37°C.

 

Option C. Direct immunofluorescence on mucosal biopsy: Sensitive but invasive (requires tissue), specialized, and not widely available.

 

Option D. Skin test with paracoccidioidin: Indicates prior sensitization (cell-mediated immunity) rather than active disease; may be negative in severe cases. It is type IV hypersensitivity reaction (delayed)

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected paracoccidioidomycosis with characteristic “pilot-wheel” yeast on microscopy, gp43 immunodiffusion is the quickest way to confirm active disease.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and peripheral artery disease presents with a 2-month history of cough while eating, difficulty initiating swallowing, and recent dysarthria affecting her speech clarity. She denies weight loss, chest pain, or choking on solids, and her symptoms began abruptly after a family gathering. Her examination shows no other focal neurological deficits, but her BP is 160/95 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stroke

 

  • Sudden-onset dysphagia, dysarthria, and cough while eating in an elderly patient with vascular risk factors (diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia) suggest a neurologic etiology, likely a stroke affecting the brainstem or cortex.
  • Stroke can impair swallowing and speech muscles, leading to these symptoms.
  • The abrupt onset and absence of chronic esophageal symptoms support a neurological cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achalasia: Causes chronic dysphagia for solids and liquids, not dysarthria.

 

Option B. Esophageal webs: Cause dysphagia for solids, not dysarthria or cough.

 

Option D. Zenker diverticulum: Causes regurgitation and dysphagia but not dysarthria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stroke is a common cause of sudden dysphagia and dysarthria in patients with vascular risk factors.
  • Neurologic evaluation, including imaging, is critical for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with metastatic ovarian-carcinoma–associated melanoma receives high-dose ifosfamide prior to autologous stem-cell transplant. Within days he develops gross hematuria and bladder pain. Which co-therapy would best prevent this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mesna

 

  • It is haemorrhagic cystitis 
  • Ifosfamide is an alkylating agent whose urinary excretion yields the urotoxic metabolite acrolein. 
  • Mesna (2-mercaptoethane sulfonate) provides a free thiol that conjugates acrolein in the bladder lumen, preventing mucosal injury and hemorrhagic cystitis without interfering with antitumor activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amifostine: A cytoprotective thiol used to reduce cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity and xerostomia with radiation; does not reliably detoxify acrolein.

 

Option C. N-acetylcysteine: Replenishes glutathione in hepatocytes but lacks sufficient bladder concentration to neutralize acrolein.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Folinic acid “rescue” for high-dose methotrexate therapy; has no role in preventing alkylator-induced cystitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering high-dose nitrogen mustards (e.g., melphalan, cyclophosphamide), co-administer mesna to neutralize acrolein and protect the bladder mucosa from hemorrhagic cystitis.

choices.text: 5 is the only incorrect one

questions.text:
Which of the following sonographic findings is/are incorrect about Placenta Accreta Spectrum (PAS)?

 

  1. Placental lacunae
  2. Thinning of the retroplacental myometrium
  3. Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosal interface
  4. Bridging vessels from the placenta to the bladder-serosal interface
  5. Thickened retroplacental myometrium (>5 mm) and smooth, undistorted uterine contour
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5 is the only incorrect one

 

Statement 5. Thickened retroplacental myometrium (>5 mm) and smooth, undistorted uterine contour: Incorrect.

 

  • This is NOT characteristic of PAS.
  • PAS is associated with thinning, not thickening, of the retroplacental myometrium.
  • Furthermore, the uterus often shows a bulge or distortion of its normal contour due to abnormal placental invasion.
  • Therefore, a thickened myometrium with a smooth, undistorted contour suggests a normal placental attachment, not PAS.

 

Correct Statements: 

 

Statement 1. Placental lacunae: Correct. These are multiple irregular vascular spaces seen within the placenta, giving a “Swiss cheese” or “moth-eaten” appearance on ultrasound. This is a typical finding of PAS and is considered a characteristic feature.

 

Statement 2. Thinning of the retroplacental myometrium: Correct. Thinning (often <1 mm) of the myometrium underlying the placenta is a well-recognized sonographic sign of PAS. It occurs due to abnormal trophoblastic invasion into the myometrium.

 

Statement 3. Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosal interface: Correct. The loss of the normal hypoechoic boundary between the uterus and bladder on ultrasound is a key feature in severe forms of PAS, especially placenta percreta.

 

Statement 4. Bridging vessels from the placenta to the bladder-serosal interface: Correct. Bridging vessels crossing from the placenta into adjacent structures, especially the bladder, seen on Doppler imaging, are a hallmark of invasive placental disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta Accreta Spectrum is diagnosed by ultrasound features such as placental lacunae, thinning of the retroplacental myometrium, disruption of the bladder-uterine interface, and bridging vessels; a thickened retroplacental myometrium with a smooth uterine contour is not characteristic of PAS and is considered incorrect.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker presents with painless hematuria. Further investigation reveals bladder cancer extending up to the muscle layer. What should be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radical cystectomy

 

  • Radical cystectomy is the standard treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer. 
  • It involves the removal of the bladder and surrounding tissues/organs (such as prostate in men and uterus in women), and it provides the best chance for long-term survival and disease control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravesical BCG: Intravesical BCG is typically used for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC). It is effective in reducing recurrence and progression of superficial bladder cancer but is not adequate for muscle-invasive disease.

 

Option B. Systemic chemotherapy: While systemic chemotherapy can be used as part of the treatment plan, especially in a neoadjuvant setting (before surgery) or for metastatic disease, it is not the primary treatment of choice for muscle-invasive bladder cancer without metastatic disease.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy: Radiotherapy can be an option for patients who are not candidates for surgery, but it is typically not the first-line treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer when the patient is otherwise healthy and a surgical candidate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For muscle-invasive bladder cancer, the treatment of choice is radical cystectomy, which involves the removal of the bladder and surrounding tissues to achieve the best long-term outcomes. 
  • Painless hematuria in a smoker is highly suggestive of bladder carcinoma and should prompt thorough evaluation.

questions.text: According to 8th AJCC classification of colorectal cancers, tumor deposits in the visceral peritoneum and serosal breach is staged as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T4a

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to 8th AJCC classification of colorectal cancers, tumor deposits in the visceral peritoneum and serosal breach is staged as T4a.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman, 8 months post-allogeneic stem cell transplant for leukemia, presents with a 5-day history of increased cough, shortness of breath, and low-grade fever. She is on steroids for graft-versus-host disease and TMP-SMX for Pneumocystis prophylaxis. A CT chest is done and shown below. She denies recent travel or sick contacts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis

 

  • The CT chest shows multiple pulmonary nodules with ground-glass opacities (“halo sign”), suggests invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA), common in immunocompromised patients post-transplant.
  • Steroid use and immunosuppression increase IPA risk, and the halo sign is a classic radiologic finding.
  • Prompt antifungal therapy is critical to prevent progression in this high-risk patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiolitis obliterans: Causes chronic cough and airflow obstruction, not nodules or halo sign.

 

Option C. MRSA pneumonia: Lacks the halo sign and it is more common in HAP and post-influenza. 

 

Option D. Respiratory syncytial virus infection: RSV causes bronchiolitis, not nodules or halo sign. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IPA is suspected in immunocompromised patients with pulmonary nodules and halo sign on CT.
  • Elevated galactomannan supports the diagnosis, requiring urgent antifungal therapy.

choices.text: Fish contains enough carbs to prevent ketosis, so avoid it.
Fish is essentially carbohydrate-free—an excellent choice on a ketogenic diet.
Fish provides moderate carbohydrates in the form of glycogen—limit to small portions.
Fish contains hidden sugars that can spike blood glucose despite low visible carbs.

questions.text: A patient on a carbohydrate-restricted diet wonders if eating fish will break ketosis. Which statement is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fish is essentially carbohydrate-free—an excellent choice on a ketogenic diet.

 

  • Ketosis is maintained when dietary carbohydrate intake is kept very low (typically <20–50 g per day), forcing the body to burn fats for fuel and produce ketone bodies.
  • Fish, including fatty species (salmon, mackerel) and lean varieties (cod, tilapia), contain virtually 0 g of carbohydrates per standard serving. 
  • Their macronutrient profile is almost entirely protein and fat.
  • Because fish lacks appreciable carbs, consuming it does not raise blood glucose or insulin levels enough to interrupt ketosis—making it an ideal protein source on a ketogenic regimen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fish contains enough carbs to prevent ketosis, so avoid it: Fish has negligible carbohydrate content (<1 g per 100 g), so it cannot provide enough carbs to halt ketosis.

 

Option C. Fish provides moderate carbohydrates in the form of glycogen—limit to small portions: Although fish muscle contains some glycogen in living tissue, post-harvest glycogen levels drop rapidly, and laboratory analyses show virtually no residual carb content in edible portions.

 

Option D. Fish contains hidden sugars that can spike blood glucose despite low visible carbs: Fish does not contain sugars or hidden carbohydrates; concerns about “hidden carbs” apply to processed foods with added sugars or starches, not to fresh fish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On a ketogenic or carbohydrate-restricted diet, fish is one of the safest protein sources—it offers essential nutrients and fats without carbohydrate content that could interrupt ketosis.

questions.text: In a 32-year-old male, during the clinical examination, his blood pressure was found to be 130/80 mm Hg, heart rate was 60/min, and respiratory rate was 16/min. What would be the stroke volume in this patient, if his cardiac output was 4.2 L?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 70 mL

 

The formula for Cardiac Output (CO) is:

 

 

Given:

 

  • Cardiac output (CO) = 4.2 L/min = 4200 mL/min
  • Heart rate (HR) = 60 beats/min

 

To find Stroke Volume (SV), rearrange the formula:

 

 

Substitute the given values:

 

The stroke volume is 70 mL per beat 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped by the heart per beat. In this case, with a cardiac output of 4.2 L/min and a heart rate of 60 beats/min, the stroke volume is 70 mL per beat.

choices.text: Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) – Type II hypersensitivity reaction
Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction – Type I cytokine-mediated reaction
Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction – Type II hypersensitivity reaction
Anaphylaxis due to IgA deficiency – Type I hypersensitivity reaction

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 6 hours after a road traffic accident. On arrival, his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate is 110/min, and SpO₂ is 92%. He receives a unit of blood for stabilization. A few hours later, he develops fever, tachypnea, hypoxia, and starts bleeding from intravenous and nasogastric tube sites. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction – Type II hypersensitivity reaction

 

  • This patient developed signs of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) following a mismatched blood transfusion, including:
    • Fever and chills
    • Hemoglobinuria
    • Bleeding (may occur secondary to DIC)
    • Hypotension and hypoxia
  • AHTR is a classic Type II hypersensitivity reaction, in which preformed anti-ABO antibodies bind to donor red cells and cause complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis. 
  • This may progress to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) in severe cases, explaining the bleeding and hypoxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI) – Type II hypersensitivity reaction: Caused by anti-leukocyte antibodies in donor plasma, leading to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema and hypoxia. It does not cause hemolysis or bleeding.

 

Option B. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction – Type I cytokine-mediated reaction: Typically presents with mild fever and chills without hemolysis or bleeding. It is caused by cytokines in stored blood, not antibodies or hemolysis.

 

Option D. Anaphylaxis due to IgA deficiency – Type I hypersensitivity reaction: Characterized by hypotension, urticaria, bronchospasm, and shock in patients with IgA deficiency. It does not present with hemolysis or DIC-like features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction is a Type II hypersensitivity reaction caused by preformed antibodies (e.g., anti-ABO) leading to intravascular hemolysis, often presenting with fever, hypotension, hemoglobinuria, and in severe cases, DIC and bleeding.

choices.text: Deposition of mutated transthyretin in multiple organs
Wild-type transthyretin deposition with predominant cardiac involvement
Deposition of amyloid light chains due to plasma cell dyscrasia

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue and exertional dyspnea. He has no significant history of hypertension or ischemic heart disease. Echocardiography reveals concentric left ventricular hypertrophy with diastolic dysfunction. Endomyocardial biopsy shows amyloid deposits, and mass spectrometry confirms transthyretin (TTR) protein. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wild-type transthyretin deposition with predominant cardiac involvement

 

  • This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with Systemic Senile Amyloidosis, also referred to as wild-type ATTR amyloidosis. 
  • It commonly presents in elderly patients with cardiac involvement, particularly diastolic heart failure due to restrictive cardiomyopathy. 
  • The amyloid is derived from wild-type transthyretin (TTR) and is not associated with a genetic mutation (as seen in hereditary ATTR amyloidosis).
  • Key features:
    • Age >65 years
    • Wild-type transthyretin is deposited (not mutated)
    • Cardiac involvement is common and may mimic hypertensive or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
    • Confirmed by biopsy and mass spectrometry

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deposition of mutated transthyretin in multiple organs: This describes hereditary ATTR amyloidosis, not senile systemic amyloidosis, which involves wild-type TTR.

 

Option C. Deposition of amyloid light chains due to plasma cell dyscrasia: This refers to AL amyloidosis, which is associated with multiple myeloma and presents with systemic involvement, not limited to the heart.

 

Option D. β2-microglobulin accumulation associated with dialysis-related amyloidosis: This is seen in patients on long-term dialysis and affects joints and bones, not typically the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic Senile Amyloidosis (ATTR wild-type) is caused by deposition of wild-type transthyretin, predominantly in the heart, leading to restrictive cardiomyopathy in the elderly.

questions.text: In the Lineweaver–Burk plot below, the inhibitor increases the slope without changing the y-intercept (1/Vₘₐₓ). Which type of inhibition does this represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibition

 

  • On a Lineweaver–Burk (double-reciprocal) plot:
    • Y-intercept (1/Vₘₐₓ) remains the same for both curves, indicating that Vₘₐₓ is unchanged by the inhibitor.
    • X-intercept (–1/Kₘ) shifts closer to zero (less negative) when the inhibitor is present, indicating an increased apparent Kₘ (lower affinity for substrate).
    • The slope of the red line (with inhibitor) is steeper than the blue (no inhibitor), reflecting a larger Kₘ/Vₘₐₓ ratio.
  • These features—unchanged Vₘₐₓ with increased Kₘ—are classic for competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor competes with substrate for the active site but can be overcome by high substrate concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allosteric inhibition: Allosteric inhibitors bind at regulatory sites and often decrease Vₘₐₓ (shifting the y-intercept upward) and can alter cooperativity. They do not leave Vₘₐₓ unchanged with only Kₘ changes.

 

Option C. Noncompetitive inhibition: Noncompetitive inhibitors bind equally to the free enzyme and enzyme–substrate complex, decreasing Vₘₐₓ (higher 1/Vₘₐₓ) while Kₘ remains unchanged (x-intercept constant). The depicted plot shows a change in x-intercept, so it is not noncompetitive.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibition: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme–substrate complex, lowering both Vₘₐₓ and apparent Kₘ. On the plot, both y- and x-intercepts would shift in parallel lines. That pattern is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition increases apparent Kₘ without changing Vₘₐₓ; on a Lineweaver–Burk plot, this appears as two lines intersecting at the same y-intercept but with different slopes and x-intercepts.

questions.text: In a patient at risk of re-feeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia 

 

  • Unlike hypokalemia, hyperkalemia is not typically associated with re-feeding syndrome.
  • Instead, rapid re-feeding may lead to increased insulin secretion, which drives potassium into cells, potentially causing hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: Re-feeding syndrome can lead to hypokalemia due to increased cellular uptake of potassium during the anabolic phase, especially if there is concomitant insulin administration.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Re-feeding syndrome can cause hypocalcemia due to decreased parathyroid hormone secretion and subsequent impaired bone resorption, leading to low serum calcium levels.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: Re-feeding syndrome is characterized by rapid shifts of phosphate into cells during the anabolic phase, leading to hypophosphatemia, which can manifest clinically as weakness, respiratory failure, and arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In patients at risk of re-feeding syndrome, electrolyte imbalances such as hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia are commonly observed, while hyperkalemia is typically not associated with this condition.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of events occurring after the P wave in an ECG: 

 

  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-2-4-3

 

  • The P wave on an ECG represents atrial depolarization, which leads to atrial contraction. 
  • After the P wave, the following sequence of events occurs in a specific order:

 

1. a wave in JVP: The “a” wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) is caused by atrial contraction, which immediately follows the P wave on the ECG. This event represents the mechanical contraction of the atria after depolarization.

 

2. First heart sound (S1): The first heart sound (S1) is heard when the atrioventricular valves (tricuspid and mitral valves) close at the beginning of ventricular contraction (systole). This follows the a wave and is a key indicator of the start of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

 

4. T wave in ECG: The T wave represents ventricular repolarization, which leads to ventricular relaxation. This is an electrical event that occurs before the mechanical relaxation of the ventricles. Repolarization precedes the mechanical relaxation process, allowing the ventricles to begin filling.

 

3. Rapid filling of ventricles: After repolarization (T wave), the ventricles undergo rapid filling during the early phase of diastole as the atrioventricular valves reopen. This mechanical event occurs after the electrical repolarization (T wave).

 

 

Sequence breakdown:

 

  • P wave triggers atrial contraction, which is reflected as the a wave in the JVP.
  • The first heart sound (S1) occurs as the AV valves close due to increased ventricular pressure.
  • The T wave marks ventricular repolarization, signaling the beginning of relaxation.
  • Finally, the rapid filling of ventricles happens after relaxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence following the P wave involves:

 

  1. Atrial contraction (a wave in JVP),
  2. First heart sound (AV valve closure),
  3. T wave (ventricular repolarization),
  4. Rapid ventricular filling.

questions.text: A 24y G4 presents to you for pre conceptional counselling. She gives a history of recurrent 2nd trimester losses and in the last pregnancy, a procedure was done at 14 weeks, despite which she still had an abortion at 18 weeks. Which of the following cervical cerclage procedures would be advised in this woman pre conceptionally as a prophylactic measure for cervical incompetence?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic cerclage

 

  • Cervical cerclage is a surgical procedure used to prevent preterm birth by reinforcing a weak or incompetent cervix.
  • Laparoscopic cerclage is a transabdominal cerclage technique performed before pregnancy or in the first trimester, especially in women with a history of cervical insufficiency where transvaginal cerclage has failed or is not feasible.
  • It is usually placed pre-pregnancy in high-risk women and remains in situ during subsequent pregnancies, avoiding repeated procedures.
  • This approach allows precise placement at the cervico-isthmic junction and is typically done before conception in women with recurrent pregnancy loss due to cervical incompetence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lash and Lash cerclage: Incorrect. The Lash and Lash stitch is a transvaginal stitch placed before pregnancy for cervical insufficiency. However, it is not routinely performed. 

 

Option B. Benson and Durfee cerclage: Incorrect. Benson and Durfee cerclage refer to a transvaginal cerclage placed during pregnancy. It is not indicated in nonpregnant women.

 

Option C. Wurm’s cerclage: Incorrect. Wurm’s cerclage is another type of transvaginal cerclage performed in pregnancy, not as a prophylactic measure in the nonpregnant state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic cerclage is a transabdominal cerclage procedure typically performed in nonpregnant women with cervical insufficiency, particularly when transvaginal cerclage has failed or is contraindicated.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents after a 24-hour fast. Which of the following enzyme activities would you expect to be reduced in hepatocytes during fasting?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetyl-CoA carboxylase

 

  • In the fasting state, the body shifts from storing nutrients toward mobilizing and utilizing energy reserves.
  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACC) catalyzes the first committed step in fatty acid synthesis, converting acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA.
  • Fasting decreases insulin and increases glucagon, leading to phosphorylation and inhibition of ACC by AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and protein kinase A (PKA).
  • As a result, fatty acid synthesis is shut off when energy is needed elsewhere.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hormone-sensitive lipase: Fasting activates HSL in adipose tissue via PKA-mediated phosphorylation, promoting lipolysis to release free fatty acids.

 

Option B. Glycogen phosphorylase: Fasting activates this enzyme in liver (via glucagon and AMP), driving glycogen breakdown to maintain blood glucose.

 

Option D. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I): Fasting increases CPS I activity (via N-acetylglutamate) to enhance the urea cycle for disposal of amino-nitrogen from gluconeogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fasting inhibits acetyl-CoA carboxylase to block fatty acid synthesis, while it activates catabolic enzymes such as hormone-sensitive lipase, glycogen phosphorylase, and CPS I.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Damage to the common peroneal nerve at the neck of fibula causes foot drop.


Reason (R): The common peroneal nerve supplies the plantar flexors of the foot.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is true, but R is false

 

  • The common peroneal nerve wraps around the neck of the fibula, making it vulnerable to injury. 
  • It innervates the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, which are responsible for dorsiflexion and eversion. 
  • Injury leads to foot drop.
    Plantarflexion is done by the posterior compartment (tibial nerve)—so the reason is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common peroneal nerve wraps around the neck of the fibula, making it vulnerable to injury. It innervates the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, which are responsible for dorsiflexion and eversion. Injury leads to foot drop.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, arthralgia, and a purpuric rash over his lower extremities. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria and mild proteinuria. A skin biopsy is performed. Which of the following immunoglobulins is most likely to be deposited in the affected tissues?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgA

 

  • The clinical presentation is characteristic of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), now called IgA vasculitis. 
  • It is the most common systemic vasculitis in children. 
  • Key features include:
    • Palpable purpura (usually on the lower limbs and buttocks)
    • Arthralgia or arthritis
    • Abdominal pain
    • Renal involvement (hematuria, proteinuria)
  • Biopsy (typically of skin or kidney) reveals leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA-dominant immune deposits, especially in the mesangium of the glomeruli in renal involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM: IgM is not the characteristic immunoglobulin in HSP. Though it may be elevated in certain infections, it is not the deposited immunoglobulin in this vasculitis.

 

Option B. IgD: IgD is primarily involved in naive B-cell receptor signaling. It does not play a role in tissue deposition in vasculitic syndromes.

 

Option C. IgG: IgG is involved in many other immune-mediated diseases (e.g., Goodpasture syndrome, lupus nephritis), but not in HSP where IgA predominates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis) is characterized by deposition of IgA immune complexes in small vessels, particularly affecting the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys.

questions.text: A neonate born with failure to pass a Ryles tube, external ear deformities, and eye coloboma is suspected to have a genetic syndrome. What other feature would most likely be present?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Genital anomalies

 

  • CHARGE Syndrome is characterized by coloboma, heart defects, atresia choanae, growth retardation, genital anomalies, and ear abnormalities.
  • CHARGE syndrome:
    • Coloboma
    • Heart defects
    • Atresia of the choanae
    • Retardation of growth and development
    • Genital and urinary abnormalities
    • Ear abnormalities

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal agenesis: Characteristic of Potter Syndrome.

 

Option B. Pulmonary hypoplasia: Seen in Potter Syndrome, not CHARGE Syndrome.

 

Option D. Holoprosencephaly: Associated with Trisomy 13 or other midline defects, not CHARGE Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital anomalies are a hallmark feature of Charge Syndrome, along with choanal atresia, coloboma, and ear abnormalities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came to the physician with complaints of heartburn and regurgitation of food. The symptoms have been present for 3 years but have worsened for the past 3 months. She took over-the-counter medications but the symptoms did not subside. Upper GI endoscopy shows the following presentation. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barrett’s esophagus

 

  • The image is an upper GI endoscopic image of Barrett's esophagus.
  • It shows tongue shaped projections in the surrounding mucosa. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schatzki ring: A Schatzki ring is a narrowing of the lower esophagus that can cause difficulty swallowing (dysphagia). It typically appears as a thin ring on endoscopy and wouldn't show the patchy red mucosa that is indicative of Barrett’s esophagus. The symptoms of heartburn and regurgitation are less specific to a Schatzki ring unless there is accompanying esophagitis.

 

Option C. Eosinophilic esophagitis: This is an allergic/immune condition that results in a buildup of eosinophils in the esophagus, leading to esophageal dysfunction. On endoscopy, it can show multiple rings, white specks of eosinophilic infiltrates, and longitudinal furrows, none of which are visible in the provided image.

 

Option D. Pseudo-achalasia: This refers to symptoms of achalasia due to carcinoma of esophagus. It would not cause the visible changes seen in Barrett’s esophagus on endoscopy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Barrett’s esophagus is the columnar metaplasia of lower esophagus.

choices.text: Anemia is a cause of symmetrical IUGR
It is a marker of chronic hypoxia in neonates.
It is elevated in neonates with asymmetrical IUGR.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ponderal index is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is calculated as (Weight/Height3) × 100.

 

Ponderal index is used to calculate intrauterine growth restriction

 

Ponderal index is a measure of neonatal nutritional status and is calculated as (Weight/Height3) × 100.

 

Weight in gram and height in cm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anemia is a cause of symmetrical IUGR: Anemia is a cause of asymmetrical IUGR. The causes of symmetrical IUGR is TORCH infections or genetic defects.

 

Option C. It is a marker of chronic hypoxia in neonates: Ponderal index reflects nutritional status, not hypoxia.

 

Option D. It is elevated in neonates with asymmetrical IUGR: It is reduced in asymmetrical IUGR due to disproportionate weight loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The ponderal index is a nutritional assessment tool calculated as (Weight/Height3) × 100, with reduced values indicating asymmetrical IUGR.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding common tinea infections?

 

  1. Corticosteroids may lead to atypical presentation in tinea infections, termed Tinea incognito.
  2. Tinea pedis, or athlete’s foot, is most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum.
  3. Tinea cruris, commonly known as Dhobi's itch, typically affects the nail folds.
  4. Tinea unguium refers to fungal infection of the nail plate but not the nail folds.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only statements 1, 2 and 4 are true

 

Statement 1. Corticosteroids may lead to atypical presentation in tinea infections, termed Tinea incognito: Is true. Corticosteroids can suppress local immunity and alter the appearance of tinea infections, leading to the atypical form known as Tinea incognito.

 

Statement 2. Tinea pedis, or athlete’s foot, is most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum: Is true. Tinea pedis, or athlete’s foot, is most frequently caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum.

 

Statement 4. Tinea unguium refers to fungal infection of the nail plate but not the nail folds: Is true. Tinea unguium (onychomycosis) is a fungal infection of the nail plate itself and does not involve the surrounding nail folds.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Tinea cruris, commonly known as Dhobi's itch, typically affects the nail folds: Is false. Tinea cruris, or Dhobi’s itch, affects the groin region—not the nail folds. The term “Dhobi's itch” is commonly used in South Asian countries to describe this condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tinea unguium affects the nail plate, not the surrounding structures like nail folds. 
  • Correct identification of dermatophyte infections based on anatomical distribution and common pathogens is essential for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

choices.text: Repeat fetal scalp blood pH measurement within 30 minutes
Administer maternal left lateral positioning and intravenous fluids

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida in active labor reaches 5 cm cervical dilation. Cardiotocography (CTG) monitoring shows recurrent late decelerations. A fetal scalp blood sample is obtained, showing a pH of 7.19. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate cesarean section

 

  • The detection of late decelerations on CTG is an alarming sign of uteroplacental insufficiency, leading to fetal hypoxia and acidosis.
  • Fetal scalp blood pH analysis is used to assess fetal acid-base status during labor:
    • Normal pH (> 7.25): Indicates no immediate concern — continue monitoring.
    • Borderline pH (7.21–7.24): Repeat fetal scalp pH within 30 minutes to assess trends.
    • Abnormal pH (≤ 7.20): Indicates fetal acidosis, requiring immediate delivery to prevent hypoxic injury.
  • In this case, the fetal scalp blood pH is 7.19, which is below the critical threshold of 7.20, signifying fetal acidosis. 
  • The presence of recurrent late decelerations combined with pH ≤ 7.20 mandates immediate cesarean section to avoid perinatal complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Forceps-assisted vaginal delivery: Incorrect. Forceps delivery is only indicated when the cervix is fully dilated and fetal head is low enough in the birth canal. In this scenario, the cervix is 5 cm dilated, making operative vaginal delivery inappropriate and unsafe.

 

Option C. Repeat fetal scalp blood pH measurement within 30 minutes: Incorrect. This option is correct only when the pH is borderline (7.21–7.24). However, since the pH is 7.19, this indicates established fetal acidosis, which requires immediate delivery, not a repeat test.

 

Option D. Administer maternal left lateral positioning and intravenous fluids: Incorrect. While maternal repositioning and hydration may help improve uteroplacental perfusion in cases of mild decelerations, they are not sufficient nor definitive when fetal scalp pH indicates acidosis (≤ 7.20). Immediate delivery is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fetal scalp pH of ≤ 7.20 in the presence of late decelerations during labor is indicative of fetal acidosis and mandates immediate cesarean section to prevent hypoxic injury.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male agricultural worker presents with a single, nontender lesion on his forearm. The lesion began as a small papule a few weeks ago and has gradually enlarged, now showing a central ulceration with a crusted surface surrounded by an erythematous rim. The patient recalls traveling to a rural area endemic for sandfly bites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leishmaniasis

 

  • The description of a central ulcer with a crusted appearance and an erythematous border corresponds to the "Volcano sign", a classic feature of Old World cutaneous leishmaniasis.
  • This condition occurs after a bite from an infected sandfly and is endemic in certain rural areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leprosy: Leprosy lesions are typically hypopigmented or erythematous macules/plaques with loss of sensation. Central ulceration is uncommon.

 

Option C. Lupus vulgaris: Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, presents as a chronic plaque with reddish-brown “apple-jelly nodules” on diascopy, not as an ulcerated lesion with an erythematous rim.

 

Option D. DLE: DLE (Discoid Lupus Erythematosus) lesions are erythematous plaques with adherent scales, atrophy, and scarring, but they lack the “Volcano sign.”

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "Volcano sign" is a classic descriptor for cutaneous leishmaniasis. It appears as a central ulcer with a crusted surface surrounded by an erythematous rim, resembling a volcanic crater.
  • This feature helps differentiate leishmaniasis from other dermatological conditions.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with a history of heart failure and atrial fibrillation has been taking digoxin for several months. He was recently started on a new medication for hypertension. He presents to the clinic with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and visual disturbances. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

  • Symptoms of digoxin toxicity include nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and visual disturbances. 
  • Other symptoms can include dizziness, confusion, and changes in heart rate or rhythm.
  • Hydrochlorothiazide can cause electrolyte abnormalities such as hypokalemia, which can increase the risk of digoxin toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: An antihyperglycemic that reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis and improves insulin sensitivity. It has no effect on potassium homeostasis or digoxin metabolism.

 

Option B. Lisinopril: An ACE inhibitor that can cause mild hyperkalemia by reducing aldosterone—this would protect against, not precipitate, digoxin toxicity.

 

Option C. Amlodipine: A dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker; it does not alter potassium levels or digoxin clearance and is not linked to digoxin toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient on digoxin develops toxicity signs after starting a new medication, check for hypokalemia-inducing agents—thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide are common culprits. 
  • Always monitor electrolytes closely.

 

Note – Digoxin overdose caused by – Quinidine, Verapamil, Amiodarone, Thiazides and Thromycin

choices.text: Shift IMI to biweekly “pulse” rounds instead of monthly
Expand the target age up to 5 years for all antigens, not only measles
Increase social mobilization to reduce vaccine hesitancy
Replace vaccination-on-demand with fixed-site delivery only

questions.text: A surveillance report finds that in areas where more than three consecutive routine immunization sessions were missed, measles outbreaks continue to occur despite ongoing Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) rounds. Which strategic adjustment would most strengthen IMI’s impact in these pockets?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase social mobilization to reduce vaccine hesitancy

 

  • Areas that miss multiple sessions often suffer not only from access gaps but also from community resistance or distrust—vaccine hesitancy. 
  • Merely increasing the frequency of campaigns (Option A) or broadening age groups (Option B) without addressing the underlying reluctance will leave many children unvaccinated. 
  • Vaccination-on-demand (Option D) ensures availability but does nothing to overcome fears or misinformation.
  • By intensifying social mobilization—engaging local leaders, conducting targeted awareness campaigns, and deploying community health volunteers to address concerns—IMI can convert hesitant families into willing participants, thereby closing the remaining coverage gaps and preventing outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shift IMI to biweekly “pulse” rounds instead of monthly: More frequent campaigns may marginally increase contacts but also strain resources and may still falter if families refuse vaccines.

 

Option B. Expanding target age to 5 years for all antigens, not only measles: While capturing older missed children is beneficial, it doesn’t resolve the root cause of persistent non-uptake in under-2s.

 

Option D. Replace vaccination-on-demand with fixed-site delivery only: Removing on-demand flexibility would likely reduce access further, particularly for migratory or hard-to-reach populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Effective immunization drives must combine supply-side measures (availability, frequency) with demand-generation strategies (social mobilization) to overcome vaccine hesitancy in low-coverage pockets.
  • Closing immunization gaps in high-risk areas requires not just more vaccines, but strong community engagement to build trust, dispel myths, and motivate families to participate.

questions.text: Researchers note that countries with more physicians per capita tend to have higher cancer survival rates. They warn that simply training more doctors will improve an individual patient’s prognosis. This inference is most likely flawed because of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ecological fallacy

 

  • The ecological fallacy occurs when associations observed at the group level are incorrectly assumed to hold at the individual level.
  •  In this scenario, the observation—that countries with more doctors have better cancer survival—may reflect factors such as overall health infrastructure, screening programs, or socioeconomic status, rather than a direct effect of physician density on any one patient’s outcome. 
  • Extrapolating from the country‐level data to predict individual benefit commits the ecological fallacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lead‐time bias: Occurs when earlier detection (e.g., through screening) appears to increase survival time without truly delaying death. It does not explain a country‐level association between physician density and outcomes.

 

Option C. Information bias: Arises from systematic errors in measurement or classification of exposure or outcome. Here, data on physicians per capita and survival are unlikely to be misclassified in a way that explains the misleading inference.

 

Option D. Berkson’s bias: A selection bias seen in hospital‐based studies when patients with multiple conditions are more likely to be hospitalized. This does not apply to aggregated national statistics on doctors and survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beware the ecological fallacy, strong relationships seen when data are averaged across populations can be misleading if used to make predictions about individuals.
  •  Always seek individual-level data before drawing causal conclusions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with treatment-resistant schizophrenia is started on clozapine. After 4 weeks, his CBC reveals an absolute neutrophil count of 700/mm³. Which adverse effect is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agranulocytosis

 

  • Clozapine is reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia but is associated with a risk of agranulocytosis, a potentially life-threatening drop in neutrophil count. 
  • An absolute neutrophil count (ANC) <1000/mm³ is considered agranulocytosis. 
  • In this case, an ANC of 700/mm³ after 4 weeks of treatment strongly suggests clozapine-induced agranulocytosis, which requires immediate discontinuation of the drug and close hematologic monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leukemoid reaction: Involves marked elevation in white blood cell count, mimicking leukemia — not relevant here where WBC count is low.
 

Option B. Myelosuppression: A general term for bone marrow suppression affecting multiple cell lines. Although clozapine can cause this, the specific and critical drop in neutrophils points more precisely to agranulocytosis.
 

Option D. Aplastic anemia: Involves pancytopenia (low RBCs, WBCs, and platelets) and hypocellular bone marrow, not isolated neutropenia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the serum protein electrophoresis given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatic cirrhosis

 

  • The serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) pattern in the image shows:
  • A reduced albumin peak
  • Beta-gamma bridging: This is a key characteristic finding where the beta and gamma globulin fractions merge without a clear separation.
  • A broad-based gamma region elevation due to polyclonal gammopathy (chronic antigenic stimulation)
  • These findings are classic for hepatic cirrhosis, especially due to chronic liver disease from alcohol or viral hepatitis. 
  • The liver’s inability to synthesize albumin leads to hypoalbuminemia, while chronic inflammation increases polyclonal immunoglobulin production.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrotic syndrome: Typically shows a markedly reduced albumin band but increased alpha-2 globulin due to compensatory synthesis of proteins like α2-macroglobulin and ceruloplasmin. Gamma globulins are often low, not broad-based.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma: Shows a sharp monoclonal spike (M spike) in the gamma or beta region, not a broad-based elevation as seen here. Also, albumin may be relatively preserved.

 

Option D. Acute inflammation: Typically causes elevations in alpha-1 and alpha-2 regions, due to increased acute-phase reactants. Gamma globulin elevation is not prominent or diffuse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-gamma bridging on serum protein electrophoresis is a hallmark of hepatic cirrhosis, reflecting polyclonal gammopathy from chronic antigenic stimulation along with decreased albumin production.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of progressive visual loss is diagnosed with pseudoexfoliation glaucoma. On gonioscopic examination, dense pigmentation is observed anterior to Schwalbe’s line in the inferior quadrant of the angle. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sampaolesi’s line

 

  • Sampaolesi’s line refers to a pigmented line anterior to Schwalbe’s line seen on gonioscopy, commonly in the inferior angle. 
  • It is associated with excessive trabecular meshwork pigmentation, often due to:
    • Pseudoexfoliation glaucoma
    • Pigment dispersion glaucoma
    • Other secondary open-angle glaucomas
  • In pseudoexfoliation glaucoma, abnormal fibrillary material accumulates in the anterior segment, leading to trabecular blockage and elevated intraocular pressure. 
  • The increased pigment dispersion in this condition is what creates the Sampaolesi’s line.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haab’s striae: Incorrect. These are horizontal breaks in Descemet’s membrane, seen in congenital glaucoma, not angle pigmentation.

 

 

Option B. Axenfeld’s line: Incorrect. Refers to anteriorly displaced Schwalbe’s line associated with Axenfeld-Rieger anomaly, not pigment deposition.

 

 

Option D. Vogt’s line: Incorrect. Vogt’s striae are vertical lines in the deep corneal stroma seen in keratoconus, unrelated to angle structures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sampaolesi’s line is a pigmented line seen anterior to Schwalbe’s line on gonioscopy, classically associated with pseudoexfoliation and pigment dispersion syndromes.
  • It is an important clue for diagnosing secondary open-angle glaucomas.

choices.text: Inform the patient that effect of LASIK will last for only 7.5 years
The patient should have keratometry values between 30–40 D
The laser should ablate 25 µm per diopter of correction
At least 300 µm of stromal bed must remain post-procedure

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a stable refraction of –7.50 D in both eyes presents for LASIK evaluation. His central corneal thickness measures 520 µm, and you plan a 110 µm flap. Which of the following must be ensured before proceeding with LASIK to minimize the risk of postoperative ectasia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) At least 300 µm of stromal bed must remain post-procedure

 

  • The most critical safety parameter in LASIK is preserving an adequate residual stromal bed (RSB) after flap creation and laser ablation. 
  • Insufficient RSB predisposes the cornea to biomechanical weakening and postoperative ectasia.
  • Flap thickness: 110 µm
  • Estimated ablation depth: ~12–15 µm per diopter
    • For –7.50 D: 7.5 D × 14 µm/D ≈ 105 µm
  • Total tissue removal: 110 µm + 105 µm = 215 µm
  • RSB calculation: 520 µm – 215 µm = 305 µm
  • Most guidelines now recommend 300 µm of RSB.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inform the patient that effect of LASIK will last for only 7.5 years: LASIK can provide long-lasting results, especially if refraction is stable and myopia is not progressive. This is a counselling point, not a surgical safety criterion to prevent ectasia.

 

Option B. The patient should have keratometry values between 30–40 D: Normal adult keratometry ranges roughly 40–47 D. Values below 40 D indicate an abnormally flat cornea, which may affect flap adhesion but are not the primary safety criterion.

 

Option C. The laser should ablate 25 µm per diopter of correction: Contemporary excimer lasers remove approximately 10–15 µm per diopter, not 25 µm. Overestimating the ablation depth would lead to unnecessary cancellation of surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ensure a residual stromal bed of 300 µm after LASIK to minimize the risk of corneal ectasia, particularly in high myopes.

choices.text: Lateral recess of the fourth ventricle

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient with Neurofibromatosis type 2 undergoes surgical resection for bilateral acoustic neuromas. Postoperatively, the patient is found to have bilateral auditory nerve destruction, making cochlear implantation ineffective. An auditory brainstem implant (ABI) is planned to restore auditory perception. Where is the auditory brainstem implant placed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral recess of the fourth ventricle

 

  • The auditory brainstem implant (ABI) is designed for patients in whom the auditory nerve is non-functional or absent, as in bilateral vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas)—especially in Neurofibromatosis type 2. Unlike cochlear implants, ABIs bypass the auditory nerve and directly stimulate the cochlear nucleus.
  • The cochlear nucleus is located in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle, making this the precise site for ABI placement.
  • The device allows sound perception by stimulating the brainstem auditory pathway directly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal auditory canal: This is where the vestibulocochlear nerve passes, but not a site for ABI placement.

 

Option B. Round window of the cochlea: This is the site for cochlear implants, not ABI.

 

Option D. Inferior colliculus of the midbrain: Higher auditory center; not targeted by ABI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The auditory brainstem implant (ABI) is used when the auditory nerve is destroyed, commonly in bilateral acoustic neuroma, and is surgically placed in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle to stimulate the cochlear nucleus directly.

questions.text: Metformin is least likely to reduce blood sugar in which of the following patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-diabetics

 

  • Metformin is an oral medication commonly used to treat type 2 diabetes. It works by reducing glucose production in the liver, improving insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues, and reducing glucose absorption in the intestines. 
  • As a result, metformin helps to lower blood sugar levels in individuals with diabetes.
  • In non-diabetic individuals, who already have normal blood sugar regulation, the use of metformin is not indicated. 
  • Metformin does not cause hypoglycemia and since the blood sugar levels of non-diabetics are within the normal range, metformin cannot further reduce blood sugar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obese diabetics: Metformin is commonly prescribed to obese individuals with type 2 diabetes as it helps improve insulin sensitivity and control blood sugar levels.

 

Option C. Type 2 diabetics: Metformin is considered a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes and is widely used to reduce blood sugar levels in these patients.

 

Option D. Diabetics not responding to sulfonylureas: When individuals with diabetes do not respond adequately to sulfonylureas (another class of antidiabetic medication), metformin is often added as an adjunct therapy to help improve blood sugar control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is ineffective at lowering blood sugar in non-diabetics; its therapeutic benefit depends on correcting the pathological insulin resistance and excessive hepatic glucose production of type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: A city launches a fall‐prevention exercise program for community‐dwelling seniors. In a controlled trial, supervised sessions reduced fall rates by 40%. When rolled out citywide under usual conditions—with variable attendance and instructor skill—the program reduced falls by 25%. The reduction observed under routine community implementation reflects the programs:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Effectiveness

 

  • Effectiveness measures how well an intervention performs in real‐world settings, incorporating factors such as participant adherence, variability in delivery, and system constraints.
  • The 25% reduction seen in routine practice indicates the program’s effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Efficacy: Refers to performance under the ideal conditions of a controlled trial (40% reduction), not routine implementation. Lab conditions are fully controlled

 

Option C. Internal validity: Relates to the rigor and freedom from bias within a study design, not the real‐world impact.

 

Option D. Cost‐effectiveness: Evaluates the economic value (cost per fall prevented), which is a separate consideration from the program’s performance. It is output in terms of results achieved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An intervention’s effectiveness reflects its impact in usual practice, which is often lower than its efficacy measured under controlled conditions.

questions.text: To treat nets in a high‐resistance area where mosquitoes have partial tolerance to deltamethrin, which alternative pyrethroid and dosage would best match deltamethrin’s initial efficacy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyfluthrin, 50 mg/m²

 

  • Cyfluthrin at 50 mg/m² delivers a nominal twice-the–surface concentration (5% formulation) compared to deltamethrin’s 2.5% at 25 mg/m². 
  • This dosage produces a comparable knockdown and mortality rate against pyrethroid-tolerant mosquitoes, compensating for their reduced sensitivity.
  • Simply increasing deltamethrin concentration risks accelerated wash-off and resistance selection, whereas cyfluthrin’s intrinsic potency and higher dosing maintain efficacy without frequent retreatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Permethrin, 25 mg/m²: Permethrin at this dosage (2% formulation) has inherently lower potency against Anopheles than deltamethrin; it would underperform in tolerant populations.

 

Option C. Etofenprox, 10 mg/m²: Although etofenprox is a pyrethroid-like compound, a 10 mg/m² dosage falls well below the effective surface load needed to match deltamethrin’s knockdown rate.

 

Option D. Lambdacyhalothrin, 5 mg/m²: Lambdacyhalothrin is highly potent, but at only 5 mg/m² (0.5% formulation), its total active load is too low to overcome partial resistance and would give suboptimal control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When migrating from deltamethrin in a high-resistance setting, choose cyfluthrin at 50 mg/m² (5% formulation) to replicate the original net efficacy, rather than simply raising deltamethrin doses or using lower-load alternatives.

choices.text: Persistence of hyperintensity on fat-suppressed T1 images
Loss of signal on T2-weighted images (T2 shading)
Signal dropout on opposed-phase chemical-shift imaging

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with chronic pelvic pain undergoes pelvic MRI. A left ovarian cyst appears hyperintense on both standard T1‐weighted and fat‐suppressed T1 images. Which finding confirms that the high T1 signal arises from blood rather than fat?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Persistence of hyperintensity on fat-suppressed T1 images

 

  • T1 hyperintense → Fat and blood 
  • Fat‐suppression techniques selectively null the signal from lipids.
  • A true fatty lesion (e.g., a dermoid cyst) will lose its high T1 signal when fat‐sat pulses are applied.
  • In contrast, blood breakdown products (methemoglobin) remain bright on T1 even after fat suppression because their T1 shortening effect is independent of lipid content.
  • Thus, if a cyst remains hyperintense after fat saturation, the high signal must be due to proteinaceous or hemorrhagic content, diagnostically pointing to an endometrioma (chocolate cyst).

 

Other Options:
