Statement 2. When metabolic enzymes become saturated: Correct. First‐order elimination assumes that the enzymes or transporters responsible for drug clearance have excess capacity, so rate ∝ concentration. When these pathways are overwhelmed—for example, the enzyme is working at its maximum velocity (Vₘₐₓ)—the elimination rate can no longer increase in proportion to rising drug levels. At this point it shifts to zero‐order, removing a constant amount per time regardless of how high the concentration climbs.

 

Statement 4. At very high‐dose: Correct. In overdose, plasma concentrations often far exceed the Km of metabolic enzymes. Once saturating levels are reached, additional increases in drug concentration will not speed elimination. Hence the body clears a fixed mass of drug per hour (zero‐order), rather than a fixed fraction.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. At very low plasma concentrations: Incorrect. At very low concentrations, enzymes are well below saturation and operate in the first‐order range—clearance remains proportional to concentration.

 

Statement 3. After a single therapeutic dose: Incorrect. A single therapeutic dose typically yields concentrations within the first‐order region; only exceptionally large or sustained dosing overwhelms metabolic capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zero‐order kinetics occurs when elimination pathways are saturated, resulting in a constant amount of drug cleared per unit time—most commonly seen in enzyme‐saturation (high‐dose) contexts like overdoses.

choices.text: To examine the condition of the uterine endometrium
To assess sperm motility and interaction with cervical mucus
To confirm ovulation has taken place
To analyze the consistency and viscosity of cervical mucus alone

questions.text: A couple undergoing evaluation for infertility is advised to undergo a postcoital test (PCT) as part of their diagnostic workup. What is the primary purpose of this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To assess sperm motility and interaction with cervical mucus

 

  • The postcoital test (PCT), also known as the Sims-Huhner test, is performed during infertility evaluation to assess the interaction between sperm and cervical mucus in the peri-ovulatory period.
  • The cervical mucus, under the influence of estrogen, becomes thin and receptive to sperm penetration around ovulation. 
  • The test is conducted within 8–12 hours after intercourse, and a sample of cervical mucus is examined microscopically for:
    • Presence of motile sperm
    • Number of motile sperm per high-power field
    • Sperm motility pattern (progressive vs. sluggish)
  • The purpose of this test is to assess whether the sperm can survive and migrate through the cervical mucus, which is critical for natural conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To examine the condition of the uterine endometrium: Incorrect. The uterine lining is assessed by endometrial biopsy, not the postcoital test. The PCT does not provide information about endometrial health.

 

Option C. To confirm ovulation has taken place: Incorrect. The occurrence of ovulation is typically confirmed through methods such as mid-luteal serum progesterone measurement, ultrasound follicular monitoring, or basal body temperature tracking, not via the postcoital test.

 

Option D. To analyze the consistency and viscosity of cervical mucus alone: Incorrect. Although the postcoital test includes an assessment of cervical mucus properties, its primary aim is to evaluate sperm survival and motility within the mucus after intercourse, not just the mucus characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The postcoital test is performed during infertility evaluation to assess sperm motility and survival within the cervical mucus, providing information on the sperm-cervical mucus interaction critical for natural conception.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is brought to the casualty with maxillofacial trauma after a road traffic accident (RTA). He has altered consciousness and desaturation. What is the preferred method of securing the airway for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheostomy

 

  • Patients with severe maxillofacial trauma are highly likely to experience severe airway compromise or obstruction.
  • In such cases, intubation is necessary to maintain airway competency. 
  • Given the presence of facial trauma, tracheostomy is the preferred method as it bypasses the obstructed upper airway by creating an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mask ventilation: Mask ventilation is often difficult in patients with facial trauma due to structural damage and may not provide a secure airway.

 

Option B. Laryngeal mask airway (LMA): LMA can be used temporarily but is not ideal for long-term airway management in patients with facial trauma as it does not protect against aspiration and may be dislodged.

 

Option D. Nasotracheal intubation: Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in patients with facial trauma due to the risk of further injury to the nasal and facial structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tracheostomy is the preferred method for securing the airway in patients with severe maxillofacial trauma.
  • Mask ventilation and LMA may be used temporarily but do not provide a secure airway.
  • Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in facial trauma due to the risk of further injury.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with T2DM, hypertension, and COPD presents with a 4-day history of worsening shoulder and hip stiffness, lasting over an hour each morning, improving with activity. He denies fever, headache, or vision changes, and has a history of osteoarthritis. Labs show elevated ESR/CRP and normal CPK. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prednisolone
 

  • The patient’s morning stiffness, proximal joint pain, and elevated ESR/CRP with normal CPK suggest polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR).
  • Steroids (prednisolone) are the first-line treatment, leading to rapid symptom improvement.
  • The absence of systemic symptoms rules out giant cell arteritis at this stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rituximab: Is for refractory autoimmune diseases, not first-line for PMR.

 

Option B. Infliximab: Are not used for PMR.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Is for maintenance in some cases, not initial therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PMR presents with proximal stiffness and elevated inflammatory markers, treated with steroids.
  • Rapid response to steroids confirms the diagnosis and prevents complications.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with a history of renal transplant 2 years ago presents to your clinic with a 3-day history of burning with urination, urinary frequency, and foul-smelling urine. He has a history of ESBL E. coli urinary tract infection 6 months ago and is on tacrolimus for immunosuppression. He denies fever or flank pain, but his creatinine is slightly elevated at 1.5 mg/dL from a baseline of 1.2 mg/dL. Which is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Ertapenem

 

  • This renal transplant recipient with immunosuppression presents with features of lower urinary tract infection.
  • The history of ESBL-producing E. coli and mild creatinine rise raises concern for early graft involvement.
  • Ertapenem, a once-daily carbapenem, is effective against ESBL-producing Enterobacteriaceae.
  • It is preferred when Pseudomonas is not suspected, as it avoids unnecessary broad-spectrum exposure.
  • Particularly useful in transplant patients and other immunosuppressed hosts where early empiric coverage is essential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Aztreonam: Not reliably effective against ESBL-producing E. coli.

 

Option B. IV Imipenem: Active against ESBL but broader than necessary; reserved for severe infections or Pseudomonas risk.

 

Option C. Oral Nitrofurantoin: Contraindicated in renal dysfunction (eGFR <60 mL/min); inadequate urinary levels in this setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ertapenem is the empiric drug of choice for ESBL-associated UTIs in renal transplant recipients.
  • It is administered once daily, making it highly suitable for outpatient parenteral therapy (OPAT).
  • Nitrofurantoin is not suitable in patients with impaired renal function or systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl spends the afternoon swimming in a warm freshwater pond near her friend’s village. A week later she develops profuse, purulent nasal discharge, severe headache, and rapidly progressive encephalitis, succumbing within five days. Which pathogen is the most likely cause of her illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Naegleria fowleri

 

  • Free living amoebas 
    • Naegleria
    • Acanthamoeba 
  • Naegleria fowleri—the “brain-eating” amoeba—gains entry via the nasal mucosa when a person swims or dives in warm freshwater.
  •  It migrates along the olfactory nerves through the cribriform plate into the meninges and brain, causing primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM). 
  • PAM has an extremely rapid onset (days), with intense headache, fever, rhinorrhea, and fulminant meningitis leading to death in most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acanthamoeba spp.: Cause chronic granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE) over weeks to months, primarily in immunocompromised hosts, and are acquired by inhalation or through skin lesions—not by acute swimming exposure.

 

Option C. Toxoplasma gondii: Leads to subacute/chronic meningoencephalitis in immunosuppressed patients; transmission is via ingestion of oocysts or undercooked meat, not nasal entry from water.

 

Option D. Plasmodium falciparum: Causes severe malaria with cerebral involvement, but does not produce purulent nasal discharge or acute meningoencephalitis after freshwater exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a previously healthy swimmer develops a fulminant, rapidly fatal meningoencephalitis with nasal symptoms days after freshwater exposure, Naegleria fowleri is the presumptive agent.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with chronic bronchitis produces a sputum specimen that, on Gram stain, reveals delicate, weakly Gram-positive, branching filamentous bacilli with a beaded appearance. Which organism most likely matches these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

  • Branching filamentous bacilli are of 2 types
    • Actinomyces – Lumpy Jaw
    • Nocardia – Pulmonary disease and cutaneous disease (mycetoma)
  • Nocardia species are aerobic, branching filamentous bacteria that stain weakly Gram-positive and often appear beaded. 
  • They exhibit partial acid-fastness due to mycolic acids in their cell wall. 
  • On Gram stain, they form delicate, filamentous networks resembling fungal hyphae, distinguishing them from other bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus: Gram-positive cocci in chains or pairs, not filamentous branching rods.

 

Option C. Corynebacterium: Club-shaped (“palisading”) Gram-positive rods; do not branch extensively or bead.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Thin, slightly curved rods that are weakly Gram-positive but do not form branching filaments and require acid-fast staining for reliable visualization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia on Gram stain - Weakly Gram-positive, branching, filamentous morphology with beaded appearance and partial acid-fast property.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea associated with her menstrual cycles is started on danazol as part of her treatment plan for endometriosis. Which of the following best describes the primary mechanism by which danazol alleviates the symptoms of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suppression of luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion

 

  • Danazol is a synthetic androgen (Gonadotropic Antagonist) used in the management of endometriosis due to its unique endocrine effects. Its primary mechanism of action involves suppression of the pituitary-ovarian axis, particularly by:
    • Inhibiting the release of luteinizing hormone (LH)
    • This suppression leads to decreased ovarian estrogen production.
    • The resultant hypoestrogenic environment causes atrophy of ectopic endometrial tissue, leading to symptomatic relief of pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea associated with endometriosis.
  • Additionally, danazol exhibits weak androgenic activity, contributing to side effects such as acne and hirsutism. However, these androgenic properties are not the primary mechanism by which it treats endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stimulation of progesterone receptor-mediated activity: Incorrect. Stimulation of progesterone receptors is the mechanism of action of progestin therapy, not danazol. Progestins act by decidualizing endometrial tissue and suppressing its growth. Danazol does not primarily stimulate progesterone receptor activity.

 

Option C. Enhancement of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) release: Incorrect. Danazol does not enhance FSH release. In fact, it suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, leading to reduced FSH and LH secretion. Increased FSH release would be counterproductive in endometriosis management.

 

Option D. Inhibition of estrogen synthesis: Incorrect. Direct inhibition of estrogen synthesis is the mechanism of action of aromatase inhibitors, such as letrozole or anastrozole. While danazol indirectly reduces estrogen levels by suppressing gonadotropin release, it does not directly inhibit estrogen production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Danazol alleviates symptoms of endometriosis primarily by suppressing luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion, leading to decreased estrogen production and subsequent atrophy of ectopic endometrial tissue.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with Turner syndrome presents with complaints of fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. Cardiac evaluation reveals a bicuspid aortic valve. What other cardiac anomaly should be screened for in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortic dissection

 

Turner syndrome is associated with an increased risk of aortic dissection, especially in the presence of bicuspid aortic valve or coarctation of the aorta.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral valve prolapse: More common in Marfan syndrome.

 

Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus: Associated with congenital rubella syndrome.

 

Option D. Ventricular septal defect: Can occur in Down syndrome but is less common in Turner syndrome. Associated with Patau syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Turner syndrome and cardiovascular anomalies should be screened for aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the gynecology outpatient department seeking contraceptive advice. She is married, has a 3-year-old son, and is currently taking lamotrigine for epilepsy. She is looking for an effective method of contraception. Use of which of the following contraceptive methods would necessitate increasing the dose of lamotrigine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Combined oral contraceptive pills

 

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) contain estrogen, which enhances the activity of hepatic enzyme uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A4). 
  • This enzyme increases the metabolism of lamotrigine, reducing its plasma concentration.
  • The decreased lamotrigine levels can increase the risk of seizures in epileptic patients.
  • Therefore, when COCPs are prescribed to a woman on lamotrigine, her lamotrigine dose may need to be increased to maintain therapeutic efficacy.
  • Close monitoring of seizure frequency and lamotrigine levels is recommended during the initiation or discontinuation of COCPs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Etonogestrel subdermal implant: Incorrect. The etonogestrel implant is a progestin-only contraceptive that releases the hormone steadily over time. It does not significantly induce hepatic enzymes and therefore does not affect lamotrigine metabolism, making a dose adjustment unnecessary.

 

Option B. Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate injection: Incorrect. Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive with no significant impact on hepatic enzyme activity. It does not alter lamotrigine metabolism, and no dose change is required.

 

Option D. Centchroman (Selective estrogen receptor modulator): Incorrect. Centchroman acts as a selective estrogen receptor modulator with a non-hormonal contraceptive effect. It does not induce hepatic enzymes and therefore does not necessitate any change in lamotrigine dosage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills can increase hepatic metabolism of lamotrigine through enzyme induction, potentially lowering drug levels and requiring a dosage adjustment to prevent seizure breakthrough in women with epilepsy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old park ranger develops fever, headache, and a maculopapular rash affecting extremities and trunk after hiking in a tick-infested area. Doxycycline is started empirically. Which bacterial feature explains why this organism cannot be cultured on standard laboratory agar?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obligate intracellular organism

 

  • Rickettsia species (e.g., Rickettsia rickettsii, the agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever) are obligate intracellular bacteria.
  • They lack many metabolic pathways and rely on host cell machinery and ATP to replicate, making them incapable of growing on cell-free artificial media such as standard blood or chocolate agar.
  • Instead, they must be cultured in living host cells (e.g., yolk sacs, cell lines) or detected by molecular or serologic methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of peptidoglycan: Describes Mycoplasma (which grow on sterol-supplemented PPLO agar) but not Rickettsia.

 

Option B. Modified peptidoglycan inaccessible to nutrients: Refers to Chlamydia, which has a reduced or altered cell-wall structure but also requires intracellular culture primarily due to ATP parasitism.

 

Option D. Requirement for sterol-supplemented medium: Characteristic of Mycoplasma species, not obligate intracellular Rickettsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a suspected tick-borne pathogen fails to grow on routine agar but presents with compatible clinical features, think obligate intracellular organisms like Rickettsia or Chlamydia—these require living cells for culture.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with congenital stapes fixation leading to conductive hearing loss. Histologic analysis shows abnormal development of the stapes footplate. Which of the following embryological structures is primarily responsible for the development of the stapes footplate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Otic capsule

 

  • The stapes has two embryological components:
    • Stapes suprastructure (head and crura): Derived from the 2nd pharyngeal arch (Reichert’s cartilage).
    • Stapes footplate and annular ligament: Derived from the otic capsule, a mesenchymal condensation surrounding the developing otic vesicle.
  • The otic capsule is neural crest– and mesoderm-derived mesenchyme that ossifies and forms parts of the bony labyrinth of the inner ear.
  •  It gives rise not only to the stapes footplate but also to structures like the cochlear capsule and the bony walls of the semicircular canals.
  • Thus, fixation of the stapes footplate (as in otosclerosis) involves a structure of otic capsule origin, not pharyngeal arch mesoderm.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1st pharyngeal arch: 

 

  • Derivatives: Malleus, incus, and muscles of mastication.

 

Option B. 2nd pharyngeal arch:

 

  • Gives rise to the stapes suprastructure, styloid process, lesser horn of hyoid, and muscles of facial expression.

 

Option C. Otic vesicle:

 

  • Forms the membranous labyrinth (e.g., semicircular canals, cochlea, utricle, saccule).
  • It is the epithelial component of the inner ear, not the bony capsule (which is mesenchymal and forms the footplate).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stapes footplate and annular ligament arise from the otic capsule, not from pharyngeal arches.
  • This distinction is critical in understanding the embryology and pathology of congenital and acquired conductive hearing loss, such as otosclerosis, where the otic capsule–derived footplate becomes fixed.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent fever and severe abdominal pain since childhood, prompting multiple exploratory laparotomies with no clear cause. She immigrated to India from Armenia to work in a hotel Spa and now reports calf muscle pain with exercise, limiting her activity. Without additional therapy, what is not at risk of?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systemic Infection
 

  • His presentation is typical of Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF), an autoinflammatory disease seen in individuals of Middle Eastern, Armenian, Turkish, or North African descent.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Recurrent episodes of fever
    • Serositis: abdominal pain, pleuritis, pericarditis
    • Arthralgia or myalgia, especially after exertion
  • The disease is not due to infection, but due to aberrant innate immune activation.
  • If left untreated, FMF can lead to:
    • AA (serum amyloid A) amyloidosis, leading to renal failure
    • Infertility, particularly in women due to tubal damage from peritonitis
    • Intestinal adhesions, due to repeated peritonitis or unnecessary surgeries
  • However, since FMF is not an infectious disease, it does not increase the risk of systemic infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amyloidosis: A known complication of FMF due to persistent elevation of serum amyloid A protein.

 

Option C. Infertility: Chronic pelvic inflammation from peritonitis can impair fertility, especially in women.

 

Option D. Intestinal adhesions: Can occur due to repeated inflammatory episodes or multiple laparotomies, both of which are common in FMF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Familial Mediterranean Fever is an autoinflammatory, non-infectious disorder characterized by recurrent fever and serosal inflammation.
  • Systemic infections are not a risk; complications arise from inflammation, not infection.
  • Untreated FMF may lead to AA amyloidosis, infertility, and abdominal adhesions.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is admitted with fever and signs of endocarditis. Blood cultures grow a Gram-positive coccus in pairs. The organism hydrolyzes esculin in the presence of bile and grows in 6.5% NaCl. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enterococcus faecalis

 

  • Bile esculin test: Organisms that hydrolyze esculin in the presence of bile produce esculetin, which reacts with ferric citrate in the medium to form a black complex.
  • 6.5% NaCl tolerance: Only certain streptococci (enterococci) can withstand high salt concentrations, allowing them to grow in media containing 6.5% sodium chloride.
  • Enterococcus faecalis is both bile esculin–positive and salt-tolerant. 
  • These features distinguish it from most other streptococci and are the basis for separating the enterococci (formerly group D streptococci) from non–enterococcal species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus agalactiae: Group B strep is bile esculin–negative and cannot grow in 6.5% NaCl. It is gram positive cocci in chains

 

Option B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Optochin-sensitive, bile soluble, but bile esculin–negative and salt sensitive.

 

Option D. Streptococcus viridans: Alpha-hemolytic commensals; bile esculin–negative and do not grow in high salt. It is gram positive cocci in chains

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterococci (formerly group D streptococci) are distinguished from other α- or β-hemolytic streptococci by their ability to hydrolyze esculin in bile and tolerate high salt concentrations.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents with eruptive xanthomas, recurrent abdominal pain, and episodes of acute pancreatitis. Lab results show:

  • Fasting triglycerides >1,000 mg/dL
  • Markedly elevated chylomicrons
  • Undetectable lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity

Which dyslipoproteinemia best fits this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Familial Hyperchylomicronemia

 

  • This is a classic presentation of Familial Hyperchylomicronemia (Fredrickson Type I).
  • Caused by LPL deficiency or Apo C-II deficiency (cofactor for LPL)
  • Leads to massive accumulation of chylomicrons in plasma
  • Results in severe hypertriglyceridemia (>1,000 mg/dL)
  • Common symptoms:
    • Eruptive xanthomas (especially on extensor surfaces)
    • Recurrent pancreatitis
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • No increased risk of atherosclerosis (unlike other types)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Familial Hypercholesterolemia (Type IIa):

 

  • Elevated LDL, normal triglycerides
  • Causes tendon xanthomas and early-onset atherosclerosis, not pancreatitis or eruptive xanthomas

 

Option C. Familial Dysbetalipoproteinemia (Type III):

 

  • Elevated IDL/remnant particles
  • Mixed elevation of cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Associated with palmar xanthomas, not severe TG elevation or chylomicrons

 

Option D. Abetalipoproteinemia:

 

  • A rare condition with absence of Apo B-containing lipoproteins (chylomicrons, VLDL, LDL)
  • Results in low cholesterol and TG, fat malabsorption, acanthocytosis, and neurologic issues, not hypertriglyceridemia or pancreatitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frederickson dyslipoproteinemia types and their primary biochemical defects:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with symptoms of urinary urgency, frequency, and nocturia. He has been diagnosed with overactive bladder and his previous medication (oxybutynin) was not effective in managing his symptoms. Which of the following drugs is a beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist that may be effective in treating this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vibegron

 

  • This is a beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist (similar to mirabegron) that is used in the treatment of overactive bladder.
  • By stimulating beta-3 adrenergic receptors in the detrusor muscle of the bladder, it relaxes the muscle and improves symptoms like urinary urgency and frequency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tolterodine: This drug is an antimuscarinic agent, not a beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist. It is commonly used in the treatment of overactive bladder but works through a different mechanism of action than beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonists.

 

Option B. Memantine: Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used primarily in the treatment of moderate-to-severe Alzheimer's disease. It has no role in the treatment of overactive bladder.

 

Option D. Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic drug that is used to treat various types of seizures. It has no role in the treatment of overactive bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patient’s intolerant of anticholinergics or with refractory overactive bladder, β₃-adrenergic agonists like vibegron offer an effective alternative by relaxing detrusor muscle via a distinct receptor pathway and minimizing systemic side effects.

choices.text: The second CI is more likely to contain the true mean because it’s narrower.
The first study had a higher chance of missing the true mean than the second.
Increasing sample size reduces CI width but does not change the confidence level.
A narrower CI always implies higher confidence in the estimate.

questions.text: A researcher reports a 95% confidence interval (CI) for a new drug’s mean systolic blood pressure reduction as (8 mm Hg, 12 mm Hg) based on n = 100 patients. He then repeats the study with n = 1,000 patients and finds a 95% CI of (9.5 mm Hg, 10.5 mm Hg). Which statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increasing sample size reduces CI width but does not change the confidence level.

 

  • Confidence level vs. CI width: 
    • The confidence level (95%) is a property of the method—it means that if you repeated the study many times, 95% of those intervals would capture the true mean. 
    • Changing the sample size does not alter that 95% coverage guarantee.
  • Effect of sample size: 
    • Increasing n reduces the standard error of the mean (SEM = SD/√n), which narrows the CI around the sample estimate.
    • Thus, moving from n = 100 to n = 1,000 makes the interval tighter (from a width of 4 mm Hg down to 1 mm Hg) without changing the confidence level.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The second CI is more likely to contain the true mean because it’s narrower: Narrower CIs are more precise but are not inherently more likely to include the true mean—both intervals have a 95% chance under repeated sampling.

 

Option B. The first study had a higher chance of missing the true mean than the second: Both intervals, being 95% CIs, each have the same 5% chance of failing to capture the true mean, regardless of width.

 

Option D. A narrower CI always implies higher confidence in the estimate: A narrower interval indicates greater precision, not greater confidence. Confidence is set by the chosen level (e.g., 95%), not by interval width.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Precision (interval width) and confidence (coverage probability) are distinct: larger samples yield narrower CIs, but your stated confidence (e.g., 95%) stays the same unless you choose a different confidence level.
